sentence: The Kansas road to a strong republican state was examined by historian Thomas Frank in his 2004 book What's the Matter with Kansas?.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has a history of many firsts in legislative initiatives – it was the first state to establish a workers' compensation system (1910) and regulate the securities industry (1911).

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas also allowed women's suffrage in 1912, almost a decade before the federal Constitution was amended to require it.

name: kansas
sentence: Suffocation in all states would not be guaranteed until the 19th amendment to the United States Constitution was ratified in 1920.

name: kansas
sentence: The board's model of government was adopted by many major Kansas cities in the years following the First World War, while many American cities were run by political machines or organized crime, including the Pendergast machine in nearby Kansas, Missouri.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas was also at the centre of Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka, a 1954 Supreme Court decision that banned racially segregated schools throughout the United States.

name: kansas
sentence: The state supported the Republicans Wendell Willkie and Thomas E. Dewey in 1940 and 1944, respectively.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas also supported Dewey in 1948 despite the presence of outgoing President Harry S. Truman, who came from Independence, Missouri, about 24 kilometres east of the Kansas–Missouri State Line.

name: kansas
sentence: Since Roosevelt carried Kansas in 1932 and 1936, only one democrat won the Kansas vote, Lyndon B. Johnson in 1964.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2008, Governor Kathleen Sebelius vetoed the construction of new coal-fired power plants in Kansas, saying: "We know that greenhouse gases contribute to climate change.

name: kansas
sentence: As an agricultural state, Kansas is especially vulnerable.

name: kansas
sentence: Therefore, reducing pollutants is beneficial not only in the short term, but also for future generations."

name: kansas
sentence: However, shortly after Mark Parkinson became governor in 2009 following Sebelius' resignation as secretary of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Parkinson announced a compromise plan for the construction of a coal-fired plant.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2010, Sam Brownback was elected governor with 63 per cent of the state's votes.

name: kansas
sentence: He was sworn in as governor in 2011, the first republican governor of Kansas in eight years.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback had established himself as a Conservative member of the U.S. senator in previous years, but since becoming governor, he has made several controversial decisions, leading to an approval rating of 23% among the registered voters, the lowest of all governors in the U.S..

name: kansas
sentence: In May 2011, against the opposition of art leaders and state enthusiasts, Brownback eliminated the Kansas Arts Commission, making Kansas the first state without an artistic agency.

name: kansas
sentence: In July 2011, Brownback announced its intention to close the Lawrence branch of the Kansas Department of Social Services and Rehabilitation as a cost-saving measure.

name: kansas
sentence: Hundreds have rallied against this decision.

name: kansas
sentence: The City of Lawrence Commission then voted to provide the necessary funding to keep the branch open.

sentence: The Democrat Laura Kelly defeated the former Secretary of State of Kansas Kris Kobach during the governor's election in 2018 with 48.0% of the vote.

name: kansas
sentence: The current state delegation to the United States Congress includes Republican Senators Pat Roberts of Dodge City and Jerry Moran of Manhattan, as well as Republican Representatives Roger Marshall of Great Bend (District 1), Steve Watkins (District 2), Ron Estes of Wichita (District 4) and Democratic Representative Sharice Davids (District 3).

name: kansas
sentence: Davids is the second Indian to represent Kansas in Congress, after Republican Charles Curtis (Kaw).

name: kansas
sentence: Historically, Kansas was heavily republican, dating from the Antebellum age when the Republican Party was created from the movement opposing the expansion of slavery in Kansas territory.

name: kansas
sentence: Kansas has not elected a Democrat in the U.S. Senate since the 1932 election, when Franklin D. Roosevelt won his first term as President following the Great Depression.

name: kansas
sentence: This is the longest series of Senators' losses for either party in a single state.

name: kansas
sentence: Senator Sam Brownback was a candidate for the position of President of the Republican Party in 2008.

name: kansas
sentence: Brownback was not a candidate for re-election for a third full term in 2010, but he was elected governor in that year's general election.

name: kansas
sentence: Moran defeated Tiahrt for the Republican nomination for Brownback's seat in the August 2010 primary and then won an overwhelming victory in the general election against the Democrat Lisa Johnston.

sentence: The only candidates for the non-republican presidency that Kansas gave his election vote were populist James Weaver and democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt (twice) and Lyndon Johnson.

name: kansas
sentence: In 2004, George W. Bush won the state's six election votes with an overwhelming margin of 25 percentage points with 62% of the votes.

name: kansas
sentence: The only two counties supporting Democratic John Kerry in this election were Wyandotte, which contains Kansas City, and Douglas, which houses the University of Kansas, located in Lawrence.

name: kansas
sentence: The 2008 elections yielded results similar to those won by John McCain with 57% of the vote.

name: kansas
sentence: Douglas, Wyandotte and Crawford County were the only counties to support President Barack Obama.

sentence: Abilene was the childhood home of Republican President Dwight D. Eisenhower, and he maintained ties of life with his family and friends there.

sentence: During the 19th century, the Kentucky slaves began selling useless slaves to the deep south, Louisville becoming a large slave market and a port of departure for the slaves transported downstream.

sentence: Kentucky was one of the frontier states during the American Civil War.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although often described as having never seceded, representatives of 68 out of 110 counties met in Russellville, claiming to be the "Kentucky People's Convention" and passed a secession order on 20 Nov. 1861.

name: kentucky
sentence: They established a confederate Kentucky government with its capital in Bowling Green.

name: kentucky
sentence: Although Kentucky was represented by the central star on the Confederate Combat Flag, it remained officially "neutral" throughout the war because of the Union's sympathies of the majority of Commonwealth citizens.

name: kentucky
sentence: Some 21st-century Kentuckians celebrate Confederate Memorial Day on the anniversary of Confederate Chief Jefferson Davis on June 3, and participate in the reconstitution of the Confederate Battle.

name: kentucky
sentence: Davis and Abraham Lincoln, U.S. president, were both born in Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: John C. Breckinridge, the 14th and youngest vice-president, was born in Lexington, Kentucky, at Dale Farm in Cabell.

name: kentucky
sentence: On January 30, 1900, Governor William Goebel, flanked by two bodyguards, was fatally wounded by a murderer while travelling to the State Capitol in downtown Frankfort.

name: kentucky
sentence: Goebel challenged the election of the governor of Kentucky in 1899, which William S. Taylor had first won.

name: kentucky
sentence: For several months, J. C. W. Beckham, Goebel's second, and Taylor fought for who the legal governor was, until the United States Supreme Court ruled in favour of Beckham in May.

name: kentucky
sentence: After fleeing to Indiana, Taylor was charged as a co-conspirator in the murder of Goebel.

name: kentucky
sentence: Goebel is the only governor of an American state to have been murdered during his term of office.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Black Patch Tobacco Wars, a vigilante action, took place in the west of Kentucky in the early 20th century.

name: kentucky
sentence: Due to the monopoly of the tobacco industry, tobacco producers in the region were forced to sell their crops at too low prices.

name: kentucky
sentence: Many local farmers and activists joined forces to refuse to sell their crops to large tobacco companies.

name: kentucky
sentence: A meeting of the Association took place in downtown Guthrie, where a vigilant wing of "Night Riders" was formed.

name: kentucky
sentence: Runners terrorized farmers who sold their tobacco at the low prices demanded by tobacco companies.

sentence: During the later period of their operation, they were known to physically attack the farmers who broke up the boycott.

sentence: Governor Auguste E. Willson declared martial law and deployed the Kentucky National Guard to end the wars.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of the four U.S. states that officially use the term commonwealth.

name: kentucky
sentence: The term was used for Kentucky as it had also been used by Virginia, from which Kentucky was created.

name: kentucky
sentence: The term has no particular meaning in its sense and was chosen to emphasize the distinction between the status of the royal colonies as a place governed by the general well-being of the population.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky was originally referred to as the "State of Kentucky" in the act accepting it to the union, as it was called in the first Kentucky constitution.

name: kentucky
sentence: The term commonwealth was used in citizens' petitions submitted between 1786 and 1792 for the creation of the State.

name: kentucky
sentence: It was also used in the title of a state history that was published in 1834 and was used in various places in this book with reference to Virginia and Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: The other three states officially referred to as "commonwealths" are Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

name: kentucky
sentence: Puerto Rico and the Northern Mariana Islands are also officially municipalities.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of only five states that elect their state officials in odd years (the others being Louisiana, Mississippi, New Jersey and Virginia).

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky holds elections for these offices every four years in the years preceding the presidential election.

name: kentucky
sentence: For example, Kentucky held Governor elections in 2011, 2015 and 2019.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Executive is headed by the Governor, who is both Head of State and Head of Government.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Lieutenant Governor may or may not have executive authority depending on whether the person is a member of the Governor's Cabinet.

name: kentucky
sentence: Under the current Constitution of Kentucky, the Lieutenant Governor assumes the functions of the Governor only if the Governor is unable to do so.

name: kentucky
sentence: (Before 1992, the Lieutenant Governor assumed power at any time when the Governor had left the state.)

name: kentucky
sentence: The Governor and the Lieutenant Governor generally have a single ticket (also under a 1992 constitutional amendment) and are elected for a four-year term.

name: kentucky
sentence: The current Governor is Andy Beshear and the Lieutenant Governor is Jacqueline Coleman.

name: kentucky
sentence: Both are Democrats.

name: kentucky
sentence: The executive branch consists of the following "cabinets", each headed by a secretary who is also a member of the cabinet of the governor:

name: kentucky
sentence: The cabinet system was introduced in 1972 by Governor Wendell Ford to consolidate hundreds of government entities that directly related to the governor's office.

name: kentucky
sentence: Other elected constitutional positions include the Secretary of State, the Attorney General, the Auditor of Public Accounts, the Treasurer of State and the Commissioner for Agriculture.

name: kentucky
sentence: Currently, Republican Michael G. Adams is Secretary of State.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Chief Prosecutor, the law enforcement officer and the commonwealth justice officer is the Attorney General, currently Republican Daniel Cameron.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Public Auditor is Republican Mike Harmon.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Allison Republican Ball is the current treasurer.

name: kentucky
sentence: Republican Ryan Quarles is the current Commissioner of Agriculture.

name: kentucky
sentence: The legislative power of Kentucky consists of a bicameral body known as the Kentucky General Assembly.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Senator is considered to be the Upper House.

name: kentucky
sentence: It has 38 members and is led by the Speaker of the Senate, currently Robert Stivers (R).

name: kentucky
sentence: The House of Representatives has 100 members and is headed by the Speaker of the Chamber, currently David Osborne of the Republican Party.

name: kentucky
sentence: In November 2016, the Republicans won House control for the first time since 1922, and currently have supermajorities in the House and Senator.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky's judicial branch is called the Kentucky Court of Justice and includes limited courts of jurisdiction called district courts; general courts of jurisdiction called circuit courts; specialized courts such as the Drug and Family Courts; an intermediate court of appeal, the Kentucky Court of Appeal; and a final court of appeal, the Kentucky Supreme Court.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Kentucky Court of Justice is headed by the Commonwealth President.

name: kentucky
sentence: The Chief Justice is appointed by the Supreme Court of Kentucky.

name: kentucky
sentence: The present Chief Justice is John D. Minton Jr.

name: kentucky
sentence: Unlike federal judges, who are usually appointed, judges sitting in Kentucky State courts are chosen by the public in non-partisan elections.

sentence: The state is divided into six congressional districts, represented by Republicans James Comer (1st), Brett Guthrie (2nd), Thomas Massie (4th), Hal Rogers (5th) and Andy Barr (6th) and Democrat John Yarmuth (3rd).

name: kentucky
sentence: In the federal judiciary, Kentucky is served by two U.S. District Courts: the Eastern Kentucky District, with its main headquarters in Lexington, and the Western Kentucky District, with its main headquarters in Louisville.

name: kentucky
sentence: Appeals are heard by the Sixth Circuit Court of Appeal, based in Cincinnati, Ohio.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky Laws, known as the Revised Kentucky Statutes (KRS), were enacted in 1942 to better organize and clarify the entire Kentucky Act.

name: kentucky
sentence: The laws are enforced by local police, sheriffs and deputy sheriffs, as well as deputy police officers and gendarmes.

name: kentucky
sentence: In addition, in 1948, the Kentucky General Assembly created the Kentucky State Police, making it the 38th state to create a force whose jurisdiction extends to the entire state.

name: kentucky
sentence: Kentucky is one of the 32 states in the United States that punishes the death penalty for some murders defined as heinous.

name: kentucky
sentence: Persons convicted of capital offences after 31 March 1998 are still executed by lethal injection; persons convicted by that date may opt for the electric chair.

name: kentucky
sentence: Only three persons have been executed in Kentucky since the United States Supreme Court re-established this practice in 1976.

Mercer County's ACLU case, wrote that an exhibition including the Mayflower Compact, the Declaration of Independence, the Ten Commandments, the Magna Carta, the Star-Spangled Banner, and the national motto could be erected in the Mercer County Courthouse.

sentence: In the presidential elections of the 21st century, the state became a republican bastion, supporting the presidential candidates of this party by double-digit margins from 2000 to 2016.

sentence: Kentucky has also been a long-standing major centre of the tobacco industry – both as a business and as a tobacco farming centre.

sentence: Kentucky has a classified general property tax system.

sentence: All categories of property, unless exempted by the Constitution, are taxed by the State, although at very varying rates.

sentence: There is no definitive explanation for the origin of the name "Maine", but the most probable is that the first explorers named it after the former province of Maine in France.

sentence: As for the good and true substances of the earth, we are for the most part still totally ignorant of them, vnlesse it bee the parts around the bay of Chisapeack and Sagadahock: but here and there we have touched or haue seen a little bit the edges of these great dominions, which stretch them selves in Maine, God knows how many thousands of miles;" Note that his description of the continent of North America is "the Maine".

name: maine
sentence: "MAINE" appears in the Domesday Book of 1086 in reference to Dorset County, which is now Broadmayne, just southeast of Dorchester.

name: maine
sentence: The general point of view among British researchers of place names is that Mayne in Dorset is Brytonic, corresponding to the modern Welsh "maen", plural "hand" or "meini".

sentence: Some early spellings are: MAINE 1086, MEINE 1200, MEines 1204, MAYNE 1236.

name: maine
sentence: The first known registration of the name appears in a land charter of 10 August 1622 to Sir Ferdinando Gorges and to Captain John Mason, veterans of the British Royal Navy, who were granted a vast territory in the present Maine which Mason and Gorges "intended to appoint the Province of Maine".

name: maine
sentence: Mason had served with the Royal Navy in the Orkney Islands, where the main island is called Mainland, a possible name diversion for these English sailors.

name: maine
sentence: In 1623 English naval captain Christopher Levett, exploring the coast of New England, wrote: "The first place on which I set my foot in New England was the island of Shoals, being Ilands [sic] in the sea, over two Leagues of the Mayne."

sentence: A charter reconfirmed and strengthened on April 3, 1639, by the King of England Charles I, entrusted Sir Ferdinando Gorges with increased powers over his new province and declared that it "will be forever called and named the PROVINCE OR CUNTY OF MAINE, and not by any other name or name whatsoever..." Maine is the only American state whose name has only one syllable.

name: maine
sentence: The first inhabitants of the territory which is now Maine were the Algonquian Wabanaki peoples, including Passamaquoddy, Maliseet, Penobscot, Androscoggin and Kennebec.

name: maine
sentence: During the last war of King Philip, many of these peoples would merge in one form or another to become the Wabanaki Confederation, helping the Wampanoag of Massachusetts and the Mahican of New York.

name: maine
sentence: Subsequently, many of these people were driven out of their natural territories, but most of the tribes of Maine continued, without change, until the American Revolution.

name: maine
sentence: Before that, however, most of these people were considered to be separate nations.

name: maine
sentence: Many had adapted to life in permanent Iroquois-inspired settlements, while those along the coast tended to be semi-nomadic – moving from establishment to establishment over an annual cycle.

name: maine
sentence: They usually winter inland and head to the coast by summer.

name: maine
sentence: European contact with what is now known as Maine may have started around 1200 CE when the Norwegians interacted with the native Penobscot in the present county of Hancock, probably thanks to trade.

name: maine
sentence: If this were confirmed, Maine would be the site of the first European landings in the United States.

name: maine
sentence: About 200 years earlier, from colonies in Iceland and Greenland, Norwegians first identified America and attempted to settle in areas like Newfoundland, but failed to establish a permanent settlement.

name: maine
sentence: Archaeological evidence suggests that Greenlanders returned to North America for centuries after the initial discovery to trade and collect wood, with the most relevant evidence being Maine Penny, an 11th-century Norwegian piece found at an Amerindian excavation site in 1954.

name: maine
sentence: The first European establishment confirmed in modern Maine was in 1604 on Sainte-Croix Island, led by French explorer Pierre Dugua, Sieur de Mons.

name: maine
sentence: Popham's settlers returned to Britain after 14 months.

name: maine
sentence: The French established two Jesuit missions: one on the bay of Penobscot in 1609 and the other on the island of Mount Desert in 1613.

name: maine
sentence: The central Maine was once inhabited by the Androscoggin tribe of the Abenaki Nation, also known as Arosaguntacook.

name: maine

name: maine
sentence: They were resettled in St. Francis, Canada, which was destroyed by Rogers' Rangers in 1759, and is now Odanak.

name: maine
sentence: The other Abenaki tribes suffered several severe defeats, especially during the Dummer War, with the capture of Norridgewock in 1724 and the defeat of the Pequawket in 1725, which greatly reduced their numbers.

name: maine
sentence: They eventually retired to Canada, where they settled in Bécancour and Sillery, and then in Saint-François, along with other southern refugee tribes.

name: maine
sentence: The province, within its current boundaries, was part of the Massachusetts Bay colony in 1652.

name: maine
sentence: Maine was much fought by the French, English and Allies during the 17th and 18th centuries, who carried out raids against each other, taking captives for ransom or, in some cases, adoption by the Amerindian tribes.

name: maine
sentence: A notable example was the raid by Abenaki on York in early 1692, where about 100 English settlers were killed and another about 80 taken hostage.

name: maine
sentence: The Abenakis captured during the Massachusetts raids in the Queen Anne's War of the early 1700s at Kahnewake, a Catholic Mohawk village near Montreal, where some were adopted and others bought.

name: maine
sentence: After the British defeated the French in Acadia in the 1740s, the territory of the Penobscot River fell under the nominal authority of the province of Nova Scotia and, with present-day New Brunswick, formed Sunbury County, Nova Scotia, with its general session court in Campobello.

name: maine
sentence: American and British forces opposed the territory of Maine during the American Revolution and the War of 1812, with the British occupying East Maine in both conflicts through the colony of New Ireland.

name: maine
sentence: The territory of Maine was confirmed as part of Massachusetts when the United States was formed as a result of the Paris Treaty ending the revolution, although the final boundary with British North America was established only with the Treaty of Webster–Ashburton of 1842.

name: maine
sentence: Maine was physically separated from the rest of the Massachusetts.

sentence: Long-standing disagreements over land speculation and settlements led the residents of Maine and their allies in Massachusetts to impose a vote of 1807 in the Massachusetts Assembly to allow Maine to separate

name: maine
sentence: During the War of 1812, pro-British merchants in Massachusetts opposed the war and refused to defend Maine against the British invaders.

name: maine
sentence: In 1819, Massachusetts agreed to allow secession, sanctioned by voters in the growing area the following year.

name: maine
sentence: Formal secession and formation of the State of Maine as the 23rd State took place on 15 March 1820, within the framework of the Missouri compromise, which geographically limited the spread of slavery and allowed admission to the State of Missouri the following year, maintaining a balance between the slave and the free states.

name: maine

sentence: Maine has a humid continental climate (climate classification Köppen Dfb), with warm and sometimes humid summers, and long, cold and very snowy winters.

name: maine
sentence: Winters are particularly severe in the north and west of Maine, while coastal areas are slightly moderated by the Atlantic Ocean, resulting in milder winters and cooler summers than inland areas.

name: maine
sentence: Daytime peaks are generally between 75 and 80°F (24 and 27°C) in the state as a whole in July, with nightfalls at the highest 50°F (approximately 15°C).

name: maine
sentence: January temperatures range from 30°F (−1°C) on the south coast to 0°F (−18°C) on average for the night in the far north.

name: maine
sentence: The record state temperature is 105°F (41°C), set in July 1911, at North Bridgton.Precipitation in Maine is evenly distributed throughout the year, but with a slight summer maximum in north/northwest Maine and a slight end of fall or beginning of winter along the coast due to "no'esters" or intense cold-season rains and snow storms.

name: maine
sentence: In coastal Maine, late spring and summer months are usually the driest, a rarity in the eastern United States.

name: maine
sentence: Maine has fewer storm days than any other state east of the Rocky Mountains, with most of the average condition less than 20 storm days per year.

name: maine
sentence: The tornadoes are rare in Maine, with an average of less than four per year, although this number is increasing.

name: maine
sentence: The most severe thunderstorms and tornadoes occur in the Sebago and Foothills Lakes area of the state.

name: maine
sentence: Maine rarely sees the effect of tropical cyclones, as they tend to pass well to the east and south or are heavily weakened when they reach Maine.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland government is led according to the constitution of the state.

name: maryland
sentence: The Maryland Government, like the other 49 state governments, has exclusive authority over matters that are entirely within the borders of the state, with the exception of those limited by the United States Constitution.

name: maryland

sentence: Maryland imposes five tax brackets, ranging from 2 to 6.25 percent of personal income.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts, officially known as Commonwealth of Massachusetts, is the most populous state in New England in the northeastern United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It borders the Atlantic Ocean to the east, Connecticut and Rhode Island states to the south, New Hampshire and Vermont to the north, and New York to the west.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The capital of Massachusetts is Boston, which is also the most populated city in New England.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It is home to the Greater Boston Metropolitan Area, an area that has an impact on the history, academia and industry of the United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Originally dependent on agriculture, fisheries and commerce, Massachusetts was transformed into a manufacturing centre during the industrial revolution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: During the 20th century, the economy of Massachusetts shifted from manufacturing to services.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Modern Massachusetts is a world leader in biotechnology, engineering, higher education, finance and maritime trade.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Plymouth was the site of the second colony in New England after Popham Colony in 1607 in what is now the Maine.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Plymouth was founded in 1620 by the pilgrims, passengers of the Mayflower.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1692 Salem and the surrounding area experienced one of the most famous cases of mass hysteria in America, the Salem witch trial.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1777 General Henry Knox founded the Springfield Armory, which, during the Industrial Revolution, catalyzed many important technological advances, including interchangeable parts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 1786 Shays' rebellion, a populist revolt led by veterans of the American Revolutionary War, influenced the United States Constitutional Convention.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the 18th century, the first great Protestant revival, which swept Britain and the 13 colonies, came from the pulpit of Northampton preacher Jonathan Edwards.

name: massachusetts
sentence: At the end of the 18th century, Boston became known as "Cradle of Liberty" for its agitation which later led to the American Revolution.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The entire Commonwealth of Massachusetts has played a strong scientific, commercial and cultural role in the history of the United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Before the American Civil War, Massachusetts was a centre of abolitionist, temperant, and transcendentalist movements.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In the late 19th century, basketball and volleyball were invented in the cities of Springfield and Holyoke, respectively, in western Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 2004, Massachusetts became the first U.S. state to legally recognize same-sex marriage following the decision of the Massachusetts Supreme Court in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Many prominent American political dynasties originate from the state, including the Adams and Kennedy families.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Harvard University in Cambridge is the oldest institution of higher education in the United States, with the largest funding from any university, and Harvard Law School has trained a contemporary majority of judges of the Supreme Court of the United States.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Kendall Square in Cambridge has been called "the most innovative square kilometre on the planet", in reference to the high concentration of entrepreneurial start-ups and the quality of innovation that have appeared near the square since 2010.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Harvard and MIT, also in Cambridge, were ranked among the world's top academic institutions.

sentence: Students in Massachusetts public schools are among the highest levels of academic performance in the world.

sentence: The state has been ranked as one of the main states in the United States for citizens to live in, as well as one of the most expensive.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It has been translated as "near the great hill", "by the blue hills", "on the small large hill", or "on the range of the hills", referring to the blue hills, or in particular the Grande Colline Bleue, which is located at the edge of Milton and Canton.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was originally inhabited by tribes of the Algonquian family such as Wampanoag, Narragansett, Nipmuc, Pocomtuc, Mahican, and Massachusett.

name: massachusetts
sentence: While cultivation of crops such as squash and corn complemented their diet, these tribes generally depended on hunting, gathering, and fishing for most of their food.

sentence: The villages consisted of lodges called wigwams and long houses, and the tribes were led by elders, male or female, known as sachems.

sentence: Warmer temperatures will also disrupt the migration of birds and the flowering of flora.

name: massachusetts

name: massachusetts
sentence: The State of Massachusetts has developed a plethora of incentives to encourage the implementation of renewable energy and efficient household appliances and facilities.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Mass Save was created in collaboration with the state by Berkshire Gas, Blackstone Gas Company, Cape Light Compact, Eversource, Liberty Utilities, National Grid and Unitil to provide homeowners and tenants with incentives to renovate their homes with efficient HVAC equipment and other household appliances.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For example, up to $100 in rebates can be obtained for upgrading an ENERGY STAR certified smart or programmable thermostat.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other appliances, such as water heaters, air conditioners, washers and dryers, and heat pumps, are eligible for additional rebates.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The concept of Mass Save was created in 2008 by the adoption of the Green Communities Act of 2008 during the Deval Patrick regime.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The main objective of the Green Communities Act was to reduce fossil fuel consumption in the State and to encourage the adoption of new, more efficient technologies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Among other things, one of the consequences of this Act has been the obligation for public service program administrators to invest in energy saving, as opposed to the purchase and production of additional energy where economically feasible.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In Massachusetts, eleven program administrators, including NStar, National Grid, Western Massachusetts Electric, Cape Light Compact, Till and Berkshire Gas, jointly hold the program rights, in collaboration with the Ministry of Energy Resources (DOER) and the Advisory Council on Energy Efficiency (CCEE).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Mass Save also conducts home energy assessments free of charge so that homeowners, tenants and small business owners can learn about energy efficiency home improvements and find opportunities to save money and energy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: During the home evaluation, Mass Save provides ENERGY STAR certified LED bulbs, power bands, low-flow shower heads, faucet aerators and efficient thermostats for free.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In addition, air leaks will be detected in the house or building and corrected, and recommendations will be made to install additional insulation to reduce the loss of heated or cooled air.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Reductions of 75 per cent or more are available on these insulation improvements.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Due to COVID-19, Mass Save is currently conducting remote assessments.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Residents can plan a remote assessment using the program's website or telephone line.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The State Revenue Service offers incentives for the installation of solar panels.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In addition to the federal residential renewable energy credit, residents of Massachusetts may qualify for a tax credit of up to 15 per cent of the project.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Once installed, tables are eligible for net measurement.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Some municipalities will offer up to $1.20 per watt, up to 50% of the system cost on photovoltaic networks of 25 kW or less.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The programme is expected to end on 31 December 2020.

name: massachusetts
sentence: As part of efforts by the Massachusetts Department of Energy Resources (Massachusetts Department of Energy Resources) to encourage the use of renewable energy, the MOR-EV (Massachusetts Offers Rebates for Electric Vehicles) was established.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Through this incentive measure, residents may be eligible for up to $2,500 in state incentives for the purchase or rental of an electric vehicle, or $1,500 for the purchase or rental of a plug-in hybrid vehicle.

name: massachusetts
sentence: This rebate is in addition to the U.S. Department of Energy tax credits for the purchase of hybrid electric and rechargeable vehicles.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For income-eligible residents, Mass Save has partnered with Massachusetts Community Action Program and LEAN (Low-Income Energy Affordability Network) organizations to provide housing improvement assistance to residents, which will enable more efficient use of energy.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Residents may be entitled to a replacement of their heating system, insulation system, appliances and thermostats if they meet the income requirements set out on the Mass Save website.

name: massachusetts
sentence: For residents of more than 5 family residential buildings, there are additional benefits limited to available income through LEAN.

name: massachusetts
sentence: If at least 50% of the building's residents are eligible for low income, energy efficiency improvements such as those available through Mass Save are available.

sentence: Residential structures operated by non-profit organizations, for gainful activities or housing organizations can benefit from these programs.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In 2018, Massachusetts' education system was ranked first among the fifty U.S. states by US News & World Report.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was the first state in North America to require municipalities to appoint a teacher or establish a secondary school with the passage of the Massachusetts Education Act of 1647, and the 19th-century reforms initiated by Horace Mann laid much of the foundation for contemporary universal public education, which was established in 1852.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts is home to the oldest permanent school in North America (the Roxbury Latin School, founded in 1645), as well as the oldest public primary school in the country (the Mather School, founded in 1639), its oldest secondary school (Boston Latin School, founded in 1635), its oldest continuing boarding school (The Governor's Academy, founded in 1763), its oldest college (Harvard University, founded in 1636), and its oldest women's college (Mont Holyoke College, founded in 1837).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts is also home to the highest private secondary school in the United States, Phillips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts, which was founded in 1778.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Depending on how it is calculated, the tax burden of states and local authorities in Massachusetts was estimated among U.S. states and Washington as the 21st highest ($11.44% or $6,163 per year for a household with a national median income) or the 25th highest overall with a lower-than-average corporate tax (39th higher), a higher-than-average personal income tax, the 13th highest), a higher-than-average sales tax (18th higher) and a lower-than-average property tax (46th higher).

sentence: In the 1970s, the Commonwealth ranked itself as a relatively high tax state, winning the pejorative nickname "Taxachusetts".

sentence: This was followed by a series of tax restrictions in the 1980s, a conservative period in American policy, including the 21⁄2 proposal.

name: massachusetts
sentence: As of January 1, 2019, Massachusetts has a flat-rate personal income tax rate of 5.05 per cent, after an election referendum in 2002 to reduce it to 5.0 per cent, as amended by the legislature.

name: massachusetts
sentence: There is a tax exemption for income below a threshold that varies from year to year.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The corporate income tax rate is 8.8% and the short-term capital gains tax rate is 12%.

name: massachusetts
sentence: An unusual provision allows registrants to voluntarily pay at the pre-referendum tax rate of 5.85 per cent, which occurs between one and two thousand taxpayers per year.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Crown imposes a sales tax of 6.25% on retail sales of tangible personal property, except for groceries, clothing (up to $175.00) and periodicals.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Sales tax is charged on clothing that costs more than $175.00 for an amount exceeding $175.00.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts also charges a user tax when goods are purchased from other states and the vendor does not pay Massachusetts sales tax; taxpayers report and pay the tax on their income tax forms or on special forms, although there are "safe harbour" amounts that can be paid without counting actual purchases (except for purchases over $1,000).

name: massachusetts
sentence: There is no estate tax and Massachusetts limited estate tax associated with the collection of federal estate tax.

sentence: The Massachusetts electricity generation market was competitive in 1998, allowing retail customers to switch suppliers without changing utilities.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts has a long political history; previous political structures included the Mayflower Compact of 1620, the distinct colonies of Massachusetts Bay and Plymouth, and the combined colonial province of Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts Constitution was ratified in 1780 when the revolutionary war was under way, four years after the articles of Confederation were drafted, and eight years before the current United States Constitution was ratified on 21 June 1788.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Drafted by John Adams, the Massachusetts Constitution is currently the oldest permanent written constitution in the world.

name: massachusetts
sentence: It has been amended 120 times, most recently in 2000.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The policy of Massachusetts since the second half of the 20th century has generally been dominated by the Democratic Party, and the state has the reputation of being the country's most liberal state.

sentence: In 1974, Elaine Noble became the first openly lesbian or gay candidate elected to a state legislature in US history.

sentence: The state housed the first openly gay member of the United States House of Representatives, Gerry Studds, in 1972 and 2004, Massachusetts became the first state to allow same-sex marriage.

sentence: In 2006, Massachusetts became the first state to approve a law that provided for almost universal health care.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts Government is divided into three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Governor of Massachusetts directs the executive; the Governor's duties include signing or vetoing the law, filling judicial and organizational positions, granting pardons, preparing an annual budget and ordering the Massachusetts National Guard.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The governors of Massachusetts, unlike the governors of most other states, are treated as His Excellency.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The present governor is Charlie Baker, a Swampscott Republican.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Executive also includes the Executive Council, composed of eight elected councillors and the seat of Lieutenant Governor, currently occupied by Karyn Polito, a Republican of Shrewsbury.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The capacity of the Council includes the confirmation of Governor appointments and the certification of elections.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts House of Representatives and the Massachusetts Senators include the Massachusetts Legislature, known as the Massachusetts General Court.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The House is made up of 160 members, while the Senator has 40 members.

name: massachusetts
sentence: House leaders and senators are chosen by the members of these bodies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Each section is composed of several committees.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The members of these two bodies are elected for a term of two years.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Massachusetts Supreme Court of Justice (one Chief Justice and six Associates) is appointed by the Governor and confirmed by the Executive Council, as well as all other judges of the State.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The delegation of the Massachusetts Congress is completely democratic.

sentence: Currently, senators are Elizabeth Warren and Ed Markey, while representatives are Richard Neal (1st), Jim McGovern (2nd), Lori Trahan (3rd), Joseph Kennedy III (4th), Katherine Clark (5th), Seth Molton (6th), Ayanna Pressley (7th), Stephen Lynch (8th) and Bill Keating (9th).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Federal court decisions are heard by the United States District Court for the Massachusetts District, and appeals are heard by the United States Court of Appeal for the first round.

sentence: In the US presidential election since 2012, Massachusetts won 11 votes in the electoral college, out of a total of 538.

sentence: Like most states, Massachusetts electoral votes are given in a winning system.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts has gradually moved from a republican state to a largely democrat-dominated state; John F. Kennedy's 1952 victory over current Senator Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr., is considered a pivotal moment in this transformation.

name: massachusetts
sentence: His younger brother Edward M. Kennedy held this seat until his death from a brain tumor in 2009.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Since the 1950s, Massachusetts has gained a reputation as a liberal political state and is often used as an archetype of modern liberalism, hence the expression "liberal Massachusetts".

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts is easily one of the country's most democratic states.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The basic democratic concentrations are everywhere, with the exception of a handful of republican cities tilted in the central and southern parts of the State.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Until recently, Republicans were dominant in the western and northern suburbs of Boston, but both regions heavily swept the Democrats back in Trump's day.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The state as a whole has not given its votes in the Electoral College to a Republican in a presidential election since Ronald Reagan carried it in 1984.

sentence: In 2020, Biden won 65.6% of the votes, the best performance in more than 50 years for a Democrat.

sentence: Massachusetts is the most populous state represented in the United States Congress by a single party.

sentence: Since the 2018 elections, the Democratic Party has held a super-majority over the Republican Party in the two chambers of the Massachusetts General Court (state legislature).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Of the 160 seats in the State Chamber, the Democrats hold 127 seats (79 per cent) compared to the 32 seats in the Republican Party (20 per cent), one independent seat in the rest, and 34 of the 40 seats in the State Senate (85 per cent) belong to the Democratic Party compared to the six seats in the Republican Party (15 per cent).

name: massachusetts
sentence: Both chambers of Parliament have had democratic majorities since the 1950s.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Despite the democratic tendency of the state, Massachusetts has generally elected Republicans as governor: only one Democrat (Deval Patrick) has been governor since 1991 and among the results of the Guberatorial elections from 2002 to 2018, Republican candidates have won 48.4% of the vote against 45.7% for Democratic candidates.

Wade, dropped the age of parental consent for those seeking abortion from 18 to 16 years and legalized abortion after 24 weeks, if a fetus had fatal anomalies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts has 50 cities and 301 cities grouped into 14 counties.

sentence: The 14 counties, which move approximately from west to east, are Berkshire, Franklin, Hampshire, Hampden, Worcester, Middlesex, Essex, Suffolk, Norfolk, Bristol, Plymouth, Barnstable, Dukes and Nantucket.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Eleven communities that are called "towns" are, by law, cities since they have exchanged the form of city meeting government for a form of mayor-counsel or manager-counsel.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Boston is the state capital and largest city of Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The city itself has a population of 692,600, and Greater Boston, with a population of 4,873,019, is the 11th metropolitan area of the nation.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other cities with more than 100,000 inhabitants are Worcester, Springfield, Lowell and Cambridge.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Plymouth is the largest municipality in the state by region followed by Middleborough.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts, along with the other five states of New England, presents the local government structure known as the city of New England.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Within this structure, integrated cities, as opposed to cantons or counties, hold many of the responsibilities and powers of local government.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Most county governments were abolished by the State of Massachusetts beginning in 1997, including Middlesex County, the largest county in the state by population.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The voters in these now defeated counties elect only the sheriffs and the registers of acts, which are part of the government of the state.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other counties have been reorganized and some still retain county councils.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts contributed to American arts and culture.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Inspired by its Amerindian and Yankee roots and later immigrant groups, Massachusetts produced several writers, artists and musicians.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Some major museums and historic sites are also located there, and events and festivals throughout the year celebrate the history and heritage of the State.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts was an early centre of the transcendentalist movement, which emphasized intuition, emotion, human individuality, and a deeper connection with nature.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Ralph Waldo Emerson, who was born in Boston but spent much of his later life in Concord, largely created philosophy with his work of 1836 Nature, and continued to be a key figure in the movement for the rest of his life.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Emerson's friend, Henry David Thoreau, who was also involved in transcendentalism, recorded his last year alone in a small cabin in Walden Pond, in Walden, in 1854, or Life in the Woods.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Nathaniel Hawthorne, Louisa May Alcott, John Updike, Emily Dickinson, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, E.E. are other famous authors and poets born or closely associated with Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Cummings, Sylvia Plath, H. P.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Lovecraft, Edgar Allan Poe, and Theodor Seuss Geisel, better known as "Dr. Seuss".

name: massachusetts
sentence: Famous Massachusetts painters include Winslow Homer and Norman Rockwell

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts is also an important centre for the performing arts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Both the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Boston Pops Orchestra are based in Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other Massachusetts orchestras include Barnstable's Cape Cod Symphony Orchestra, the New Bedford Symphony Orchestra, and the Springfield Symphony Orchestra.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Tanglewood, in western Massachusetts, is a music venue that hosts both the Tanglewood Music Festival and the Tanglewood Jazz Festival, as well as the summer host of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Other performing and performing arts organizations in Massachusetts include the Boston Ballet, Boston Lyric Opera and Shakespeare & Company, based in Lenox.

name: massachusetts
sentence: In addition to classical and folk music, Massachusetts has produced musicians and bands covering a number of contemporary genres, such as classical rock band Aerosmith, proto-punk band The Modern Lovers, new wave band The Cars and alternative rock band Pixies.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The state has also been the birthplace of the Nu Metal and Heavy Metal Staind and Godsmack groups since they were formed in Springfield and Lawrence in 1995.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Cinematographic events in the state include the Boston Film Festival, the Boston International Film Festival, and a number of small film festivals in various cities of Massachusetts.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Massachusetts is home to many museums and historical sites.

name: massachusetts
sentence: The Boston Museum of Fine Arts, the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art and the DeCordova Museum of Contemporary Art and Sculpture in Lincoln are all located in Massachusetts, and the Maria Mitchell association in Nantucket includes several observatories, museums and an aquarium.

name: massachusetts
sentence: Themed museums and historic sites such as Springfield Armory National Historic Site in Springfield, the Boston Freedom Trail and the nearby Minute Man National Historic Park, which preserve a number of important sites during the American Revolution, Lowell National Historic Park, which focuses on some of the early mills and canals of the industrial revolution in the United States, the Boston Black Heritage Trail, which includes important Afro-American and abolitionist sites in Boston, and New Bedford Whaling National Historic Park highlight various periods of Massachusetts history.

name: massachusetts

sentence: Since 1992, it has supported the Democrats by moderate margins, with the exception of a narrow victory by Donald Trump in 2016.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan was the home of Gerald Ford, the 38th president of the United States.

name: michigan
sentence: Born in Nebraska, he moved to Grand Rapids as a child.

name: michigan
sentence: The Gerald R. Ford Museum is located in Grand Rapids, and the Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is located on the campus of its alma mater, the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor.

name: michigan
sentence: In 1846, Michigan became the first state of the Union, as well as the first government in the world to abolish the death penalty.

name: michigan
sentence: Historian David Chardavoyne suggested that the movement to abolish capital punishment in Michigan was born out of hostility towards Canada, making public executions a regular practice under British rule.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has approved plans to extend Medicaid coverage in 2014 to adults with incomes up to 133% of the federal level of poverty (approximately $15,500 for a single adult in 2014).

name: michigan
sentence: In 2018, the state electorate adopted proposals to create an independent Restriction Commission and to legalize the recreational use of marijuana.

name: michigan
sentence: In 2020, voters approved two voting measures, one to increase the limit on sales of gas and oil from state-owned land that could benefit public parks, and the other to require a search or seizure warrant for electronic data and communications.

name: michigan
sentence: The Government of the State is decentralized between three levels, at the state, county and canton levels.

name: michigan
sentence: The counties are administrative divisions of the state and the cantons are administrative divisions of a county.

name: michigan
sentence: Both exercise the authority of the government of the State, located to meet the special needs of their jurisdictions, as provided for by the law of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: There's 83 counties in Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: Cities, state universities and villages have original government powers to varying degrees.

name: michigan
sentence: Cities of origin can generally do anything that is not prohibited by law.

name: michigan
sentence: The fifteen state universities have broad powers and can do anything within the parameters of their status as educational institutions which is not prohibited by the constitution of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: Villages, on the other hand, have a limited membership rule and are not entirely autonomous of the county and canton in which they are located.

name: michigan
sentence: There are two types of townships in Michigan: the township of general law and the charter.

name: michigan
sentence: The charter cantonal status was created by the Legislature in 1947 and grants additional powers and continuous administration in order to ensure better protection against annexation by a city.

name: michigan
sentence: In April 2001, there were 127 charter townships in Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: In general, the charter cantons have many of the same powers as a city but without the same level of obligations.

name: michigan
sentence: For example, a charter canton may have its own fire department, water and sewer service, police service, etc., as well as a city, but it is not required to have these things, while cities must provide these services.

name: michigan
sentence: Charter Townships may choose to use county-wide services, such as the deputies of the county sheriff's office instead of a home-based prescription force.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan consists of two peninsulas separated by the Strait of Mackinac.

name: michigan
sentence: The 45th parallel north crosses the state, marked by road signs and the Polar-Equator trail, along a line comprising Mission Point Light near Traverse City, the towns of Gaylord and Alpena in the Lower Peninsula and Menominee in the Upper Peninsula.

name: michigan
sentence: With the exception of two small areas drained by the Mississippi River by the Wisconsin River on the upper peninsula and by the Kankakee-Illinois River on the lower peninsula, Michigan is drained by the Great Lakes and St. Lawrence watershed and is the only state with the majority of the lands drained.

name: michigan
sentence: No point in the state is more than six miles (9.7 km) from a natural water source or more than 85 miles (137 km) from a shore of the Great Lakes.

name: michigan
sentence: The Great Lakes bordering Michigan from east to west are Lakes Erie, Huron, Michigan and Superior.

name: michigan
sentence: The state is restricted to the south by the states of Ohio and Indiana, sharing the boundaries of land and water with both.

name: michigan
sentence: The western limits of Michigan are almost entirely bounded, from south to north, with Illinois and Wisconsin in Lake Michigan; then a terrestrial boundary with Wisconsin and the upper peninsula, which is primarily bounded by the Menominee and Montreal rivers; then water boundaries again, in Lake Superior, with Wisconsin and Minnesota to the west, captured by the Canadian province of Ontario to the north and east.

name: michigan
sentence: The high heavily wooded peninsula is relatively mountainous in the west.

name: michigan
sentence: Porcupine Mountains, which are part of one of the oldest mountain ranges in the world, reach an altitude of nearly 2,000 feet (610 m) above sea level and form the watershed between streams flowing into Lake Superior and Lake Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: The surface on each side of this range is robust.

name: michigan
sentence: The highest point in the state, in the Huron Mountains northwest of Marquette, is Mount Arvon at 603 metres.

name: michigan
sentence: The peninsula is as large as Connecticut, Delaware, Massachusetts and Rhode Island combined, but has fewer than 330,000 inhabitants.

name: michigan
sentence: It is 446 km long from north to south and 314 km from east to west and occupies almost two thirds of the area of the state.

sentence: The geography of the Thumb is mostly flat with a few hilly hills.

sentence: Other Michigan Peninsulas include the Keweenaw Peninsula, which is the state copper country region.

name: michigan

name: michigan

name: michigan
sentence: The Grand and Little Traverse, Thunder and Saginaw bays pass through the Lower Peninsula.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has the second longest shore of any state, 3288 miles (5,292 km), of which 1,056 miles (1,699 km) are island shorelines.

name: michigan
sentence: There are many large islands in the state, the main of which are North Manitou and South Manitou, Beaver and Fox in Lake Michigan; Isle Royale and Grande Isle in Lake Superior; Marquette, Bois Blanc and Mackinac in Lake Huron; and Neebish, Sugar and Drummond in the St. Mary's River.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has approximately 150 lighthouses, the largest of all U.S. states.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan's first lighthouses were constructed between 1818 and 1822.

name: michigan
sentence: They were built to project light at night and serve as a point of reference during the day to safely guide passenger ships and cargo ships travelling in the Great Lakes.

name: michigan
sentence: See the headlights in the United States.

name: michigan
sentence: State rivers are usually small, short and shallow, and few are navigable.

name: michigan
sentence: The main rivers are the Detroit River, the St. Marys River and the St. Clair River, which connect the Great Lakes; the Au Sable River, Cheboygan and Saginaw, which flow through Lake Huron; the Ontonagon and Tahquamenon River, which flow through Lake Superior; and the Saint Joseph, Kalamazoo, Grand, Muskegon, Manistee and Escanaba River, which flow through Lake Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: There are 11,037 inland lakes in the state, a total of 1,305 square miles (3,380 km2) of inland water, in addition to 38,575 square miles (99,910 km2) of Great Lakes water.

name: michigan
sentence: No points in Michigan are located more than six miles (9.7 km) from an indoor lake or more than 85 miles (137 km) from one of the Great Lakes.

name: michigan
sentence: The state is home to several areas maintained by the National Parks Service, including Royal Island National Park, Lake Superior, approximately 48 km southeast of Thunder Bay, Ontario.

name: michigan
sentence: Other national protected areas include Keweenaw National Historic Park, illustrated Rocks National Side Lake, sleeping Dunes Bear National Lake, Huron National Forest, Manist National Forest, Hiawatha National Forest, Ottawa National Forest, and Father Marquette National Memorial.

name: michigan
sentence: The largest section of the Northern National Scenography Trail passes through Michigan.

name: michigan
sentence: With 78 state parks, 19 state recreation areas and six state forests, Michigan has the largest state park and state forest network in any state.

name: michigan
sentence: These parks and forests include Holland State Park, Mackinac Island State Park, Sable State Forest and Mackinaw State Forest.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan has a continental climate, although there are two distinct areas.

name: michigan
sentence: The southern and central parts of the Lower Peninsula (south of Saginaw Bay and the Grand Rapids area southward) have a warmer climate (Köppen Dfa climate classification) with warm summers and cold winters.

name: michigan
sentence: The northern part of the Lower Peninsula and the entire Upper Peninsula have a more severe climate (Köppen Dfb), with warm summers, but shorter and longer, cold to very cold winters.

name: michigan
sentence: Some of the average state temperatures are below freezing from December to February, and until early March in distant northern areas.

name: michigan
sentence: During the winter until mid-February, the state is often subjected to heavy lake-effect snowfalls.

name: michigan
sentence: The average condition ranges from 30 to 40 inches (76 to 102 cm) of precipitation per year; however, some areas of the lower north and upper peninsula have an average of almost 160 inches (4,100 mm) of snowfall per year.

name: michigan
sentence: The highest recorded temperature in Michigan was 112°F (44°C) at Mio on July 13, 1936, and the coldest recorded temperature was −51°F (−46°C) at Vanderbilt on February 9, 1934.

name: michigan
sentence: The government has an average of 30 days of stormy activity per year.

name: michigan
sentence: These can be severe, especially in the southern part of the State.

name: michigan
sentence: The state has an average of 17 tornadoes per year, which are more frequent in the extreme south of the state.

name: michigan
sentence: Portions of the southern border have been almost as vulnerable historically as states to the west and in the Tornado aisle.

name: michigan
sentence: For this reason, many communities in the very southern regions of the State have tornado sirens to warn the inhabitants of the tornado approach.

name: michigan
sentence: Further north, in central Michigan, northern Michigan, and the upper peninsula, tornadoes are rare.

name: michigan
sentence: The geological formation of the state is very varied, with the Michigan Basin being the most important formation.

name: michigan
sentence: Primary blocks are found throughout the upper peninsula (mainly of primitive origin), while secondary deposits cover the entire lower peninsula.

name: michigan
sentence: The upper peninsula has lower Silurian sandstones, limestone, copper, and iron-bearing rocks, corresponding to Canada's Huron system.

name: michigan
sentence: The central part of the Lower Peninsula contains measurements of coal and rocks from the Pennsylvanian period.

name: michigan
sentence: Devonian and sub-Carboniferous deposits are dispersed throughout the state.

name: michigan
sentence: Michigan rarely experiences earthquakes, so far mostly smaller earthquakes that do not cause significant damage.

name: michigan
sentence: A 4.6-magnitude earthquake struck in August 1947.

name: michigan
sentence: More recently, an earthquake of 4.2 magnitude occurred on Saturday, May 2, 2015, shortly after noon, approximately five miles south of Galesburg, Michigan (9 miles southeast of Kalamazoo) in central Michigan, approximately 140 miles west of Detroit, according to the National Earthquake Information Centre of the Colorado-based US Geological Survey.

name: michigan
sentence: According to Governor Rick Snyder's office, no major damage or injury has been reported.

name: michigan
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that Michigan's population was 9,986,857 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 1.04 per cent from the total population of 9,883,635 registered at the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: michigan
sentence: This includes a natural increase since the last census of 177,254 people (i.e. 1,043,213 births minus 865,959 deaths) and a decrease due to net migration of 73,053 people.

name: michigan
sentence: Immigration resulted in a net increase of 193,031 people, and migration within the United States resulted in a net decrease of 266,084 people.

sentence: The Roman Catholic Church has six dioceses and one archdiocese in Michigan, Gaylord, Grand Rapids, Kalamazoo, Lansing, Marquette, Saginaw and Detroit.

sentence: Michigan's personal income tax is a flat rate of 4.25%.

name: michigan

sentence: The name Montana comes from the Spanish word montaña, which in turn comes from the Latin word montanea, meaning "mountain" or more widely "mountainous country".

sentence: The name Montana was added in 1863 to a bill of the United States House Committee on Territories (then chaired by James Ashley of Ohio) for the territory that would become Idaho's territory.

sentence: The name was changed by representatives Henry Wilson (Massachusetts) and Benjamin F. Harding (Oregon), who complained Montana had "no meaning".

sentence: When Ashley introduced a bill to establish a temporary government in 1864 for a new territory to be dug into Idaho, he again chose the territory of Montana.

name: nevada
sentence: Under the Constitution of the State of Nevada, the powers of the Government of Nevada are divided into three separate departments: the executive composed of the Governor of Nevada and their cabinet, as well as the other elected members of the Constitution; the legislature consisting of the Nevada Legislative Assembly, which includes the Assembly and the Senate; and the judiciary composed of the Nevada Supreme Court and the lower courts.

sentence: The current governor is Steve Sisolak, a democrat.

name: nevada
sentence: The Legislature of Nevada is a bicameral body divided into an assembly and a senator.

name: nevada
sentence: Members of the Assembly serve for two years, and members of the Senator for four years.

name: nevada
sentence: The two Houses of the Nevada Legislative Assembly will be affected by the terms of office from 2010, since senators and MPs/women will be limited to a maximum of 12 years in each chamber (by appointment or election that is a lifetime limit) – a provision of the Constitution that has recently been confirmed by the Nevada Supreme Court in a unanimous decision.

sentence: Nevada's tax laws are designed to attract new residents and businesses to the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state in the northeastern part of the United States in the New England region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bordered by Massachusetts to the south, Vermont to the west, Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east and the Canadian province of Quebec to the north.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the 5th smallest by region and the 10th least populated US state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Concord is the capital of the state, while Manchester is the biggest city.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has no general sales tax or income tax other than on interest and dividends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire primary is the first primary in the U.S. presidential election cycle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its license plates bear the motto of the state, "Live Free or Die".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state nickname, "The Granite State", refers to its extensive granite formations and quarries.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In January 1776 it became the first colony in British North America to establish a government independent of the authority of the Kingdom of Great Britain; it was the first to establish its own state constitution.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Six months later, it became one of the first 13 colonies that signed the United States Declaration of Independence and, in June 1788, it was the ninth state to ratify the United States Constitution, bringing it into force.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, New Hampshire has been a major centre for textile, footwear and paper manufacturing, with Amoskeag Manufacturing Company in Manchester at one point being the largest textile cotton factory in the world.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many mills were located along various rivers in the state, especially the Merrimack and Connecticut rivers.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Many French Canadians migrated to New Hampshire to work the mills in the late 19th and early 20th centuries; New Hampshire still ranks second among the states by the percentage of people claiming French American ancestry, with 24.5% of the state identifying itself as such.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Manufacturing centres such as Manchester, Nashua and Berlin were hit hard in the 1930s-1940s as the major manufacturing industries left New England and settled in the southern United States or abroad, reflecting national trends.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 1950s and 1960s, defence contractors moved into many former mills, such as Sanders Associates in Nashua; the population of southern New Hampshire increased from the 1980s as major highways connecting the area to Greater Boston and established several sleeping communities in the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With some of the highest ski mountains on the East Coast, New Hampshire's major recreational attractions include skiing, snowmobiles and other winter sports, hiking and mountaineering (Monadnock Mountain in the southwest corner of the state is one of the most climbing mountains in the United States), autumn foliage observation, summer cottages along many lakes and the sea coast, motorsports at the New Hampshire Motor Speedway, and Moto Week, a popular motorcycle rally that took place at Weirs Beach in Laconia in June.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountain National Forest connects the Vermont and Maine portions of the Appalachian Trail and has the automatic Mount Washington Road, where visitors can drive to the top of Mount Washington, 1,917 metres long.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State was named after the South English county of Hampshire by Captain John Mason.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is part of the six-state New England region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is bounded by Quebec, Canada, north and northwest; Maine and the Atlantic Ocean to the east; Massachusetts to the south; and Vermont to the west.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main areas of New Hampshire are the Northern Great Woods, the White Mountains, the Lakes Region, the Seacoast, the Merrimack Valley, the Monadnock Region, and the Dartmouth-Lake Sunapee Region.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the shortest ocean coast of an American coastal state, 29 km long, sometimes only 33 km long.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains range in New Hampshire covers the north-central part of the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The range includes Mount Washington, the highest in the northeastern United States, the site of the second highest wind speed ever recorded, and Mount Adams and Mount Jefferson.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: With strong winds of hurricanes every three days on average, more than a hundred deaths recorded among visitors, and visible krumholtz (dwarfs, matt trees like a bonsai carpet), the climate on the upper part of Mount Washington inspired the meteorological observatory on the summit to pretend that the area has the "World's Pire Weather".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The White Mountains house the rock formation known as the Old Man of the Mountain, a profile similar to Franconia Notch, until the disintegration of the formation in May 2003.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Even after its loss, the old man remains a lasting symbol for the state, seen on state highway signs, car license plates, and many government and private entities around New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the southwestern corner of New Hampshire, Mount Monadnock gave its name to a class of earth forms — a monadnock — meaning, in geomorphology, any resistant isolated peak that rises from a less resistant eroded plain.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The main rivers include the Merrimack River (177 km), which crosses the lower half of the north-south state before crossing into Massachusetts and reaching the sea at Newburyport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its tributaries are the Contoocook River, the Pemigewasset River, and the Winnipesaukee River.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 660 km-long Connecticut River from Connecticut Lakes in New Hampshire flows south to Connecticut defines the western boundary with Vermont.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state border is not at the centre of this river, as is generally the case, but at the low line on the Vermont side; that is, the entire river along the Vermont border (reserving areas where water levels have been raised by dam) is located in New Hampshire.

sentence: Connecticut's "northwestern upstream waters" also define the part of Canada-U.S.

sentence: About 11 km offshore are the islands of Shoals, nine small islands (including four in New Hampshire) known as the site of a 19th-century art colony founded by poet Celia Thaxter, and the presumed location of one of the buried treasures of the pirate Black Barbe.

sentence: It is the state with the highest percentage of wooded land in the country.

sentence: New Hampshire occurs in the biome of mixed and broad-leaved temperate forests.

sentence: Much of the state, especially the White Mountains, is covered by conifers and northern deciduous forests of New England and Acadia.

sentence: The duration of the winter season is expected to decrease in the New Hampshire ski resorts due to the effects of global warming, which is expected to continue the historical contraction and consolidation of the ski industry and threaten ski companies and communities dependent on ski tourism.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a humid continental climate (classification of the climate of Köppen Dfa in certain areas of the south, Dfb in most states and subarctic Dfc in some areas of the north of the highlands), with warm and humid summers and long, cold and snowy winters.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Precipitation is distributed fairly evenly throughout the year.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The climate in the southeast is moderated by the Atlantic Ocean and the average winters are relatively milder (for New Hampshire), while the northern and inner parts have colder temperatures and lower humidity.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Winters are cold and snowy throughout the state, and particularly severe in the north and mountainous areas.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual snowfall ranges from 60 inches (150 cm) to over 100 inches (250 cm) across the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The average diurnal peaks were between the mid-1970s and the lower 1980s (24–28 °C) in the state as a whole in July, with the lows of the night between the mid-50s and the lower 1960s (13–15 °C).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: January temperatures range from an average height of 34°F (1°C) on the coast to minimum night temperatures below 0°F (−18°C) in the extreme north and at high altitudes.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Average annual precipitation at the state level is about 40 inches (100 cm) and some variations occur in the White Mountains due to differences in altitude and annual snowfall.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The highest temperature recorded in New Hampshire was 106°F (41°C) at Nashua on July 4, 1911, while the lowest recorded temperature was −47°F (−44°C) at the top of Mount Washington on January 29, 1934.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Mount Washington also saw an unofficial reading of -50°F (−46°C) on January 22, 1885, which, if officially made, would link New England's record record (also -50°F (−46°C) to Big Black River, Maine, on January 16, 2009, and Bloomfield, Vermont, on December 30, 1933).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Extreme snow is often associated with a nor'easter, such as the 78's Blizzard and the 1993 Blizzard, when several feet accumulate on portions of the state for 24 to 48 hours.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Lighter snowfalls of several inches occur frequently throughout the winter, often associated with an Alberta brush.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Occasionally, New Hampshire is affected by hurricanes and tropical storms, although when they reach the state, they are often extratropical, with most storms on the southern coast of New England moving inside or offshore in the Gulf of Maine.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has an average of less than 20 storm days per year and two tornadoes occur each year across the state.

sentence: The population centre of New Hampshire is located in Merrimack County, Pembroke City.
