sentence: The population centre has moved south of 19 km since 1950, reflecting the fact that the fastest growth of the state has been along its southern border, which is within the Boston and other cities of Massachusetts.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The most densely populated areas are generally less than 80 km from the Massachusetts border and are concentrated in two areas: along the Merrimack valley from Concord to Nashua, and in the sea area along an axis from Rochester to Portsmouth.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Outside these two regions, there is only one community, the city of Keene, with more than 20,000 inhabitants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The four counties covering these two regions represent 72 per cent of the population of the state, and one (Hillsborough) represents nearly 30 per cent of the population of the state, as well as the two most populated communities, Manchester and Nashua.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The northern part of the state is very sparsely populated: the largest county per region, Coos, covers the northern quarter of the state and has only about 31,000 people, about one third of whom live in a single community (Berlin).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Trends over the past few decades have been for the population to move south, as many northern communities do not have the economic base to maintain their populations, while southern communities have been absorbed by Greater Boston.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of the 2010 census, the population of New Hampshire was 1,316,470.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The gender composition of the State was 49.3 per cent male and 50.7 per cent female.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: 21.8% of the population were under the age of 18

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The racial composition of New Hampshire at the time of the 2010 Census was as follows:

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Hispanics or Latinos of all races accounted for 2.8 per cent of the population in 2010: 0.6 per cent were Mexican, 0.9 per cent Puerto Rican, 0.1 per cent Cuban and 1.2 per cent other Hispanic and Latin origins.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the American Community Survey 2012–2017, the main groups of ancestry in the State were Irish (20.6%), English (16.5%), French (14.0%), Italian (10.4%), German (9.1%), French Canadians (8.9%) and Americans (4.8%).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has the highest percentage (22.9%) of French, French-Canadian and Acadian residents in any U.S. state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to estimates from the American Community Survey of the Census Bureau from 2017, 2.1% of the population aged 5 and over speak Spanish at home, while 1.8% speak French.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In Coos County, 9.6% of the population speaks French at home, up from 16% in 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Note: The percentages in the table do not add up to 100, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, resulting in a higher overall number.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A Pew survey found that the religious affiliations of New Hampshire residents were as follows: Protestants 30%, Catholics 26%, LDS (Mormon) 1%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2% and non-religious 36%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A survey suggests that people in New Hampshire and Vermont are less likely than other Americans to attend weekly services and only 54% say they are "absolutely certain that there is a God" compared to 71% in the rest of the nation.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire and Vermont are also at the lowest levels among states in religious engagement.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, 23% of New Hampshire residents in a Gallup poll considered themselves to be "very religious", while 52% considered themselves "non-religious".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Association of Religion Data Archives (ARDA), the largest denominations are the Catholic Church with 311.028 members; the United Church of Christ with 26,321 members; and the Methodist Church united with 18,029 members.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016, a Gallup Poll found New Hampshire to be the least religious in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Only 20% of New Hampshire respondents rated themselves as "very religious", while the national average was 40%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Bureau of Economic Analysis estimates that New Hampshire's total revenue in 2018 was $86 billion, ranking 40th in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The median household income for 2017 was $74,801, the fourth highest in the country (including Washington, DC).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its agricultural products include dairy products, nurseries, cattle, apples and eggs.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Its industrial products are machines, electrical equipment, rubber and plastic products, and tourism is a major component of the economy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire underwent a major change in its economic base during the 20th century.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Historically, the base was made up of New England's traditional textiles, footwear manufacturing, and small machine shops, taking advantage of low-wage labour from nearby small farms and regions of Quebec.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Today, out of the total value of the state's manufacturing dollar, these sectors contribute only two per cent for textiles, two per cent for leather goods and nine per cent for machining.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They have experienced a sharp decline due to obsolete plants and the attractiveness of cheaper wages in the southern United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire now has an enlarged and growing economy, with a government GDP growth rate of 2.2% in 2018.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The government's main economic sectors in 2018, based on its contribution to GDP, are: 15% of real estate and leasing; 13% of professional business services; 12% of manufacturing; 10% of government and government services; and 9% of health and social services.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The state budget for the 2018 fiscal year was $5.97 billion, including $1.79 billion in federal funds.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The question of taxation is controversial in New Hampshire, which has a property tax (under municipal control) but no sales tax or income tax.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has tighter taxes on meals, housing, vehicles, business income and investment, and tolls on State roads.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Energy Information Administration, New Hampshire's energy consumption and per capita energy consumption are among the lowest in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Seabrook Nuclear Generating Station, near Portsmouth, is the largest nuclear reactor in New England and provides 57% of New Hampshire's electricity generation and 27% of its electricity consumption in 2017.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2016 and 2017, New Hampshire received more wind power than coal-fired power plants.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Approximately 32% of New Hampshire's electricity consumption came from renewable resources (including nuclear, hydro, wind and other renewable resources).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire was a net exporter of electricity, exporting 63 trillion from British thermal units (18 TWh).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's residential electricity consumption is low compared to the national average, partly because demand for air conditioning is low in the generally mild summer months and because few households use electricity as a primary source of energy for domestic heating.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Nearly half of New Hampshire's households use fuel oil for winter heating, which is one of the largest shares in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has potential for renewable energy such as wind, hydro and wood.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The State has no general sales tax or personal income tax (the State taxes, at a rate of 5%, income from dividends and interest), and the legislator has exercised tax restrictions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Efforts to diversify the general economy of the State are continuing.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The absence of a general tax system in New Hampshire has resulted in the state's local governments having some of the highest property taxes in the country.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the overall tax burden of the State is relatively low; in 2010, New Hampshire ranked 44th among the states for the combined average tax burden of states and local authorities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 2010, the state unemployment rate was 7.1%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In October 2010, the unemployment rate fell to 5.4%.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The seasonal (preliminary) unemployment rate in April 2019 was 2.4% based on a civilian workforce of 767,500 people, with 749,000 people in employment.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire's workforce is 90 per cent in non-agricultural employment, 18 per cent in trade, transport and public services, 17 per cent in education and health care, 12 per cent in government, 11 per cent in professional and commercial services and 10 per cent in recreation and hospitality.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to a 2013 study by Phoenix Marketing International, New Hampshire had the eighth highest percentage of millionaire households in the United States, or 6.48 per cent of all households.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2013, New Hampshire also had the lowest poverty rate in the country, at only 8.7 per cent of all residents, according to the Census Bureau.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In March 2018, 86% of New Hampshire's workers were employed by the private sector, with 53% employed by companies with less than 100 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: About 14% of private sector employees are employed by companies with more than 1,000 employees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: According to the Community surveys of the Labour Market Information Office and the NH Employment Security Economy, the most important private employers in the State are:

sentence: The State Government of New Hampshire employs approximately 6,100 people.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the United States Department of State employs approximately 1,600 people at the Portsmouth National Visa Centre, which processes applications for immigration visas from the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The governor of New Hampshire, since January 5, 2017, is Chris Sununu (Republican).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two American senators from New Hampshire are Jeanne Shaheen and Maggie Hassan (the two Democrats), both former governors.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The two U.S. representatives of New Hampshire in January 2019 are Chris Pappas and Ann McLane Kuster (the two Democrats).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a state of control over alcoholic beverages and, through the State Alcohol Commission, takes $100 million from the sale and distribution of alcoholic beverages.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is the only state in the United States that does not require adults to wear seat belts in their vehicle.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It is one of the three States that do not have a mandatory helmet law.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New Hampshire of 1783 is the supreme law of the State, followed by the revised Annotated New Hampshire Statutes and the New Hampshire Code of Administrative Rules.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: They are roughly similar to those in the U.S. Federal Constitution, the U.S. Code and the Code of Federal Regulations, respectively.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a bifurcated executive power, consisting of the governor and a five-member executive council that votes on government contracts worth more than $5,000 and "advises and consents" to the governor's appointments to important state posts such as department heads, all judicial functions and all requests for pardons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire does not have a Lieutenant Governor; the Speaker acts as an "interim Governor" whenever the Governor is unable to perform his or her duties.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The legislator is called the Tribunal.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It consists of the House of Representatives and the senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There are 400 representatives, making them one of the largest elected bodies in the English-speaking world and 24 senators.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Legislators receive a nominal salary of $200 per year, the lowest salary in the United States by far, so most are indeed volunteers, nearly half of whom are retirees.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: (For details, see the article on the Government of New Hampshire.)

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The only State Court of Appeal is the Supreme Court of New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Superior Court is the court of general jurisdiction and the only court which provides for jury trials in civil or criminal cases.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Other State courts are the Probation Court, the District Court and the Family Division.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has 10 counties and 234 cities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is a "Dillon Rule" state, meaning that the state retains all powers that are not expressly granted to municipalities.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Despite this, the legislator is strongly in favour of local control, in particular with regard to the regulation of land use.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The municipalities of New Hampshire are classified as cities, which differ mainly in form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Most cities usually operate according to the form of government of municipal assemblies, where registered voters in the city act as municipal legislators, and a selection board acts as the city's executive.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The major cities and the thirteen cities of the State operate either in the form of a council, in the form of a council, in the form of a council or in the form of a mayor.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is no difference, from the point of view of state government, between cities and cities outside the form of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All state laws treat all municipalities in the same way.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire has a small number of unincorporated areas known as grants, locations, purchases or cantons.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: These sites are limited to the absence of self-government, and services are generally provided by neighbouring cities or by the county or state, if applicable.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of the 2000 census, there were 25 remaining in New Hampshire, with a total population of 173 (in 2000); several of them were completely depopulated.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: All but two of these areas are in Coos County.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democratic Party and the Republican Party are the two largest parties in the State.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: A plurality of electors are registered as undeclared, and can choose one or the other vote in the primary, and then regain their undeclared status after the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party had official party status from 1990 to 1996.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: There is also a program known as the Free State project to transform New Hampshire into a libertarian bastion by suggesting that libertarians move there to concentrate their power.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Libertarian Party regained access to the ballot papers after the 2016 election because the candidate for governor's office won more than four percent of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As of February 5, 2016, there were 882,959 registered voters, of whom 389,472 (44.1%) had not declared affiliation to a political party, 262,111 (29.7%) were Republicans and 231,376 (26.2%) were Democrats.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire is known internationally for the primary school of New Hampshire, the first primary of the quadrennial cycle of the US presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The law of the State requires the Secretary of State to hold this election at least one week before any "similar event".

name: new_hampshire
sentence: However, the Iowa caucus preceded the New Hampshire primary.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: This first competition, which uses the same procedure as the general election, attracts more attention than in other states, and it has been decisive in shaping the national competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: State law allows a city with fewer than 100 inhabitants to open its polling stations at midnight and close its offices when all registered citizens have voted.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: As such, the communities of Dixville Notch, Coos County, and Hart, Carroll County, among others, have chosen to implement these provisions.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Dixville Notch and Hart's Location have traditionally been the first places in New Hampshire and the United States to vote in primary and presidential elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Appointments for all other partisan offices are made in separate primary elections.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential election cycles, this is the second primary election in New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Saint Anselm College in Goffstown has become a popular campaign venue for politicians as well as several national presidential debates due to its proximity to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the past, New Hampshire often voted Republican.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Between 1856 and 1988, New Hampshire voted six times for the democratic presidential post: Woodrow Wilson (twice), Franklin D. Roosevelt (three times) and Lyndon B. Johnson (one time).

name: new_hampshire
sentence: From 1992 onwards, New Hampshire became a state rotating in national and local elections and, at that time, supported the Democrats in all presidential elections, with the exception of 2000.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: It was the only state in the country to move from the support of Republican George W. Bush in the 2000 election to that of his democratic opponent in the 2004 election, when John Kerry, a senator from neighbouring Massachusetts, won the state.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats dominated the New Hampshire elections in 2006 and 2008.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2006, the Democrats won both seats in the Congress (elected Carol Shea-Porter in the first district and Paul Hodes in the second), re-elected Governor John Lynch and won a majority on the Executive Council and in both chambers for the first time since 1911.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The democrats have not held both parliament and governorship since 1874.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Neither of the American senators voted in 2006.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2008, the Democrats retained their majorities, their government and their seats in Congress; and former Governor Jeanne Shaheen beat outgoing Republican John E. Sununu for the U.S. senator in a retake of the 2002 competition.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2008 elections allowed women to hold a majority, 13 of the 24 seats, in New Hampshire Senatte, the first for any legislative body in the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the mid-term elections of 2010, the Republicans made historical gains in New Hampshire, capturing veto-proof majorities in the state's legislature, taking the five seats on the Executive Council, electing a new American senator, Kelly Ayotte, winning the two seats in the US Chamber and reducing the margin of victory of outgoing Governor John Lynch over his 2006 and 2008 victories.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2012 parliamentary elections, the Democrats took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire and reduced the Republican majority of New Hampshire senators to 13-11.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In 2012, New Hampshire became the first state in the history of the United States to elect a federal women's delegation: Carol Shea-Porter, Democratic MP for Congressional District 1, and Ann McLane Kuster, MP for Congressional District 2, accompanied the United States.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Kelly Ayotte in 2013.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In addition, the State elected its second female governor: the Democrat Maggie Hassan.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2014 elections, the Republicans took over the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 239–160 and increased their majority in the Senate of New Hampshire to 14 of the 24 seats in the Senate.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: At the national level, outgoing Senator Jeanne Shaheen defeated her Republican opponent, former Massachusetts Senator Scott Brown.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire also elected Frank Guinta (R) for its First Congress district representative and Ann Kuster (D) for its Second Congress district representative.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the 2016 election, the Republicans held the House of Representatives of New Hampshire with a majority of 220 to 175, and held 14 seats in New Hampshire Senator.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the gibernatory race, outgoing Governor Maggie Hassan was replaced by Republican Chris Sununu, who defeated Democratic candidate Colin Van Ostern.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: Sununu became the first republican governor of the state since Craig Benson, who left office in 2005 following the defeat of John Lynch.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Republicans control the governor's office and the two chambers of the state legislature, a government trifecta in which the Republicans have full power of government.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: In the presidential race, the state voted for the Democratic candidate, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on the Republican candidate, Donald Trump, by a margin of 2,736 votes, or 0.3%, one of the closest results the state has ever seen in a presidential race, while libertarian candidate Gary Johnson received 4.12% of the vote.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The Democrats have also won a competition race in the second district of Congress, as well as a competition race in the Senate.

sentence: The New Hampshire Congress delegation is currently composed exclusively of democrats.

sentence: At the 116th Congress of the United States, it is one of the only eight states with a fully democratic delegation, five of which are in New England (the others are Delaware, Hawaii and New Mexico).

sentence: Greyhound, Concord Coach, Vermont Translines and Dartmouth Coach all provide interurban connections to and from points in New Hampshire and to long-distance points beyond and between.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority is working to expand the "Corridor Capital" service from Lowell, Massachusetts to Nashua, Concord and Manchester, including the Manchester-Boston Regional Airport; and the "Corridor Coastal" service from Haverhill, Massachusetts to Plaistow, New Hampshire.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The 2007 Act created the New Hampshire Rail Transit Authority (NHRTA) to oversee the development of suburban trains in New Hampshire.

sentence: This rail corridor would also have access to Manchester-Boston Regional Airport.

sentence: Eleven public transit administrations operate local and regional bus services around the state, and eight private carriers operate express bus services that connect the national long distance bus network.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: The first public secondary schools in the State were the secondary school for boys and the secondary school for girls in Portsmouth, established in 1827 or 1830 according to the source.

sentence: New Hampshire also houses prestigious preparatory university schools such as Phillips Exeter Academy, St. Paul's School, Proctor Academy, Brewster Academy and Kimball Union Academy.

name: new_hampshire
sentence: New Hampshire personalities include founding father Nicholas Gilman, Senator Daniel Webster, revolutionary war hero John Stark, publisher Horace Greeley, founder of Christian science religion Mary Baker Eddy, poet Robert Frost, astronaut Alan Shepard, rock musician Ronnie James Dio, author Dan Brown, actor Adam Sandler, inventor Dean Kamen, actors Sarah Silverman and Seth Meyers, restorers Richard and Maurice McDonald, and President Franklin Pierce of the United States.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is a state in the Northeastern United States of America, located in the Middle Atlantic region.

name: new_jersey
sentence: It is bordered to the north and east by New York State, to the east, south-east and south by the Atlantic Ocean, to the west by the Delaware River and Pennsylvania, and to the southwest by Delaware Bay and Delaware State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the fourth smallest state by region, but the 11th most populous, with 8,882,190 inhabitants in 2019 and an area of 8,722.58 square miles, making it the most populous of the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The capital is Trenton, while the biggest city is Newark.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All but one of the counties in New Jersey are located in the combined statistical regions of New York City or Philadelphia; therefore, the largest metropolitan area in the state is in Greater New York.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was first inhabited by Amerindians for at least 2,800 years, the Lenape being the dominant group at the time of the arrival of Europeans at the beginning of the 17th century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Dutch and Swedish settlers founded the first European colonies of the state.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The British then took control of the area, naming it Province of New Jersey – after the largest of the Channel Islands, Jersey – and granting it as a colony to Sir George Carteret and John Berkeley, first Baron Berkeley of Stratton.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was the scene of several major battles during the American Revolution War.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the 19th century, factories in the six major cities of Camden, Paterson, Newark, Trenton, Jersey City and Elizabeth contributed to the industrial revolution of the nation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The central location of New Jersey in the northeastern megapolis fuelled its rapid growth and suburbanization in the second half of the twentieth century.

name: new_jersey
sentence: At the turn of the twenty-first century, the state economy is becoming increasingly diversified, while its multicultural population is beginning to return to more urban environments within the state, surpassing the growth of the suburbs since 2008.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2020, New Jersey had the largest number of millionaires per capita in all U.S. states, with 9.76% of households – more than 323,000 out of 3.3 million – meeting the criteria.

name: new_jersey
sentence: According to 2017 data, this was the second poorest state in the United States with median household income.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's public education system is consistently ranked among the 50 U.S. states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 180 million years ago, during the Jurassic period, New Jersey was bordering North Africa.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The pressure of the North American-Africa collision gave rise to the Appalachians.

name: new_jersey
sentence: About 18,000 years ago, the ice age gave rise to glaciers that reached New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: As the glaciers retreated, they left Lake Passaic behind, as well as numerous rivers, marshes and gorges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Originally, New Jersey was established by Amerindians, with Lenni-Lenape dominant at the time of contact.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Scheyichbi is the name of Lenape for the land which is now New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Lenapes were several self-governing groups engaged in corn farming to complete their hunting and harvesting in the area surrounding the Delaware River, the lower Hudson River, and the western Long Island Strait.

name: new_jersey

sentence: (The others are Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, and Virginia.)

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey holds elections for these offices every four years, within one year of each year of federal presidential election.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, last year, when New Jersey elected a governor was 2017; the next government election will take place in 2021.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Supreme Court of New Jersey consists of one Chief Justice and six Associate Judges.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All are appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the State Senate.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Judges have an initial term of seven years, after which they can be reappointed until the age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most of the daily work in New Jersey courts is done by the municipal court, where simple traffic violations, minor criminal offences, and small civil cases are heard.

name: new_jersey
sentence: More serious criminal and civil cases are handled by the Superior Court of each county.

name: new_jersey
sentence: All judges of the Superior Court are appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of a majority of the members of the Senate of the State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Each judge has an initial term of seven years, after which he or she may be reappointed until the age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey's judiciary is unusual in that it still has separate courts of law and fairness, such as its neighbour Delaware, but unlike most other American states.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court of New Jersey is divided into the Law and Chancery Divisions at the trial level; the Law Division hears both criminal and civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is damages, while the Chancery Division hears family cases, civil cases where the plaintiff's main remedy is a fair remedy and probation proceedings.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Superior Court also has an appellate division, which operates as an intermediate court of appeal of the State.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Judges of the Superior Court shall be assigned to the Appeals Division by the Chief Justice.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There is also a Tax Court, which has limited jurisdiction.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court are seized of appeals of tax decisions rendered by the County Tax Boards.

name: new_jersey
sentence: They also have before them appeals concerning decisions rendered by the Director of the Taxation Division on matters such as State income, sales taxes and business taxes and property refunds.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Appeals from decisions of the Tax Court are heard by the Appeals Chamber of the Superior Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The judges of the Tax Court are appointed by the Governor for initial terms of seven years and are reappointed until they reach the mandatory retirement age of 70.

name: new_jersey
sentence: There are 12 judges at the Tax Court.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is divided into 21 counties.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey was completely divided into counties in 1692.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey is the only state in the nation where the elected representatives of the county are called "Freeholders", which governs each county on its own board of directors of the elected Freeholders.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The number of free owners in each county is determined by referendum and must be composed of three, five, seven or nine members.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Depending on the county, executive and legislative functions may be exercised by the Council of Free Shareholders elected or divided into various branches of the administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 16 counties, members of the board of directors of the elected Freeholders perform legislative and executive functions on a commission basis, each freeholder being responsible for a department or group of departments.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In the other five counties (Atlantic, Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Mercer), there is a directly elected county executive who performs the executive functions while the board of directors of elected free shareholders retains a legislative and supervisory role.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In non-executive counties, a county administrator (or county director) may be hired for the day-to-day administration of county functions.

name: new_jersey
sentence: New Jersey currently has 565 municipalities; the number was 566 before the merger of Princeton Township and Princeton Borough to form the Municipality of Princeton on January 1, 2013.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Unlike other states, all New Jersey lands are part of a municipality.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In 2008, Governor Jon Corzine proposed to reduce state aid to all cities with less than 10,000 inhabitants in order to encourage mergers to reduce administrative costs.

name: new_jersey
sentence: In May 2009, the Commission for the Reorganization and Consolidation of Local Units undertook a study of some 40 small communities in southern Jersey to identify those that could be good candidates for consolidation.

name: new_jersey
sentence: From the twentieth century onwards, largely motivated by reform objectives, a series of six modern forms of government were implemented.

name: new_jersey
sentence: This began with the Walsh Act, promulgated in 1911 by the New Jersey Legislative, which provided for a three or five-member commission elected on a non-partisan basis.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The 1923 Municipal Manager Act, which offered a non-partisan council, provided for a weak mayor elected by and among council members, and introduced a government structure to manage municipal affairs with a manager appointed for day-to-day administration.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Faulkner Act, originally enacted in 1950 and substantially amended in 1981, provides for four basic plans: the mayor-counsel, the council-manager, the small municipality and the mayor-counsel-manager.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The Act offers many choices to communities that prefer strong executive and professional management of municipal affairs and provides great flexibility to allow municipalities to choose the characteristics of their government: the number of seats on the council; the seats chosen in general, by neighbourhoods or by a combination of the two; staggered or concurrent mandates; and a mayor chosen by the council or directly elected by voters.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Most major municipalities and the majority of New Jersey residents are governed by municipalities with Faulkner Charters Act.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Municipalities can also formulate their own form of government and operate under a special charter with the approval of the Legislative Assembly of New Jersey.

name: new_jersey
sentence: Although municipalities retain their names derived from the types of government, they may have changed for one of the modern forms of government, or even more so in the past for one of the other traditional forms, leading to municipalities whose official names are completely flouting for the general public.

name: new_jersey
sentence: For example, although there are four municipalities that are officially of the type of village, Loch Arbour is the only one left with the form of village government.

name: new_jersey
sentence: The other three villages (Ridgefield Park (now with a Walsh Act form), Ridgewood (now with a Faulkner Act Council-Manager charter) and South Orange (now under a special charter)) all migrated to other non-village forms.

name: new_mexico

sentence: There are also local governments, consisting of counties, municipalities and special districts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Present Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham (D) and Lieutenant Governor Howie Morales (D) were first elected in 2018.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The terms of office of the Governor and Lieutenant Governor expire in January 2023.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Governors are appointed for a four-year term and may apply for re-election for an additional term (limit of two terms).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Other constitutional officers, all of which also expire in January 2023, include Secretary of State Maggie Toulouse Oliver (D), Attorney General Hector Balderas (D), Auditor of State Brian Colón (D), Commissioner of State for Lands Stephanie Garcia Richard (D) and Treasurer of State Tim Eichenberg (D).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Currently, the two chambers of the Legislative Assembly of the State of New Mexico have democratic majorities.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There are 26 Democrats and 16 Republicans in the Senate and 47 Democrats and 23 Republicans in the House of Representatives.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The U.S. Senators from New Mexico are Democrats Martin Heinrich and Ben Ray Luján.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The three members of the United States House of Representatives are Deb Haaland, Yvette Herrell and Teresa Leger Fernandez, respectively, the first, second and third districts.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has traditionally been considered an oscillating State, whose population has favoured both democratic and republican presidential candidates, but it has become more of a democratic bastion since the 2008 presidential election.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Governor is Michelle Lujan Grisham (D), who succeeded Susana Martinez (R) on January 1, 2019 after serving two terms as Governor from 2011 to 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Gary Johnson served as governor from 1995 to 2003.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Johnson was a Republican, but in 2012 and 2016, he ran as president of the libertarian party.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In previous presidential elections, Al Gore carried the state (by 366 votes) in 2000; George W. Bush won New Mexico's five electoral votes in 2004, and the state's electoral votes were won by Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton in 2008, 2012 and 2016.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Since becoming a state in 1912, New Mexico has been taken by the winner of the national popular vote in every presidential election of the last 104 years, except in 1976, when Gerald Ford won the state of 2%, but lost the national popular vote of 2%.

name: new_mexico
sentence: He also granted his electoral votes to the candidate who would ultimately win, with the exception of 1976, 2000 and 2016.

name: new_mexico
sentence: State democrats are generally the strongest in the Santa Fe region, in various areas of the Albuquerque metropolitan area (such as the south-east and central regions, including the tributary neighbourhood of Nob Hill and the vicinity of the University of New Mexico), in northern and central-western New Mexico, and in most Indian reserves, particularly the Navajo Nation.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Republicans traditionally have their strongholds in the east and south of the state, in the Farmington area, in Rio Rancho and in the newly developed areas of the northwest mesa.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The north-eastern heights of Albuquerque have always looked at the Republicans, but they have become a key sector for the Democrats in recent electoral cycles.

name: new_mexico
sentence: While registered democrats are more numerous than Republicans registered by nearly 200,000, New Mexico's voters favored moderate to conservative candidates from both parties at the state and federal levels.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico abolished its death penalty law, but not retroactively, as of 1 July 2009.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This means that people on New Mexico death row can still be executed.

name: new_mexico
sentence: On March 18, 2009, Governor Bill Richardson signed the law abolishing the death penalty in New Mexico after the vote of the assembly and the Senate the previous week, becoming the 15th U.S. state to abolish the penalty.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With respect to firearms control, New Mexico may have some of the least restrictive firearms laws in the country.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The law of the State warns all local ordinances on the control of firearms.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico residents can purchase a firearm that is deemed legal under federal law.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is no waiting period under state law to pick up a firearm once it has been purchased, and there are no restrictions on the capacity of magazines.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition, New Mexico is a "responsible" state for hidden transport permits.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Before December 2013, New Mexico's law did not explicitly authorize or prohibit same-sex marriage.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The same-sex marriage permit policy has been determined at the county level; that is, some county clerks have issued same-sex marriage permits, while others have not.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In December 2013, the New Mexico Supreme Court issued a unanimous decision ordering all county clerks to issue marriage permits to same-sex couples, making New Mexico the 17th state to recognize same-sex marriage across the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to its relatively small population, combined with many federally funded research institutions, New Mexico had the highest concentration of doctoral students in any state in 2000.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In spite of this, the State regularly ranks close to the base in surveys on the quality of primary and secondary education.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In a landmark decision, a state judge ruled in 2018 that "New Mexico violates the constitutional rights of students at risk by not providing them with enough education," and ordered the Governor and the Legislative Assembly to provide an adequate system by April 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico has a greater concentration of people who do not complete high school or have a college without a degree than the nation as a whole.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For the State, 23.9% of people over the age of 25 went to university but did not graduate.

name: new_mexico
sentence: This proportion is compared to 21.0% of the country as a whole as estimated by the American Community Survey of the United States Census Bureau 2014.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Los Alamos County has the highest percentage of post-secondary graduates in any county in New Mexico, with 38.7% of the population (4,899 people) estimated by the American Community Survey 2010-2014.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Department of Public Education of New Mexico oversees the operation of primary and secondary schools

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is one of eight states that fund university scholarships through the state lottery.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The state of New Mexico requires that the lottery put 30% of its gross sales into the scholarship fund.The scholarship is available to residents who have graduated from a state high school and attend a full-time state university while maintaining a GPA of 2.5 or more.It covered 100% of tuition fees when first enrolled in 1996, decreased to 90%, and then dropped to 60% in 2017.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The value increased slightly in 2018 and a new law was passed to specify the funds available by type of institution.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With an Amerindian population of 134,000 in 1990, New Mexico occupies an important place in Amerindian culture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Navajo and Apache share the Athabaskane origin.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Apache and a few Ute live on federal reserves within the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: With 16 million acres (6,500,000 ha), mainly in neighbouring Arizona, the Navajo Nation reserve is the largest in the United States.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Pueblo Indians prehistorically farmed live in pueblos scattered throughout the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Nearly half of the new Mexicans claim hispanic origin

name: new_mexico
sentence: They settled in the northern part of the State.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Most Mexican immigrants reside in the south of the state.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Moreover, 10-15% of the population, mainly in the north, may contain Hispanic Jewish ancestry.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many New Mexicans speak a unique Spanish dialect.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Due to the historical isolation of New Mexico from other Spanish speakers, part of New Mexico's Spanish vocabulary is unknown from other Spanish speakers.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It uses many Amerindian words for local features and includes anglicized words that express American concepts and modern inventions.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque has the New Mexico Museum of Natural History and Science, the National Hispanic Cultural Center and the National Museum of Nuclear Science & History, as well as the famous Albuquerque Ball Festival every fall.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The first artists of New Mexico whose work survives today are the Mimbres Indians, whose black and white pottery could be confused with modern art, except for the fact that it was produced before 1130.

name: new_mexico
sentence: See the Mimbres culture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Many examples of this work can be seen at the Deming Luna Mimbres Museum and at the Western New Mexico University Museum.

name: new_mexico
sentence: A great arts community thrives in Santa Fe, and has included people such as Bruce Nauman, Richard Tuttle, John Connell and Steina Vasulka.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The capital has several art museums, including the New Mexico Museum of Art, the Spanish Colonial Art Museum, the International Folk Art Museum, the Museum of Indian Arts and Culture, the Museum of Contemporary Indigenous Arts, the Santa Fe SITE and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The colonies for artists and writers flourish, and the small town is full of art galleries.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In August, the city hosts the annual Indian market in Santa Fe, which is the oldest and largest Aboriginal art showcase in the world.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Performing arts include the famous Santa Fe Opera, which features five operas in the repertoire from July to August, the Santa Fe Chamber Music Festival held every summer, and the Lensic Theatre restored a main venue for many kinds of shows.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Santa Fe is also home to Frogville Records, an independent record label.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The weekend following Labour Day is marked by the burning of Zozobra, a 15-metre-long puppet, during the Santa Fe Fiestas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Art is also a common theme in Albuquerque, New Mexico's largest city.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The National Hispanic Cultural Center has organized hundreds of performing art events, art showcases and other events related to Spanish culture in New Mexico and around the world in the Roy E Disney Center for the Performing Arts centre or in other locations of the 53-acre establishment.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico residents and visitors can enjoy art shows from around the world in the Popejoy Hall on the campus of the University of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Popejoy Hall hosts singers, dancers, Broadway shows, other types of acts, and Shakespeare.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Albuquerque also has the unique and memorable KiMo Theater built in 1927 in neo-pueblo architecture.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The KiMo features live theatre and concerts, as well as simultaneous films and operas.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to other theatres of general interest, Albuquerque also has the African American Performing Arts Center and the Exhibition Hall, which showcases the achievements of people of African descent and the Indian Pueblo Cultural Center, which showcases the cultural heritage of New Mexico's First Nations.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico is strong for its Spanish patrimony.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Ancient Spanish traditions such as zarzuelas and flamenco are popular in New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Flamenco dancer and native New Mexican María Benítez founded the Maria Benítez Institute for the Spanish Arts "to present programmes of the highest quality of the rich artistic heritage of Spain, as expressed by music, dance, visual arts and other forms of art".

name: new_mexico
sentence: There is also the Internacional Flamenco Festival of Alburquerque which takes place every year during which Spanish and neo-Mexican native flamenco dancers perform at the University of New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In the mid-20th century, there was a prosperous Hispano school of literature and scholarships produced in English and Spanish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Most notable authors include Angélico Chávez, Nina Otero-Warren, Fabiola Cabeza de Baca, Aurelio Espinosa, Cleofas Jaramillo, Juan Bautista Rael and Aurora Lucero-White Lea.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition, writer D. H. Lawrence lived near Taos in the 1920s at Ranch D. H. Lawrence, where there is a sanctuary containing its ashes.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The strong Spanish, Amerindian and wild West Border motifs of New Mexico provided equipment to many of the State's authors, including Rudolfo Anaya and Tony Hillerman, internationally recognized.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Silver City, in the southwestern mountains of the state, was originally a mining town, and at least one nearby mine still works.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It is perhaps better known today as the house or exhibition center for a large number of artists, visuals and others.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Another ancient mining town that became a haven of art is Madrid, New Mexico.

name: new_mexico
sentence: It was brought to national fame as a filming venue for the movie Wild Hogs in 2007.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The city of Las Cruces, in southern New Mexico, has a museum system affiliated with the Smithsonian Institution Affiliates Program.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Las Cruces also offers a variety of cultural and artistic opportunities to residents and visitors.

name: new_mexico
sentence: In addition to the above-mentioned Wild Hogs, other films filmed in New Mexico include Sunshine Cleaning and Vampires.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The different seasons of the A&E/Netflix Longmire series were filmed in several locations in New Mexico, including Las Vegas, Santa Fe, Eagle Nest and Red River.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The widely acclaimed Breaking Bad television show and its spin-off Better Call Saul were staged and filmed in and around Albuquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: There are no major professional sports teams in New Mexico, but the Isotopes Albuquerque are a Triple-A baseball subsidiary of the Pacific Coast League of Rockies MLB Colorado.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico hosts several Pecos League baseball teams: Roswell Invaders, Ruidoso Osos, Santa Fe Fuego and White Sands Pupfish.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The Duke City Gladiators of the Indoor Football League (IFL) plays their home games at Tingley Coliseum in Albuquerque.

name: new_mexico
sentence: New Mexico United, also based in Albuquerque, started playing in the second level of the American soccer pyramid, the USL championship, in 2019.

name: new_mexico
sentence: College athletics in New Mexico involves various teams from New Mexico Lobos and New Mexico Aggies in many sports.

name: new_mexico
sentence: For many years, the two universities had a rivalry often called "Rio Grande Rivalry" or "Battle of I-25" in recognition of the fact that the two campuses are located along this highway.

name: new_mexico
sentence: The winner of the NMSU-UTEP football match receives the Silver Spade Trophy.

name: new_mexico
sentence: Tom Jager, Olympic gold medallist, who is a champion of controversial high-altitude swimming training, led training camps in Albuquerque at 5,312 feet (1,619 m) and Los Alamos at 7,320 feet (2,231 m).

name: new_mexico
sentence: Raton's NRA Whittington Center is the largest and most comprehensive competitive shooting and training centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is a state in the northeastern part of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: It was one of the thirteen original colonies forming the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: With a total area of 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2), New York is the 27th largest state.

name: new_york
sentence: Its population of over 19 million from 2019 makes it the fourth most populous.

name: new_york
sentence: Sometimes called New York State, it is home to New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: Two thirds of the state's population lives in the New York metropolitan area.

name: new_york
sentence: With an estimated population of 8.34 million in 2019, New York is the most populated city in the United States and the first gateway to immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The metropolitan area of New York is one of the most populated in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: As a world city, New York City is home to the United Nations Headquarters and has been described as the world's cultural, financial and media capital, as well as the most economically powerful city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The state's four most populated cities are Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, while the state's capital is Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has a diverse geography.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is bordered by New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the south and by Connecticut, Massachusetts and Vermont to the east.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a maritime boundary with Rhode Island, east of Long Island, and an international border with the Canadian provinces of Quebec to the north and Ontario to the northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern portion of the state is located on the Atlantic Coastal Plain and includes Long Island and several smaller associated islands, as well as the City of New York and the lower Hudson River valley.

name: new_york
sentence: The larger Upstate New York area includes several chains from the widest Appalachians, and the Adirondack Mountains in the northeast lobe of the state.

name: new_york
sentence: The north-south of the Hudson River valley and the east-west of the Mohawk River valley bisect these more mountainous areas.

name: new_york
sentence: Western New York is considered to be part of the Great Lakes region and the boundaries of Lake Ontario, Lake Erie, and Niagara Falls.

name: new_york
sentence: The central part of the state is dominated by Finger Lakes, a popular tourist and holiday destination.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was inhabited by tribes of Algonquian and Iroquoian Amerindians for several hundred years as the first Europeans came to New York.

name: new_york
sentence: French settlers and Jesuit missionaries arrived south of Montreal to trade and proselytize.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1609 the area was visited by Henry Hudson sailing for the Dutch East India Company.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch built Fort Nassau in 1614 at the confluence of the Hudson and Mohawk rivers, where the present capital of Albany later developed.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch soon moved to New Amsterdam and parts of the Hudson Valley, establishing the multicultural colony of New Netherlands, a trade and immigration centre.

name: new_york
sentence: England took over the colony of the Dutch in 1664.

name: new_york
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War (1775-1783), a group of settlers from New York Province tried to take control of the British colony and finally succeeded in establishing independence.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, the development of the interior by New York, beginning with the Erie Canal, gave it incomparable advantages over other parts of the east coast and built its political and cultural ascendancy.

name: new_york
sentence: Many landmarks in New York are well known, including four of the top ten tourist attractions in the world in 2013: Times Square, Central Park, Niagara Falls and Grand Central Terminal.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the headquarters of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 21st century, New York emerged as a global hub of creativity and entrepreneurship, social tolerance and environmental sustainability.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has approximately 200 colleges and universities, including the State University of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Several have been ranked among the top 100 in the country and around the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The tribes of what is now New York were mainly Haudenosaunee and Algonquian.

name: new_york
sentence: Long Island was divided roughly in two between Wampanoag and Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: The Lenape also controlled most of the area surrounding New York Harbor.

name: new_york
sentence: North of Lenape was a third Algonquian nation, the Mohicans.

name: new_york
sentence: To the north of them, from east to west, there were three Iroquoian nations: the Mohawks, the Iroquois of origin and the Petuns.

name: new_york
sentence: To the south of them, divided about along Appalachia, were Susquehannock and Erie.

name: new_york
sentence: Many of the Wampanoag and Mohican peoples were caught in the War of King Philip, a joint effort of many New England tribes to repel Europeans from their lands.

name: new_york
sentence: After the death of their leader, Chief Philip Metacomet, most of these peoples fled within the country, dividing themselves into Abenaki and Schaghticoke.

name: new_york
sentence: Many Mohicans remained in the area until the 1800s, but a small group known as Ouabano migrated southwest to Western Virginia at an earlier time.

name: new_york
sentence: Maybe they merged with Shawnee.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks and Susquehannock were the most militarist.

name: new_york
sentence: By trying to catch up with Europeans, they targeted other tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: The Mohawks were also known for refusing white settlement on their land and for banishing any people who had converted to Christianity.

name: new_york
sentence: They were a major threat to the Abenakis and Mohicans, while the Susquehannock briefly conquered the Lenape in the 1600s.

name: new_york
sentence: The most devastating event of the century, however, was beaver wars.

name: new_york
sentence: From about 1640 to 1680, the Iroquoian peoples conducted campaigns from modern Michigan to Virginia against the Algonquian and Siwan tribes, as well as both.

name: new_york
sentence: The goal was to control more land for trapping animals, a career that most natives had turned to in the hope of trading with whites first.

name: new_york
sentence: This completely changed the ethnography of the region, and most of the big game was hunted before the whites completely exploded the land.

name: new_york
sentence: Subsequently, the Confederacy of the Iroquois provided shelter for refugees from the Muscouten, Erie, Chononton, Tutelo, Saponi and Tuscarora nations.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 1700s, they also merged with the Mohawks during the Franco-Indian war and took to the remaining Susquehannock of Pennsylvania after they had been decimated in the war.

name: new_york
sentence: Most of these other groups have merged until they cease to exist.

name: new_york
sentence: Then, after the Revolution, a large group of them split up and returned to Ohio, becoming known as Mingo Senatorca.

name: new_york
sentence: The six current tribes of the Iroquois Confederation are the Senatorca, Cayuga, Onondaga, Oneida, Tuscarora and Mohawk.

name: new_york
sentence: The Iroquois fought for both sides during the Revolutionary War

name: new_york
sentence: Today, the Iroquois still live on several reserves in northern New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: Meanwhile, the Lenapes have established a close relationship with William Penn.

name: new_york
sentence: However, when Penn died, his sons managed to take over much of their land and banish it in Ohio.

name: new_york
sentence: When the United States drafted the Indian Removal Act, the Lenapes were transferred to Missouri, while their cousins, the Mohicans, were sent to Wisconsin.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition, in 1778 the United States relocated the Nanticoke from the Delmarva Peninsula to the former Iroquois lands south of Lake Ontario, although they did not stay long.

name: new_york
sentence: They mostly chose to migrate to Canada and merge with the Iroquois, although some moved westward and merged with the Lenape.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1524, Giovanni da Verrazzano, an Italian explorer serving the French crown, explored the Atlantic coast of North America between the Carolinas and Newfoundland, including the port of New York and Narragansett Bay.

name: new_york
sentence: On 17 April 1524 Verrazzano entered New York Bay, passing through the strait now called the Narrows in the north bay which he named Santa Margherita, in honor of the sister of the king of France.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano described it as "a vast coastline with a deep delta in which every type of ship could pass" and added: "that it extends inside for a league and opens to form a beautiful lake.

name: new_york
sentence: This vast water table has warmed up with native boats."

name: new_york
sentence: It landed on the tip of Manhattan and perhaps on the furthest point of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: Verrazzano's stay was interrupted by a storm which pushed him north towards Martha's Vineyard.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1540, French traders in New France built a castle on Castle Island in the present Albany; it was abandoned the following year due to flooding.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1614 the Dutch, under the command of Hendrick Corstiaensen, rebuilt the French castle, which they called Fort Nassau.

name: new_york
sentence: Fort Nassau is the first Dutch settlement in North America and is located along the Hudson River, also in the current Albany.

name: new_york
sentence: The small fort served as a trade and warehouse post.

name: new_york
sentence: Located on the floodplain of the Hudson River, the rudimentary "strong" was taken away by the floods in 1617, and abandoned for good after the construction of Fort Orange, Newfoundland, nearby in 1623.

name: new_york
sentence: Henry Hudson's journey in 1609 marked the beginning of European engagement in the region.

name: new_york
sentence: Sailing for the Dutch East India Company and in search of a passage in Asia, he entered Upper New York Bay on September 11 of the same year.

name: new_york
sentence: His findings encouraged Dutch traders to explore the coast in search of a profitable fur trade with local American Aboriginal tribes.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 17th century, Dutch trading posts were created for the trade of hides from the Lenape, Iroquois and other tribes in the colony of New Netherlands.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of these trading posts was Fort Nassau (1614, near the present Albany); Fort Orange (1624, on the Hudson River, just south of the present town of Albany and created to replace Fort Nassau), developing in the Beverwijck settlement (1647), and in what became Albany; Fort Amsterdam (1625, to develop in the city of New Amsterdam which is now New York City); and Esopus (1653, now Kingston).

name: new_york
sentence: The success of Rensselaerswyck (1630), which surrounded Albany and lasted until the mid-19th century, was also a key factor in the colony's early success.

name: new_york
sentence: The English captured the colony during the Second Anglo-Dutch War and ruled it as the Province of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York was taken over by the Dutch in 1673 during the third Anglo-Dutch war (1672–74) and renamed New Orange.

name: new_york
sentence: It was returned to the English under the Treaty of Westminster a year later.

name: new_york
sentence: The Sons of Liberty were organized in New York in the 1760s, largely in response to the oppressive Stamp Act adopted by the British Parliament in 1765.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Congress met in the city on 19 October of the same year, composed of representatives of all the Thirteen Colonies that paved the way for the Continental Congress.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stamp Act Congress resulted in the Bill of Rights and Grievances, which was the first written expression by American representatives of many of the rights and complaints later expressed in the Declaration of Independence of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: That included the right to representative government.

name: new_york
sentence: At the same time, given the close commercial, personal and sentimental ties with Britain, many New York residents were loyalists.

name: new_york
sentence: The capture of Fort Ticonderoga provided the gun and powder necessary to force a British withdrawal from the siege of Boston in 1775.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the only colony not voting for independence, as delegates were not allowed to do so.

name: new_york
sentence: New York subsequently endorsed the Declaration of Independence on 9 July 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: The Constitution of the State of New York was conceived by a convention that met in White Plains on July 10, 1776, and after repeated adjournments and change of location, completed its work in Kingston on Sunday evening, April 20, 1777, when the new constitution drafted by John Jay was adopted with a single dissenting voice.

name: new_york
sentence: It has not been submitted to the people for ratification.

name: new_york
sentence: On July 30, 1777, George Clinton was inaugurated as the first governor of New York City in Kingston.

name: new_york
sentence: About a third of the battles of the American Revolutionary War took place in New York; the first major battle (and the largest of the whole war) was the Battle of Long Island, alias.

name: new_york
sentence: Battle of Brooklyn, August 1776.

name: new_york
sentence: After their victory, the British occupied the city of New York, making it their military and political base of operations in North America during the conflict and, consequently, the centre of interest of General George Washington's intelligence network.

name: new_york
sentence: Of the famous ships in Wallabout Bay British Prison, more American fighters died of intentional negligence than they were killed in combat in every battle of the combined war.

name: new_york
sentence: Both sides lost more soldiers than wounded.

name: new_york
sentence: The first of the two great British armies was captured by the Continental Army at the Battle of Saratoga in 1777, a success that influenced France to join the revolutionaries.The state constitution was promulgated in 1777.

name: new_york
sentence: New York became the eleventh State to ratify the United States Constitution on 26 July 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: In an attempt to maintain sovereignty and remain an independent nation positioned between the new United States and British North America, four of the Iroquois nations fought on the British side; only the Oneids and their dependents, the Tuscarora, joined the Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: In retaliation for the attacks on the border by the Mohawk forces of Joseph Brant and Loyalist, the Sullivan expedition in 1779 destroyed nearly 50 Iroquois villages, adjacent agricultural lands and winter shops, forcing many refugees to travel to Niagara under British control.

name: new_york
sentence: As British allies, the Iroquois were expelled from New York, although they did not participate in the treaty negotiations.

name: new_york
sentence: They moved to Canada after the war and were granted Crown land concessions.

name: new_york
sentence: In the settlement of treaties, the British ceded most Indian lands to the new United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Because New York entered into a treaty with the Iroquois without Congress' approval, some of the land purchases have been the subject of land claims since the late 20th century by the tribes recognized by the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has sold more than 5 million acres (20,000 km2) of ancient Iroquois territory in the years following the revolutionary war, leading to rapid development in northern New York.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the Treaty of Paris, the last vestige of British authority in the Thirteen Old Colonies – their troops in New York – left in 1783, which was long celebrated as a day of evacuation.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the national capital under the statutes of the Confederation and the perpetual Union, the first national government.

name: new_york
sentence: This organization was found to be insufficient, and prominent New Yorker Alexander Hamilton advocated a new government that would include an executive, national courts and the power to impose.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton led the Annapolis Convention (1786) which called for the Philadelphia Convention, which drafted the United States Constitution, in which he also participated.

name: new_york
sentence: The new government had to be a strong federal national government to replace the relatively weaker confederation of the different states.

name: new_york
sentence: Following a lively debate, which included the publication of the now quintessential constitutional interpretation — The Federalist Papers — as a series of episodes in New York City newspapers, New York was the 11th state to ratify the United States Constitution on 26 July 1788.

name: new_york
sentence: New York remained the national capital under the new constitution until 1790 and was the site of the inauguration of President George Washington, the drafting of the Charter of Rights of the United States and the first session of the Supreme Court of the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Hamilton's recovery of the highly indebted U.S. economy after the war and the establishment of a national bank have greatly contributed to New York City becoming the financial centre of the new nation.

name: new_york
sentence: The Dutch and British imported African slaves as workers into the city and colony; New York had the second largest slave population after Charleston in South Carolina.

sentence: Slavery was widespread in New York and some agricultural areas.

name: new_york
sentence: The state passed a law for the progressive abolition of slavery shortly after the revolutionary war, but the last slave of New York was not released until 1827.

name: new_york
sentence: Transportation in western New York was done by expensive cars on muddy roads before the canals opened up rich agricultural land for long distances.

name: new_york
sentence: Governor DeWitt Clinton promoted the Erie Canal, which links New York to the Great Lakes through the Hudson River, the new canal, and rivers and lakes.

name: new_york
sentence: Construction began in 1817 and the Erie Canal opened in 1825.

name: new_york
sentence: The tow-boats pulled by the horses on the tow-paths moved slowly over the canal, carrying passengers and cargo.

name: new_york
sentence: Agricultural products came from the Midwest, and finished manufactured goods moved westward.

name: new_york
sentence: It was a wonder of engineering that opened up vast areas of New York to commerce and colonization.

name: new_york
sentence: It has allowed port cities in the Great Lakes such as Buffalo and Rochester to grow and prosper.

name: new_york
sentence: It has also linked the emerging agricultural production of the Midwest and marine transportation on the Great Lakes to the port of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Improved transportation has increased population migration to the territories west of New York.

sentence: After 1850, railways largely replaced the canal.

name: new_york
sentence: South cotton factors, planters and bankers visited so often that they had favorite hotels.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the beginning of the 19th century, New York has been the largest entry point for legal immigration to the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: In the United States, the federal government did not assume direct jurisdiction over immigration until 1890.

name: new_york
sentence: Prior to that date, the case was delegated to the various states, then by contract between the states and the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: Most immigrants to New York would land on busy wharves along the Hudson and East Rivers in the eventual Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: On May 4, 1847, the New York State Parliament created the Council of Immigration Commissioners to regulate immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: The first permanent immigration depot in New York was established in 1855 at Castle Garden, a fort converted from the time of the War of 1812 in what is now Battery Park, at the tip of Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first immigrants to arrive at the new depot were on three vessels that had just been released from quarantine.

name: new_york
sentence: Castle Garden was the deposit of immigrants from New York until its closure on 18 April 1890, when the federal government took control of immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: During this period, more than eight million immigrants went through its doors (two out of three American immigrants).

name: new_york
sentence: When the federal government took control, it established the Immigration Bureau, which chose the three acres of Ellis Island in Upper New York Harbor for an entry depot.

name: new_york
sentence: Already under federal control, the island was used as an ammunition depot.

name: new_york
sentence: It was chosen because of its relative isolation with the proximity of New York City and the railway lines of Jersey City, New Jersey, by a short ferry ride.

name: new_york
sentence: While the island was under development and expansion through land reclamation, the federal government operated a temporary storage facility at the Barge battery office.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island opened its doors on 1 Jan. 1892 and became a central immigration centre until the adoption of the National Origins Act in 1924, thereby reducing immigration.

name: new_york
sentence: After that date, the only immigrants to pass were internally displaced persons or war refugees.

name: new_york
sentence: The island ceased all immigration treatment on 12 November 1954, when the last person detained on the island, Norwegian seaman Arne Peterssen, was released.

name: new_york
sentence: He had passed his shore leave and left the ferry at 10:15 a.m. in the direction of Manhattan to return to his ship.

name: new_york
sentence: More than 12 million immigrants passed through Ellis Island between 1892 and 1954.

name: new_york
sentence: More than 100 million Americans across the United States can trace their ancestry to these immigrants.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island has been the subject of a long-standing border and jurisdictional dispute between the State of New York and the State of New Jersey, as both claimed.

name: new_york
sentence: The issue was resolved in 1998 by the United States Supreme Court, which ruled that the original island of 3.3 acres (1.3 ha) was the territory of New York State and that the remainder of the 27.5 acres (11 ha) added after 1834 per landfill was in New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: The island was added to the National Park Service in May 1965 by President Lyndon B. Johnson and is still owned by the federal government as part of the Statue of Liberty National Monument.

name: new_york
sentence: Ellis Island was opened to the public as an immigration museum in 1990.

name: new_york
sentence: On October 29 and 30, 2012, Hurricane Sandy caused a major destruction of the state's shores, ravaging parts of New York City, Long Island and South Westchester with record storm surges, severe flooding and violent winds causing power outages for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers, resulting in fuel shortages and disruptions to public transit systems.

name: new_york
sentence: The storm and its profound effects led to discussions on the construction of sea walls and other coastal barriers around the shores of New York City and Long Island in order to minimize the risks arising from another such event.

name: new_york
sentence: This risk is considered highly likely due to global warming and sea level rise.

sentence: New York covers 54,555 square miles (141,300 km2) and ranks 27th among the largest states according to their size.

sentence: The highest altitude in New York is Mount Marcy in the Adirondacks, 5,344 feet (1,629 meters) above sea level; while the lowest point in the state is at sea level on the Atlantic Ocean.

name: new_york
sentence: The boundaries of the state include a water limit in (hourly from the west) two Great Lakes (Lake Erie and Lake Ontario, which are connected by the Niagara River); the provinces of Ontario and Quebec in Canada, with New York and Ontario sharing the archipelago of the Thousand Islands within the St. Lawrence River, while most of its border with Quebec is on land; it shares Lake Champlain with the State of Vermont, New England; the State of New England of Massachusetts primarily has a land boundary; New York extends to Long Island Sound and the Atlantic Ocean, sharing a water boundary with Rhode Island, while Connecticut has land and maritime boundaries.

sentence: In general, New York has a damp continental climate, although under the climate classification of Köppen, New York City has a humid subtropical climate.

sentence: The weather in New York City is strongly influenced by two continental air masses: a warm, humid southwest and a cold, dry northwest.

name: new_york
sentence: The lower part of New York State, which includes New York City, Long Island and the lower parts of the Hudson Valley, has rather warm summers with periods of high humidity and relatively mild cold and humid winters compared to temperatures at Upstate New York due to lower elevations in the lower state area, proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, and relatively lower latitude.

name: new_york
sentence: At the top of New York, summers are warm, marked by short and occasional intervals of dirty conditions, with long and cold winters.

sentence: The west of New York, particularly the Tug Hill area, receives heavy lake-effect snow, especially during the early winter months, before the surface of Lake Ontario itself is covered with ice.

sentence: The summer climate is cool in the Adirondacks, Catskills and at higher altitudes of the South Third.

sentence: Summer daytime temperatures range from the high 1970s to the low 1980s (25-28 °C) in most of the state.
