sentence: In most winter seasons, temperatures can be expected to be −13°F (−25°C) or lower in the northern (northern) highlands and 5°F (−15°C) or colder in the southwest and east-central South Tier highlands.

sentence: New York had a record temperature of 108°F (42.2°C) on July 22, 1926.

name: new_york
sentence: Some species that can be found in this state are American ginseng, starred stonewort, waterthym, water chestnut, eastern poisoned ivy, poisoned sumac, giant seaweed, cow parsnip, and common nettle.

sentence: There are more than 20 species of mammals, more than 20 species of birds, some species of amphibians, and several species of reptiles.

name: new_york

sentence: The annual New York City India Day parade, which took place on or about every August 15th since 1981, is the largest parade on Indian Independence Day outside India.

name: new_york
sentence: At the time of the 2000 census, New York had the largest Italian population in America, forming the largest self-identified ancestral group on Staten Island and Long Island, followed by the Irish Americans.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany and the Mohawk Valley also have large communities of ethnic Italians and American Irish, reflecting the immigration of the 19th and early 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey, New York also had the largest Greek American population of 148,637 people (0.7% of the state).

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo and western New York, American Germans are the largest ancestry.

name: new_york
sentence: In Northern New York, French Canadians represent the largest ethnic group, given the proximity of the region to Quebec.

name: new_york
sentence: The Americans of English origin are present throughout the northern part of New York State, reflecting the first colonial immigrants and later.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the most commonly spoken American English dialects in New York, in addition to American general English, were the dialect of the New York City region (including New York Latino English and Northern Jersey English), the accent of Western New England around Albany, and English from the northern interior of America in Buffalo and western New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Up to 800 languages are spoken in New York City, making it the most diverse city in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 70.72 per cent (12,788,233) of New York residents aged five and over reported speaking only English at home, while 14.44 per cent (2,611,903) spoke Spanish, 2.61 per cent (472,955) Chinese (which includes Cantonese and Mandarin), 1.2 per cent (216,468) Russian, 1.18% (213,785) Italian, 0.79 per cent (142,169) French Creole, 0.75 per cent (135,789) French, 0.67 per cent (121,917) Yiddish, 0.63 per cent (114,574) Korean and Polish were spoken by 0.53 per cent (95,413) of the population over five years of age.

name: new_york
sentence: A total of 29.28 per cent (5,295,016) of New York's population aged 5 and over reported speaking a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the American Community Survey's 2017 estimates, almost six million residents spoke a language other than English.

name: new_york
sentence: About 1,249,541 New York residents spoke Spanish, 386,290 Chinese, 122,150 Russian, 63,615 Haitian Creoles, 62,219 Bengali and 60,405 Koreans.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2018, 12,756,975 people aged 5 years and older spoke only English and 10,415,395 people aged 18 years and older spoke only English.

name: new_york
sentence: Most Spanish-speaking households were not English-speaking.

name: new_york
sentence: It is estimated that 2.7 million households with residents aged 5 years and over speak Spanish.

name: new_york
sentence: Chinese, Slavic and French were the most important languages spoken by households in 2018.

name: new_york
sentence: The majority of New York's religious population is Christian (60%), followed by irreligious (27%), Judaism (7 %), Islam (2 %), Buddhism and Hinduism (1% each) and other religions (0.5%).

name: new_york
sentence: Before the 1800s Protestant sects dominated New York's religious life, although religion did not play as important a role in Nova Scotia's public life as it did in New England with its Puritan population.

name: new_york
sentence: Historically, New York served as the basis for new Christian confessions in the second great revival.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Western Christian traditions and non-Christian religions did not grow in much of the state's history because immigration came mainly from Western Europe (which at the time was dominated by Western Christianity and favoured by quotas in the Federal Immigration Act).

name: new_york
sentence: The Immigration and Nationality Act 1965 had abolished quotas, which had led to the growth of other religious groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The Roman Catholic Church is New York's largest Christian denomination (31%).

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Roman Catholic diocese is the archdiocese of the Latin Church of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The largest Eastern Catholic diocese is the Ruthenian Catholic Eparchy of Passaic of the Ruthenian Greek Catholic Church.

name: new_york
sentence: The United Methodist Church is the largest major Protestant denomination and the second largest in total, followed by the Episcopal Church in the United States and other continuing Anglican organizations.

name: new_york
sentence: The Presbyterian Church (USA), the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, and the American Baptist Churches were the following major denominations.

name: new_york
sentence: The main Protestants together make up 11% of the state's Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: In evangelical Protestantism, Baptists, non-denominational Protestants, and Pentecostals were the most important groups.

name: new_york
sentence: The National Baptist Convention (USA) and the Progressive National Baptist Convention were the largest Protestant churches historically black in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 10% of New York Christians are evangelical Protestants.

name: new_york
sentence: Eastern Orthodox and Eastern Orthodox collectively represented 1% of the religious population alongside Jehovah's Witnesses and other Christians.

name: new_york
sentence: Non-Christian religions make up 12 per cent of the religious population.

name: new_york
sentence: Judaism was the second most important religion in 2014.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, 588,500 practiced Orthodox Judaism.

name: new_york
sentence: A little over 392,953 professed Islam.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is home to the oldest Zoroastrian Fire Temple in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Less than 1% of New York's population practices New Age and contemporary paganism.

name: new_york
sentence: Amerindian religions are also a significant minority.

name: new_york
sentence: The Irreligious are a growing community in the metropolitan area of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: In the state as a whole, 17 per cent do nothing in particular and 5 per cent are atheistic and agnostic.

name: new_york
sentence: Approximately 3.8 per cent of the state's adult population identifies as lesbian, gay, bisexual or transgender.

name: new_york
sentence: This is a total adult LGBT population of 570,388.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2010, the number of same-sex couples was approximately 48,932.

name: new_york
sentence: New York was the fifth state to allow homosexual marriages after New Hampshire.

name: new_york
sentence: Michael Bloomberg, Mayor of New York, said that "same-sex marriages in New York generated approximately $259 million in economic impact and $16 million in municipal revenue" in the first year after the passage of the Marriage Equality Act.

name: new_york
sentence: Same-sex marriages in New York were legalized on 24 June 2011 and were allowed to start 30 days later.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is also home to the largest transgender population in the United States, estimated at 25,000 in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: The annual New York Pride March (or gay pride parade) crosses 5th Avenue in Manhattan, ending in Greenwich Village, and rivals the Sao Paulo Gay Pride Parade as the largest pride parade in the world, attracting tens of thousands of participants and millions of spectators on the sidewalks each June.

name: new_york
sentence: The Stonewall riots were a series of spontaneous and violent protests by members of the gay community against a police raid that took place in the early morning of June 28, 1969, at Stonewall Inn, Greenwich Village, Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: They are widely seen as the most important event leading to the gay liberation movement and the modern struggle for LGBT rights.

name: new_york
sentence: In June 2017, plans were announced for the first official LGBT monument commissioned by the State of New York, unlike the Stonewall National Monument, commissioned by the U.S. federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: The State Monument should be built in the Hudson River Park in Manhattan, near the Hudson River wharves, which have historically been a significant symbol of New York's central role as a meeting place and refuge for LGBT communities.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the state of New York also planned to host the largest international celebration of LGBT pride in 2019, known as Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019, to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Stonewall riots.

name: new_york
sentence: In New York, the 2019 Stonewall 50–WorldPride NYC events produced by Heritage of Pride were enhanced through a partnership with the LGBT division of the I LOVE NY program and included a reception centre during the weeks surrounding the Stonewall 50 / WorldPride events, which was open to all.

name: new_york
sentence: Other commemorative, cultural and educational arts programs on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the rebellion at Stonewall Inn took place throughout the city and around the world; Stonewall 50 – WorldPride NYC 2019 was the largest celebration of LGBT pride in history, attracting approximately five million people.

name: new_york
sentence: Brooklyn Liberation March, the largest demonstration on transgender rights in LGBTQ history, took place on June 14, 2020, from Grand Army Plaza to Fort Greene, Brooklyn, and focused on supporting the lives of black transgender people, attracting between 15,000 and 20,000 participants.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's gross domestic product for 2018 was $1.7 trillion.

name: new_york
sentence: If the state of New York were an independent nation, it would be the 11th largest economy in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: However, in 2013, the multi-state metropolitan statistical area, centred on the city of New York, produced a gross metropolitan product (GMP) of nearly $1.4 trillion, while in 2012, the corresponding combined statistical area produced a GMP of more than $1.7 trillion, both of which were ranked first by a large margin and behind the GDP of only nine countries.

name: new_york
sentence: Anchored by Wall Street in the Financial District of Lower Manhattan, New York City was called both the most economically powerful city and the world's largest financial centre.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower Manhattan is the third largest business district in the United States and houses the New York Stock Exchange, on Wall Street, and NASDAQ, at 165 Broadway, representing respectively the largest and second largest stock exchanges in the world, measured both by the average volume of daily transactions and by the total market capitalization of their listed companies in 2013.

name: new_york
sentence: Wall Street's investment bank charges amounted to approximately $40 billion in 2012, while in 2013, New York bank executives who manage risk management and compliance functions earned up to $324,000 per year.

name: new_york
sentence: During the 2013–14 fiscal year, the Wall Street securities industry generated 19% of New York's tax revenues.

name: new_york
sentence: The city of New York remains the world's largest trading centre in the public capital and debt markets, partly because of the size and financial development of the American economy.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also directs the management of hedge funds

name: new_york
sentence: Several investment banks and investment managers headquartered in Manhattan are important participants in other global financial centres.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also the main commercial banking centre in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Several of the world's largest media conglomerates are also based in the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Manhattan contained approximately 520 million square feet (48.1 million square feet) of office space in 2013, making it the largest office market in the United States, while Midtown Manhattan is the largest central business district in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: Silicon Alley, centered in New York, has become a metanym for the sphere encompassing the high-tech and entrepreneurship ecosystem of the New York metropolitan area; in 2015, Silicon Alley generated more than $7.3 billion in venture capital.

name: new_york
sentence: High-tech industries, including digital media, biotechnology, software development, game design and other areas in the field of information technology, are growing, supported by New York's position at the terminus of several transatlantic fibre optic lines, its intellectual capital, and its open-air wireless connectivity.

name: new_york
sentence: In December 2014, the State of New York announced a $50 million venture capital fund to encourage companies working in biotechnology and advanced materials; according to Governor Andrew Cuomo, seed money would help entrepreneurs market their research.

name: new_york
sentence: On December 19, 2011, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced his choice from Cornell University and the Technion-Israel Institute of Technology to build a $2 billion college of applied science on Roosevelt Island in Manhattan to transform New York into the world's first technological capital.

name: new_york
sentence: Albany, Saratoga County, Rensselaer County, and the Hudson Valley, collectively recognized as the Eastern New York Technology Valley, have experienced significant growth in high-tech computing equipment, with major advances in nanotechnology, digital electronics design, and the manufacture of microchip integrated circuits dependent on water and electricity, involving companies including IBM and its Thomas J. Watson Research Centre, as well as the three foreign companies, GlobalFoundries, Samsung and Taiwan Semiconductor, among others.

name: new_york
sentence: The region's high-tech ecosystem is supported by technology-based academic institutions, including the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and SUNY Polytechnic Institute.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2015, Tech Valley, which straddles both sides of the Adirondack Northway and New York Thruway, generated more than $163 million in venture capital.

name: new_york
sentence: The Rochester region is important in the field of photographic processing and imaging as well as in the incubation of an increasingly diverse high-tech sphere encompassing STEM domains, as well as the results of private start-up companies working with major academic institutions, including the University of Rochester and Cornell University.

name: new_york
sentence: Westchester County has developed a booming biotechnology sector in the 21st century, with more than $1 billion in private investment expected to begin in 2016.

name: new_york
sentence: Creative industries, which are engaged in the production and dissemination of knowledge and information, such as new media, digital media, film and television production, advertising, fashion, design and architecture, account for an increasing share of employment, with the city of New York having a strong competitive advantage in these industries.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2014, the State of New York offered tax incentives of up to $420 million per year for the production of films within the state, the most generous tax refund among the U.S. states.

name: new_york
sentence: New York also attracted higher visual effects jobs by further increasing its tax credit to a maximum of 35 per cent for post-film production in Upstate New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The filmed entertainment industry has grown in New York, contributing almost $9 billion to the New York economy only in 2015.

name: new_york
sentence: I Love New York is a slogan, logo and state song that are the basis of an advertising campaign and has been used since 1977 to promote tourism in New York State, including New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The brand logo is the property of New York State Empire State Development.

name: new_york
sentence: The Broadway League reported that Broadway programs sold approximately $1.27 billion in tickets for the 2013–14 season, an increase of 11.4% from $1.39 billion for the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: Attendance in 2013–14 was $12.21 million, an increase of 5.5% compared to the $11.57 million in the 2012–13 season.

name: new_york
sentence: New York exports a wide variety of products such as prepared food, computers and electronics, cut diamonds and other products.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2007, the Government exported a total of $71.1 billion of goods, with Canada ($15 billion), Switzerland ($5.9 billion), Israel ($4.9 billion) and Hong Kong ($3.4 billion) the top five foreign export markets.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's main imports are oil, gold, aluminum, natural gas, electricity, rough diamonds and lumber.

name: new_york
sentence: The government also has an important manufacturing sector that includes clothing printing and production, primarily in New York; and furs, railway equipment, auto parts and bus line vehicles, concentrated in Upstate areas.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the third largest producer of grapes in the country, and the second largest producer of wine, behind California.

name: new_york
sentence: The southern hills of Finger Lakes, the Hudson Valley, the northern fork of Long Island and the south shore of Lake Erie are the main wine-growing and wine-growing areas of New York, with many vineyards.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2012, New York had 320 wineries and 37,000 hectares of vines, generating full-time jobs for nearly 25,000 people and annual wages over $1.1 billion, and producing $4.8 billion in direct economic impact of grapes, grape juice, wine and grape products.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York agricultural industry is an important producer overall, ranking among the top five states for agricultural products, including maple syrup, apples, cherries, cabbage, dairy products, onions and potatoes.

name: new_york
sentence: The state is the largest producer of cabbage in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: The state owns about a quarter of its agricultural land and produced $3.4 billion in agricultural products in 2001.

name: new_york
sentence: The south shore of Lake Ontario offers the right combination of soils and microclimates for many apple, cherries, plums, pears and peaches.

name: new_york
sentence: Apples are also cultivated in the Hudson Valley and near Lake Champlain.

name: new_york
sentence: A medium-sized commercial salt water fishery is located along the Atlantic side of Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: The main values are clams, lobsters, squid and plaice.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2017, the state of New York consumed 156,370 gigawatt hours (GWh) of electrical energy.

name: new_york
sentence: Lower-state areas (Hudson Valley, New York and Long Island) consumed 66% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The ultra-state regions accounted for 50% of this amount.

name: new_york
sentence: The maximum load in 2017 was 29.699 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: The resource capacity in 2017 was 42,839 MW.

name: new_york
sentence: NYISO's market monitor described the overall average price of electricity as a range (a single value was not provided) from $25 per MWh to $53 per MWh for 2017.

name: new_york
sentence: At the post-secondary level, the State-wide public academic system is the State University of New York (SUNY).

name: new_york
sentence: SUNY includes 64 community colleges, technical colleges, undergraduate colleges and doctoral institutions, including several universities.

name: new_york
sentence: New York's flagship university is Buffalo University, founded by U.S. President Billard Fillmore.

name: new_york
sentence: Along with Buffalo University, Binghamton University also ranks high in the rankings of the best public universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City has its own City University of New York (CUNY), which is funded by the city.

name: new_york
sentence: Columbia University, Cornell University and New York University are among the most important higher education institutions in New York, all world-renowned private universities and members of the Association of American Universities, the first group of research universities in the United States.

name: new_york
sentence: Other notable private universities are Syracuse University and Fordham University.

name: new_york
sentence: Among the smallest private institutions of higher education are Rockefeller University, Mercy College, the New York Institute of Technology, the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Yeshiva University and Hofstra University.

name: new_york
sentence: There are also a multitude of graduate schools in New York State, including schools of medicine, law and engineering.

name: new_york
sentence: West Point, the U.S. Army Service Academy, is located just south of Newburgh, on the west bank of the Hudson River.

name: new_york
sentence: The Federal Merchant Navy Academy is located at Kings Point on Long Island.

name: new_york
sentence: A number of selective liberal private institutions are located in New York.

name: new_york
sentence: These include Bard College, Barnard College, Colgate University, Hamilton College, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, Marist College, Sarah Lawrence College, Skidmore College, Union College, and Vassar College.

name: new_york
sentence: Two of these schools, Barnard and Vassar, are members of the Seven Sisters elite, originally all women's schools with links to the Ivy League.

name: new_york
sentence: Barnard was affiliated with Columbia University, its Manhattan neighbour, and Vassar became a co-educator in 1969 after refusing a merger offer with Yale University.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is also home to what is widely regarded as the best performing arts school in the world.

name: new_york
sentence: The Juilliard School, located in Manhattan's Upper West Side, is one of the world's largest music and dance schools.

name: new_york
sentence: The Eastman School of Music, a professional school at the University of Rochester, was ranked first among the American music schools by US News & World Report for five consecutive years.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State University accredits and establishes standards for primary, intermediate and secondary education in the State, while the New York State Department of Education supervises public schools and monitors their standardized testing.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Education operates the New York City Public School System.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1894, reflecting general racial discrimination, the State passed a law enabling communities to establish separate schools for children of African-American descent.

name: new_york
sentence: In 1900 the state passed another law requiring integrated schools.

name: new_york
sentence: In fiscal 2013, New York spent more money on public education per student than any other state, according to U.S. Census Bureau statistics.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has one of the largest and oldest transport infrastructure in the country.

name: new_york
sentence: The engineering problems posed by the complex terrain of the State and the unique infrastructure problems of the city of New York, caused by urban congestion, had to be overcome forever.

name: new_york
sentence: The expansion of the state population followed the trail of the first waterways, first the Hudson River and the Mohawk River, then the Erie Canal.

name: new_york
sentence: In the 19th century, railways were built along the river valleys, followed by the New York State Thruway in the 20th century.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Transportation (NYSDOT) is the New York Government Department responsible for the establishment and operation of highways, railways, public transport systems, ports, waterways and air facilities in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: The NYSDOT is headquartered at 50 Wolf Road in Colonie, Albany County.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York and New Jersey Port Authority (PANYNJ) is a joint venture between the States of New York and New Jersey and authorized by the American Congress, established in 1921 through an inter-State pact, which oversees much of the regional transportation infrastructure, including bridges, tunnels, airports and seaports, within the geographic jurisdiction of the port of New York and New Jersey.

name: new_york
sentence: This port area of 1,500 m2 (3,900 km2) is generally covered within a 25 mi (40 km) radius of the national monument of the Statue of Liberty.

name: new_york
sentence: The Port Authority is headquartered at the 4 World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: In addition to the well-known New York Metro system, which is confined to the City of New York, four suburban rail networks enter and exit the city: the Long Island Railway, the Metro-North Railway, the Trans-Hudson Harbour Authority and five of New Jersey Transit's railway lines.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT) is the New York City government agency responsible for the management of much of New York's transportation infrastructure.

name: new_york
sentence: Other cities in New York have urban and regional public transportation.

name: new_york
sentence: In Buffalo, the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority manages Buffalo Metro Rail's light rail system; in Rochester, Rochester Metro operated from 1927 to 1956, but became obsolete as the government and the federal government invested in roads.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles (NYSDMV or DMV) is the government agency responsible for the registration and inspection of motor vehicles and other motor vehicles, as well as the issuance of driving licences in New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: In 2008, NYSDMV had 11,284,546 driving licences and 10,697,644 vehicle registrations in force.

name: new_york
sentence: All gasoline vehicles registered in New York State must undergo an emission inspection every 12 months to ensure that environmental quality controls prevent air pollution.

name: new_york
sentence: Diesel-powered vehicles with a gross weight of more than 8,500 pounds and registered in most counties of Downstate New York are subject to annual emission inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: All vehicles registered in New York State are subject to an annual safety inspection.

name: new_york
sentence: Portions of the transportation system are intermodal, allowing passengers to switch easily from one mode of transport to another.

name: new_york
sentence: One of the most notable examples is AirTrain JFK, which allows rail passengers to travel directly to the John F. Kennedy International Airport terminals and the New York Underground Metro.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York Government embodies the Government structure of the State of New York as established by the Constitution of the State of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: It is composed of three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: new_york
sentence: The Governor is the Head of the Executive of the State and is assisted by the Lieutenant Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: Both are elected on the same note.

name: new_york
sentence: Other elected members include the Attorney General and the Controller.

name: new_york
sentence: The Secretary of State, former elected officer, is currently appointed by the Governor.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York State Legislative Assembly is bicameral and includes the New York State Senate and the New York State Assembly.

name: new_york
sentence: The Assembly is composed of 150 members, while the Senate varies in its number of members, with currently 63.

name: new_york
sentence: The Legislative Assembly has the power to make laws, subject to the Governor's power to veto a bill.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the right of veto may be annulled by the legislator if there is a two-thirds majority in favour of exceeding each chamber.

name: new_york
sentence: The permanent laws of a general nature are codified in the consolidated laws of New York.

name: new_york
sentence: The highest court of appeal in the unified judicial system is the Court of Appeal, while the first court of first instance is the County Court (or the New York Supreme Court).

name: new_york
sentence: The Supreme Court also acts as an intermediate court of appeal for many cases, and local courts deal with a variety of other issues, including small disputes, traffic tickets and local zoning issues, and are the starting point for all criminal cases.

name: new_york
sentence: The New York courts are the largest local judicial system.

name: new_york
sentence: The State is divided into counties, cities, towns and villages, all of which are municipal corporations vis-à-vis their own governments, as well as various corporations that serve for unique purposes that are also local governments, such as school districts, fire districts and public utility corporations in New York State, often known as development authorities or corporations.

name: new_york
sentence: Each municipal corporation is given different powers of home government, as provided for in the New York Constitution.

name: new_york
sentence: The State also has 10 Indian reserves.

name: new_york
sentence: There have been several movements concerning the secession of New York State.

name: new_york
sentence: Proposals include a State of Long Island, consisting of everything on the island outside New York; a State called Niagara, the counties of western New York State; the counties of northern New York State called Upstate New York; making New York City a State; a proposal for a new County of Peconic in eastern Long Island; and for the borough of Staten Island to leave New York City.

name: new_york
sentence: The death penalty was reintroduced in 1995 under the administration of Pataki, but the law was declared unconstitutional in 2004, when the New York Court of Appeal ruled in People v. LaValle that it violated the Constitution of the State.

name: new_york
sentence: The remaining death penalty was commuted by the court to life imprisonment in 2007, in People v. John Taylor, and death row was dissolved in 2008, pursuant to an order of Governor David Paterson.

name: new_york
sentence: No executions had taken place in New York since 1963.

name: new_york
sentence: Legislative efforts to amend the law had failed, and the death penalty was no longer required at the state level, although some crimes falling within the federal government's jurisdiction were punishable by the federal death penalty.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City is represented by Chuck Schumer and Kirsten Gillibrand in the United States Senate.

name: new_york
sentence: There are twenty-seven congress districts, the third largest number of congress districts in the country, equal to Florida and behind California 53 and Texas 36.

name: new_york
sentence: As of 2019, 21 districts were represented by members of the Democratic Party, while 6 were represented by Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Representation declined from 29 in 2013 due to the slowdown in the overall population growth of the State compared to the overall national population growth.

name: new_york
sentence: New York has 29 votes in the national presidential elections, down from its 47-vote summit between 1933 and 1953.

name: new_york
sentence: The state has a significant imbalance in payments with the federal government.

name: new_york
sentence: According to the New York State Comptroller's Office, New York received 91 cents of services for every dollar it sent to the United States federal government in fiscal year 2013; New York ranked 46th in the federal balance of payments to the state on a per capita basis.

name: new_york
sentence: In April 2016, Democrats represented a plurality of voters in New York, representing more than twice as many registered voters as any other political party.

name: new_york
sentence: Since the second half of the 20th century, New York has generally supported Democratic Party candidates in national elections.

name: new_york
sentence: Democratic presidential candidate Barack Obama won the State of New York by more than 25 percentage points in 2012 and 2008.

name: new_york
sentence: New York City, along with other major cities in the state, including Albany, Buffalo, Rochester, Yonkers and Syracuse, are important democratic strongholds, with liberal politics.

name: new_york
sentence: However, the rural areas of New York State are generally more conservative than cities and tend to favour Republicans.

name: new_york
sentence: Largely populated suburban areas, such as Westchester County and Long Island, have crossed the main parties since the 1980s, but most often they support the Democrats.

name: new_york
sentence: New York is the largest source of political funding in the United States for the two major parties.

name: new_york
sentence: Four of the nation's five main postal codes for political contributions are in Manhattan.

name: new_york
sentence: The first postal code, 10021 in the Upper East Side, generated the most money for George W. Bush and Al Gore's 2000 presidential campaigns.

name: new_york
sentence: The State of New York has the distinction of being the State of origin for the two major parties appointed in three presidential elections.

name: new_york
sentence: The 1904 presidential election saw the former governor of New York and outgoing president Theodore Roosevelt face Alton B. Parker, Chief Justice of the New York Court of Appeal.

name: new_york

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is a state in the southeastern region of the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was established as a royal colony in 1729 and is one of the Thirteen original colonies.

sentence: As the anthropologist Robbie Ethridge described, the Mississippi break-up zone was an area of great instability, in what is now the South American, caused by the instability of the Mississippi chiefdoms, high mortality due to new Eurasian diseases, the construction of a global capitalist economy based on the trade of Amerindian slaves, and the emergence of indigenous "militarist slave societies".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Historically documented tribes in the North Carolina region include the Algonquian tribes of Carolina in coastal areas, such as Chowanoke, Roanoke, Pamelico, Machapunga, Corea and Cape Fear, which were the first to be met by the English; Meherrin, Cherokee and Tuscarora Indians speaking Iroquoian from within; and Southeast Siwan tribes, such as Cheraw, Waxhaw, Saponi, Waccamaw and Catawba tribes of Piedmont.

name: north_carolina

sentence: The majority of settlers generally supported the American Revolution, and a smaller number of loyalists than in other colonies such as Georgia, South Carolina, Delaware, and New York.

sentence: During colonial times, Edenton served as a state capital from 1722, and New Bern was chosen as the capital in 1766.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Officially established in 1792 as the seat of the county and capital of the state, the city bears the name of Sir Walter Raleigh, godfather of Roanoke, the "lost colony" on Roanoke Island.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The colony's population more than quadrupled, from 52,000 in 1740 to 270,000 in 1780, due to strong immigration from Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania, as well as immigrants from abroad.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Differences in colonization patterns in eastern and western North Carolina, or Tidewater and highlands, affected the political, economic and social life of the state from the 18th to the 20th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tidewater, in eastern North Carolina, was established mainly by immigrants from rural England and Scottish Highlands.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western highland of North Carolina was established mainly by the Scottish-Irish, English, and German Protestants, the so-called "cohee".

name: north_carolina
sentence: Arriving from the middle to the end of the 18th century, the Scottish-Irish people of what is now Northern Ireland were the largest group of non-English immigrants before the Revolution; English-contracted servants were largely the largest group of immigrants before the Revolution.

name: north_carolina
sentence: During the American Revolutionary War, British Scots and the Eastern Highlands of North Carolina tended to remain loyal to the British Crown, due to long-standing commercial and personal ties with Britain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: English, Welsh, Scottish, and German settlers in western North Carolina favoured Britain's American independence.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most English settlers had arrived as servants under contract, committing themselves as workers for a specified period of time to pay for their passage.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early years, the line between contractual servants and African slaves or workers was fluid.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Some Africans had been allowed to earn their freedom before slavery became a permanent status.

sentence: Most of the free-coloured families formed in North Carolina before the Revolution were descended from unions or marriages between free white women and men who were slaves or free of Africans or Afro-Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: As mothers were free, their children were born free.

sentence: Many had emigrated or were descendants of migrants from colonial Virginia.

sentence: While the flow of contract workers to the colony decreased with the improvement of economic conditions in Britain, planters imported more slaves, and the legal boundaries of the state between the status of free and slave were tightened, which effectively hardened the latter in racial caste.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The growth and prosperity of the economy was based on slave labour, primarily devoted to tobacco production.

name: north_carolina
sentence: On April 12, 1776, the colony became the first to ask its delegates to the Continental Congress to vote for the independence of the British Crown through the Halifax Resolves, adopted by the North Carolina Provincial Congress.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A major American victory in the war took place at King's Mountain along the border between North Carolina and South Carolina; on October 7, 1780, a force of 1,000 mountain men from western North Carolina (including what is now the state of Tennessee) and southwestern Virginia submerged a force of some 1,000 British soldiers led by Major Patrick Ferguson.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Most of the soldiers fighting for the British side in this battle were Carolinians who had remained loyal to the Crown (they were called "Historys" or Loyalists).

sentence: The American victory at Kings Mountain gave the advantage to the settlers who promoted American independence, and prevented the British army from recruiting new Tories soldiers.

name: north_carolina

sentence: As the British army moved northward from the victories in Charleston and Camden, South Carolina, the southern division of the continental army and the local militias prepared to meet them.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After General Daniel Morgan's victory over British cavalry commander Banaster Tarleton at the Battle of Cowpens on 17 Jan. 1781, South Commander Nathanael Greene led British Lord Charles Cornwallis through the heart of North Carolina, and away from the latter's supply base in Charleston, South Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This campaign is known as "The Race in Dan" or "The Race for the River".

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Battle of the Cowan Ford, Cornwallis encountered resistance along the banks of the Catawba River at the Cowan Ford on 1 Feb. 1781, in an attempt to engage General Morgan's forces in a tactical withdrawal.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Morgan had moved to the northern part of the state to join the newly recruited forces of General Greene.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Generals Greene and Cornwallis finally met at the Guilford Courthouse at Greensboro today, March 15, 1781.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Although British troops held the field at the end of the battle, their casualties in the hands of the numerically superior Continental Army were paralysing.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Following this "pyrrhic victory," Cornwallis chose to settle on the Virginia coast to obtain reinforcements, and to allow the Royal Navy to protect its beaten army.

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the collapse of Confederation in 1865, North Carolina, along with the rest of the former Confederate states, was placed under the direct control of the American army and was relieved of its constitutional government and its representation in the United States Congress in what is now called the era of reconstruction.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In order to recover its rights, the state had to make concessions in Washington, one of which ratified the thirteenth amendment.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Although the Fifteenth Amendment was also adopted in the same year, in most cases it remained ineffective for almost a century, not to mention paramilitary groups and their lynching with impunity.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The April 1868 elections following the constitutional convention led to a narrow victory for a Republican-dominated government, with 19 African-Americans holding positions in the North Carolina State Legislative Assembly.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In order to implement the reforms, the new Republican Governor William W. Holden declared martial law on any county that would not comply with the law and order by using the adoption of the Shoffner Act.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A coalition of the Republican Party of Freed Blacks, Northern Tapestries and Local Scalawags controlled the government of the state for three years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: White Conservative Democrats regained control of the state legislature in 1870, partly by Ku Klux Klan, violence and terrorism at the polls, to suppress the black vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Republicans were elected as governor until 1876, when the Red Shirts, a paramilitary organization born in 1874 and allied to the Democratic Party, helped to suppress the black vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: More than 150 black Americans were murdered during electoral violence in 1876.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Post-civil war debt cycles have moved people from subsistence farming to commodity farming.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Meanwhile, the famous Crop-Link system has developed and has been financially difficult on landless whites and blacks, due to large amounts of wear and tear.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Also due to the surge in commodity farming, the free range has been completed.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Before that time, people closed their crops and fed their cattle on the range.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the end of the free range people have now fenced their animals and have their crops in the open air.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Democrats were elected to the legislature and to the office of governor, but the populists attracted the discontented voters with them.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1896, a populist-republican fusionist coalition, biracial, obtained the position of governor and passed laws that would extend the right to vote to blacks and poor whites.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The democrats regained control of Parliament in 1896 and passed laws imposing Jim Crow and racial segregation of public facilities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Voters in the 2nd district of the North Carolina Congress elected a total of four African-American MPs in the late 19th century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The political tensions were so strong that a small group of white democrats in 1898 planned to take over the leadership of the Wilmington government if their candidates were not elected.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the Wilmington insurgency in 1898, more than 1,500 white men attacked the black newspaper and the neighborhood, killed many men and fled the mayor and the white Republicans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: They set up their own people and elected Alfred M. Waddell as mayor, in the only coup d'état in the history of the United States.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1899, the state legislature adopted a new constitution, with requirements for voting taxes and literacy tests for the registration of voters who deprived most black Americans of the state.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Exclusion from voting has a broad effect: it means that American blacks cannot be used in juries or in any local office.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After a decade of white supremacy, many people have forgotten that North Carolina has never had flowering middle-class blacks.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black citizens had no political voice in the State until after the adoption of the Federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 and the Electoral Rights Act of 1965 to enforce their constitutional rights.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It was not until 1992 that another African American was elected American representative of North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After the reconstruction period, North Carolina became a single-party state, dominated by the Democratic Party.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state has essentially maintained itself with an economy based on tobacco, cotton textiles and commodity farming.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Large cities remained in small numbers.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, an important industrial base emerged in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, in the counties of the Triade du Piedmont, from cotton mills established at the autumn line.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Railways have been built to connect the new industrialised cities.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state was the place where the Wright brothers, near Kitty Hawk, on December 17, 1903, made the first flight heavier than the air, controlled, motorized and successfully sustained.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the first half of the 20th century, many African-Americans left the state to go north for better opportunities in the Great Migration.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Their departure changed the demographic characteristics of many regions.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina was hit hard by the Great Depression, but Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal programs for cotton and tobacco helped farmers a lot.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After World War II, the state economy experienced rapid growth, marked by the growth of cities such as Charlotte, Raleigh and Durham in the Piedmont region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Raleigh, Durham and Chapel Hill form the research triangle, a major domain of universities and advanced scientific and technical research.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the late 1960s, driven in part by the increasingly left-wing inclination of national democrats, the Conservative whites began to vote for national Republican candidates and gradually for more republicans locally.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Greensboro Sit-ins have played a crucial role in the civil rights movement to bring full equality to black Americans.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since the 1970s, North Carolina has experienced a steady increase in population growth.

name: north_carolina
sentence: This growth occurred primarily in metropolitan areas within the Piedmont Crescent, in places such as Charlotte, Raleigh, Greensboro, Winston-Salem and Durham.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Charlotte's metro has experienced strong growth mainly because of its financial, banking and technological industries.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The State of North Carolina, Duke University and the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill helped the Raleigh region (Research Triangle) attract an educated workforce and create more jobs.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 1990s Charlotte had become a major regional and national banking centre.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Tourism has also been a boom for North Carolina's economy, as people flock to the coastal areas of the outer banks and the Appalachians anchored by Asheville.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is bordered by South Carolina to the south, Georgia to the south-west, Tennessee to the west, Virginia to the north, and the Atlantic Ocean to the east.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau places North Carolina in the South Atlantic Division of the South Region.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina consists of three major geographic areas: the Atlantic coastal plain, which occupies the eastern part of the state, the central region of Piedmont and the western mountainous region, which is part of the Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain consists of more specifically defined areas such as the outer shores, a chain of sandy and narrow islands separated from the mainland by sounds or inlets, including the Albemarle Strait and Pamlico Strait, the tidal waters region, the home of the venous flyer, and the inland coastal plain, where long-leaved pines are native.

name: north_carolina
sentence: So many ships have been lost off Cape Hatteras that the area is known as the "Graveyard of the Atlantic"; more than a thousand ships have sank in these waters since the records began in 1526.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The most famous of them is the revenge of the Queen Anne (flagship of the Black Barbe pirate), who failed at Beaufort Inlet in 1718.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain passes to the Piedmont region along the autumn line of the Atlantic coast, the altitude at which the waterfalls appear for the first time on rivers and streams.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont region of central North Carolina is the most populated region of the state, with the six largest cities in the state per population.

name: north_carolina
sentence: It consists of a gently sloping country often broken by low hills or mountain ridges.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Small, isolated and deeply eroded mountain ranges are located in Piedmont, including the Sauratown Mountains, Pilot Mountain, Uwharrie Mountains, Crowder's Mountain, King's Pinnacle Mountains, Brushy Mountains and the South Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Piedmont extends from about 91 metres in the east to about 1,500 feet (460 metres) in the west.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The western section of the State is part of the range of Appalachians.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Among the sub-ranges of the Appalachians located in the state are the Smoky Mountains, Blue Ridge Mountains and Black Mountains.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The black mountains are the highest in the eastern United States and peak at Mount Mitchell at 2684 feet (2,037 m), the highest point east of the Mississippi River.

name: north_carolina
sentence: There are 17 major watersheds in North Carolina.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The five basins west of the Blue Ridge Mountains flow into the Gulf of Mexico, while the remainder flow into the Atlantic Ocean.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of the 17 basins, 11 are from the state of North Carolina, but only four are located entirely within the state border: Cap Peur, Neuse, White Oak and Tar-Pamlico Basin.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Elevation above sea level is the main cause of temperature change throughout the state, the mountainous area being the coolest all year round.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The climate is also influenced by the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf Stream, especially in the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: These influences tend to cause warmer winter temperatures along the coast, where temperatures fall only occasionally under freezing at night.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The coastal plain represents an average of about 2.5 cm of snow or ice per year, and there may be no snow or ice for many years.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The Atlantic Ocean has less influence on the climate of the Piedmont region, which has warmer summers and cooler winters than along the coast, although the average daily maximum is always less than 90°F (32°C) in most locations.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina is experiencing severe weather, both in summer and winter, with the threat of hurricanes, tropical storms, heavy rains and flooding.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The destructive hurricanes that struck North Carolina included Hurricane Fran, Hurricane Florence, Hurricane Floyd, Hurricane Hugo and Hurricane Hazel, which was the strongest storm ever struck in the state as a category 4 in 1954.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Hurricane Isabel is the most destructive in the 21st century.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina has an average of less than 20 tornadoes per year, many of which are produced by hurricanes or tropical storms along the coastal plain.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Storm tornadoes are a risk, particularly in the eastern part of the State.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Western Piedmont is often protected by mountains, which tend to break storms while trying to cross; storms will often reshape more eastward.

name: north_carolina
sentence: A phenomenon known as a "cold-air dam" often occurs in the northwestern part of the state, which may weaken storms, but may also lead to significant ice events in winter.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In April 2011, the worst tornado in North Carolina history took place.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Thirty confirmed tornadoes fell, mainly in eastern Piedmont and Sandhills, killing at least 24 people.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In September 2019, Hurricane Dorian hit the area.

sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Carolina population was 10,488,084 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 9.99% since the 2010 census.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Of those residing in North Carolina, 58.5% were born there; 33.1% were born in another state; 1.0% were born in Puerto Rico, in the U.S. islands, or were born abroad by U.S. parents; and 7.4% were born abroad.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since colonial times, the inhabitants of North Carolina have always been very Protestant – first Anglicans, then Baptists and Methodists.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 1845, the Baptists divided into regional associations in the North and the South, on the issue of slavery.

name: north_carolina
sentence: At the end of the 19th century, North Carolina's largest Protestant denomination was a Baptist.

name: north_carolina
sentence: After emancipation, black Baptists quickly established their own independent congregations in North Carolina and other southern states because they wanted to be free from white surveillance.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Black Baptists have developed their own state and national associations such as the National Baptist Convention USA, Inc.

name: north_carolina
sentence: While the Baptists have maintained the majority Protestant denomination in this part of the country (known as the Biblical Belt), a wide variety of religions are practised by other residents of the state, including Judaism, Islam, Bahá'í, Buddhism and Hinduism.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2010, the Southern Baptist Convention was the largest denomination, with 4,241 churches and 1,513 000 members.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The third was the Roman Catholic Church, with 428 000 members in 190 parishes.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The fourth largest was the Presbyterian Church (USA), with 186,000 members and 710 congregations; this designation was brought by Scottish-Irish immigrants who established the hinterland in colonial times.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The state also has a special history with the Moravian Church, as the settlers of this faith (mainly of German origin) settled in the Winston-Salem region in the 18th and 19th centuries.

sentence: Residents of North Carolina have lower life expectancy than the national average of life expectancy.

name: north_carolina
sentence: North Carolina's transportation systems include air, water, road, rail and public transportation, including the long distance railway via Amtrak and the light rail in Charlotte.

sentence: The government of North Carolina is divided into three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

sentence: North Carolina has 13 seats in the U.S. House of Representatives and two seats in the U.S. Senate.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The loyalties of the North Carolina party have undergone a series of important changes in recent years: while the mid-term elections of 2010 saw the voters of Tar Heel elect for the first time in more than a century a two-camera republican majority, North Carolina has also become a turning state of the South in presidential races.

name: north_carolina
sentence: Since southern democrat Jimmy Carter's comfortable victory in the state in 1976, the state had always leaned Republican in the presidential elections until democrat Barack Obama won the state closely in 2008.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the 1990s, democrat Bill Clinton reached a point of winning the state in 1992 and lost the state only narrowly in 1996.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In the early 2000s, Republican George W. Bush easily won the state of more than 12 points.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2008, demographic changes, population growth and increased liberalization in densely populated areas such as the Research Triangle, Charlotte, Greensboro, Winston-Salem, Fayetteville and Asheville brought Barack Obama to victory in North Carolina, the first democrat to win the state since 1976.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, North Carolina was once again considered a competitive swing state, with Democrats holding even their 2012 National Democratic Convention in Charlotte.

name: north_carolina
sentence: However, Republican Mitt Romney finally won a two-point victory in North Carolina, the only swing state in 2012 Obama lost, and one of only two states (with Indiana) to return from Obama in 2008 to the GOP in 2012.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2012, the state elected a Republican Governor (Pat McCrory) and a Lieutenant Governor (Dan Forest) for the first time in over two decades, while giving Republicans veto-proof majorities to the House of State Representatives and the State Senator.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The North Carolina Republicans won 10 of the 13 seats in 2016, when the Democrats won 47 percent of the vote in the state as a whole.

name: north_carolina
sentence: In 2018 the Republicans took nine, with an undecided seat, even though the Democrats won 48 per cent of the overall vote.

name: north_carolina
sentence: The undecided election in the 9th district of the North Carolina Congress was due to the fact that the State Electoral Council refused in February 2019 to certify the results, after an investigation found evidence of widespread fraud committed by Republican members.

name: north_carolina

sentence: Public primary and secondary schools are supervised by the Department of Public Education in North Carolina.
