name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is a state in the Midwestern United States of America.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It bears the name of the Amerindian tribes Lakota and Dakota Sioux, which make up a large part of the population and historically dominate the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the nineteenth largest in the region, the fourth least populated, and the fourth least populated of the 50 states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its capital is Bismarck and its biggest city is Fargo.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was admitted to the Union on 2 November 1889, together with its neighbouring State, South Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were the 39th and 40th states admitted to the Union.

name: north_dakota
sentence: President Benjamin Harrison changed the state documents before signing them so that no one would know who became a state first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For ease of reference, both states are officially numbered in alphabetical order.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, the natural resources of North Dakota played a major role in its economic performance, including the extraction of oil from the Bakken Formation, which is located under the north-western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This has led to population growth and a reduction in unemployment, resulting in North Dakota having the second lowest unemployment rate in the nation (after Hawaii).

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is home to the highest structure in the Western Hemisphere, the KVLY-TV mast.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located in the U.S. High Midwest region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is located in the middle of the North American continent and borders Canada to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The geographic centre of North America is close to the city of Center.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck is the capital of North Dakota, and Fargo is the largest city.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soils are the most precious resource in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the basis of the state's great agricultural wealth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota also has enormous mineral resources.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These mineral resources include billions of tonnes of lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has large oil reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Oil was discovered in the state in 1951 and rapidly became one of the most valuable mineral resources in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 2000s, the emergence of hydraulic fracturing technologies enabled mining companies to extract huge amounts of oil from the formation of Bakken shale rocks in the western part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota economy is more based on agriculture than most other states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many North Dakota plants process agricultural products or produce agricultural equipment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many state merchants are also dependent on agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farms and ranches cover almost all North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They stretch from the flat valley of the Red River to the east, through the hilly plains, to the rugged Badlands to the west.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main crop, wheat, is grown in almost every county.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota harvests more than 90 per cent of the country's canola and flaxseed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is also the country's largest producer of barley and sunflower and a leader in the production of beans, honey, lentils, oats, peas and sugar beets.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Few white settlers arrived in the North Dakota region before the 1870s because the railways had not yet entered the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the early 1870s, the North Pacific Railway began crossing Dakota territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Large-scale agriculture also started in the 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Eastern societies and some families have established huge wheat farms covering vast lands in the Red River valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The farms made huge profits as they were called Bonanza Farms.

name: north_dakota
sentence: White settlers, attracted by the success of the bonanza farms, flocked to North Dakota, rapidly increasing the territory's population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1870, there were 2,405 persons in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1890, the population increased to 190,983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has been named for the Sioux people who once lived in the territory.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Sioux are called Dakota or Lakota, meaning allies or friends.

name: north_dakota
sentence: One of the nicknames of North Dakota is the state of the Garden of Peace.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This nickname honours the International Garden of Peace, located on the state border with Manitoba, in Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is also called the state of Flickr because of the numerous ground squirrels (Richardson ground squirrels) that live in the central part of the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is found in the U.S. region known as the Great Plains.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state shares the Northern Red River with Minnesota to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: South Dakota is located to the south, Montana to the west, and the Canadian provinces of Saskatchewan and Manitoba to the north.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is located near the centre of North America, with a stone marker in Rugby, North Dakota, which marks the "Geographic Centre of the North American Continent."

name: north_dakota
sentence: With an area of 70,762 square miles (183,273 km2), of which 178,712 square kilometres are land, North Dakota is the 19th largest state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western half of the state consists of the great hilly plains as well as the northern part of the Badlands, which are west of the Missouri River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The highest point of the state, White Butte at 306 feet (1,069 m), and Theodore Roosevelt National Park are in the Badlands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The region is abundant in fossil fuels, including natural gas, crude oil, and lignite coal.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Missouri River forms Sakakawea Lake, the third largest artificial lake in the United States, behind the Garrison Dam.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The central area of the state is divided into the Drift Prairie and the Missouri Plateau.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The eastern part of the state consists of the flat valley of the Red River, the bottom of glacial lake Agassiz.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its fertile soil, drained by the meander of the Red River that flows north into Lake Winnipeg, supports a large agricultural industry.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lake Devils, the largest natural lake in the state, is also to the east.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most of the state is covered by grasslands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Natural trees are generally found in North Dakota where there is good drainage, such as the ravines and valley near Pembina Gorge and Killdeer Mountains, Turtle Mountains, the hills around Devil Lake, in the dunes of McHenry County in central North Dakota, and along the slopes of the Sheyenne Valley and Sheyenne Delta.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This diverse land is home to nearly 2,000 species of plants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has a continental climate with hot summers and cold winters.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Temperature differences are significant due to its remote interior position and being in the centre of the Northern Hemisphere, with distances approximately equal to the North Pole and the equator.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Amerindian peoples lived in what is today North Dakota for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The known tribes included the Mandan people (ca. 11th century), while the first Hidatsa group arrived a few hundred years later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Both gathered in villages on tributaries of the Missouri River in what was to become the western centre of North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Crow Indians travelled to the western plains to visit and trade with the related Hidatas after the split between them, probably in the 17th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Later came the divisions of the Dakota people – Lakota, Santee, and Yanktonai.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Crees of Assiniboine and Plains travelled south to the Indians of the village, either for trade or for war.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shoshone Indians in present-day Wyoming and Montana may have carried out attacks on Indian enemies as far east as Missouri.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A group of Cheyennes lived in a village of houses of land at the lower Sheyenne River (site of Biesterfeldt) for decades in the 18th century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: As a result of attacks by Cris, Assiniboines and Chippewas armed with firearms, they left the area around 1780 and crossed Missouri some time later.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A band of the few Sotaio Indians lived east of the Missouri River and met uprooted Cheyennes before the end of the century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They quickly followed the Cheyennes across Missouri and lived among them south of the Cannonball River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Finally, the Cheyennes and the Sutaio became a tribe and became hunters of bison mounted with ranges primarily outside North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Before the middle of the 19th century, Arikara entered the future state of the south and joined Mandan and Hidatsa.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Over time, many Indians entered into treaties with the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many treaties define the territory of a given tribe (see map).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The first European to join the region was the French-Canadian merchant Pierre Gaultier, Sieur de La Vérendrye, who led an exploration and trade team in the villages of Mandan in 1738.

name: north_dakota
sentence: From 1762 to 1802, the area was part of the Spanish Louisiana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: European Americans did not settle in the Dakota territory until the end of the 19th century, when railways opened the area.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advantage of land concessions, they vigorously traded their property, exalting the region as the ideal for agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: On February 22, 1889, Congress passed an omnibus bill for North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington, entitled the enabling act of 1889, under the administration of President Grover Cleveland.

name: north_dakota
sentence: His successor, Benjamin Harrison, signed the proclamations of official admission of North Dakota and South Dakota to the Union on November 2, 1889.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The rivalry between the two new states presented a dilemma which must first be admitted to exist.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Harrison ordered Secretary of State James G. Blaine to mix the papers and obscure him that he signed first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The current order has not been recorded, so no one knows which Dakotas were admitted first.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, since North Dakota appears alphabetically in front of South Dakota, its proclamation was first published in the At Large Statutes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The carelessness among wheat producers, particularly among Norwegian immigrants, led to a populist political movement centered in the non-partisan League ("NPL") at the time of the First World War.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The NPL presented candidates on the Republican ticket (but merged into the Democratic Party after World War II).

name: north_dakota
sentence: She tried to isolate North Dakota from the power of banks and out-of-state corporations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition to founding the Bank of North Dakota and North Dakota Mill and Elevator (both still exist), NPL established a state-owned railway line (later sold to Soo Line Railroad).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Anti-society laws virtually prohibited a corporation or bank from owning title to land delimited as agricultural land.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These laws, still in force today, after being confirmed by the state and federal courts, make it almost impossible to seize agricultural land, since even after the seizure, the title to property cannot be held by a bank or a mortgage company.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, the North Dakota Bank, with powers similar to those of a federal reserve branch bank, exercised its power to limit the issuance of sub-prime mortgages and their guarantee in the form of derivative instruments, thus preventing the collapse of domestic housing prices following the 2008 financial crisis.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The original Capitol of the State of North Dakota at Bismarck burned on the ground on December 28, 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It has been replaced by an art deco skyscraper with limestone facets that still stands today.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A series of federal investment and construction projects began in the 1950s, including the Garrison Dam and the Minot and Grand Forks Air Force Bases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Western North Dakota experienced an increase in oil exploration in the late 1970s and early 1980s, as higher oil prices made development profitable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This boom came to an end after the fall in oil prices.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In recent years, the State has recorded unemployment rates below the national average and has increased employment and population growth.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of the growth was based on the development of Bakken's oil fields in the western part of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Estimates of the remaining amount of oil in the region vary, some of which are estimated to be over 100 years.

name: north_dakota
sentence: For decades, the annual North Dakota murder rate and violent crime rate were consistently lowest in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, in recent years, although still below the national average, crime has risen sharply.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2016, the violent crime rate was three times higher than in 2004, with the increase occurring mostly in the late 2000s, coinciding with the oil boom era.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This happened at a time when the national rate of violent crime decreased slightly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Workers in the oil boom cities were blamed for much of the increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that the North Dakota population was 762,062 as of 1 July 2019, an increase of 13.30 per cent over the 2010 U.S. Census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This makes North Dakota the U.S. state with the highest percentage of population growth since 2011.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the fourth least populous state in the country; only Alaska, Vermont and Wyoming have fewer residents.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The population of North Dakota increased from less than 2,000 in 1870 to nearly 680,000 in 1930.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Growth then slowed and the population fluctuated slightly over the past seven decades, reaching 617,761 at the 1970 census, of which 642,200 at the 2000 census.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the exception of Amerindians, the North Dakota population has a lower percentage of minorities than the nation as a whole.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2011, 20.7 per cent of the North Dakota population under the age of 1 were minorities.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Population Centre is located in Wells County, near Sykeston.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Note: Births in the table do not add up, because Hispanics are counted both by ethnicity and race, resulting in a higher overall number.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the second half of the 19th century and until the early 20th century, North Dakota, with most of the Midwest, experienced a massive influx of newcomers from the eastern United States and immigrants from Europe.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota was a popular destination known for immigrant farmers and workers in general and their families, mainly Norway, Iceland, Sweden, Germany and the United Kingdom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Much of this colony was on the western side of the Red River Valley, as seen in South Dakota and parallel in Minnesota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This area is well known for its fertile lands.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of World War I, it was one of North America's richest agricultural regions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: But a period of stronger rain ended, and many migrants failed in arid conditions.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many family plots were too small to grow successfully.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between the 1930s and the end of the 20th century, the North Dakota population gradually declined, interrupted by a few brief increases.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Young adults with a university degree are particularly likely to leave the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With the advance of the process of mechanization of agricultural practices and the environmental conditions requiring more important land for successful agriculture, subsistence farming has proved too risky for families.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many people have moved to urban areas to find employment.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since the end of the 20th century, one of the main causes of migration from North Dakota has been the lack of skilled employment for college graduates.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The expansion of economic development programmes had been encouraged to create skilled and high-tech jobs, but the effectiveness of those programmes had been discussed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the first decade of the 21st century, the population increased largely as a result of employment in the oil industry related to the development of tight oil fields (shale oil).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Elsewhere, the Amerindian population has grown, with some reserves attracting people from urban areas.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Immigration Policy

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is one of the first places to resettle refugees proportionately.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the U.S. Office of Refugee Resettlement, in 2013-2014, "more than 68 refugees" per 100,000 North Dakota were settled in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During fiscal year 2014, 582 refugees settled in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo Mayor Mahoney stated that North Dakota's acceptance of the largest per capita refugee population should be celebrated given the benefits they provide to the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2015, Lutheran Social Services in North Dakota, the only state resettlement agency, received $458,090 in federal funding to improve refugee services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Immigration from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 3,323 people, and internal migration resulted in a net loss of 21,110 people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Of the North Dakota population, 69.8 per cent were born in North Dakota, 27.2 per cent were born in a different state, 0.6 per cent were born in Puerto Rico, the United States Islands or abroad to American parents, and 2.4 per cent were born in another country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The distribution by age and sex is close to the national average.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the 2010 Census, the racial and ethnic composition of North Dakota was as follows:

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the mid-19th century, the territory of Dakota was still dominated by the Amerindians.

name: north_dakota
sentence: War and disease reduced their population at the same time as Europeans and Americans moved into the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, most North Dakotas are of North European origin.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2009, the seven largest groups of European descent in North Dakota were:

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the most churches per capita of any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, North Dakota has the highest percentage of church population in any state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to a 2001 survey, 35% of the North Dakota population was Lutheran and 30% Catholic.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other religious groups represented were Methodists (7%), Baptists (6%), God's Assemblies (3%), Presbyterians (1.27%) and Jehovah's Witnesses (1%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Christians with or without denominational affiliations, including other Protestants and the Church of Jesus Christ of the Last-Day Saints (LDS Church), totaled 3%, bringing the total Christian population to 86%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The number of Muslims is estimated at 920 and the number of Jews in the State at 730 in 2000.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Three per cent of respondents answered "no religion" in the survey, and six per cent refused to answer.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The largest bodies of churches by the number of adherents in 2010 were the Roman Catholic Church with 167,349; the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America with 163,209; and the Lutheran Church – Synod of Missouri with 22,003.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2010, 94.86 per cent (584,496) of North Dakotas over 5 years of age spoke English as their main language.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 5.14% (31,684) of the North Dakotas spoke a language other than English.

name: north_dakota
sentence: 1.39% (8,593) speak German, 1.37% (8,432) Spanish and 0.30% (1,847) Norwegian.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Other spoken languages include Serbo-Croatian (0.19%), Chinese and Japanese (0.15%), and Native American and French (0.13%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2000, 2.5% of the population spoke German in addition to English, reflecting the immigration of the early twentieth century.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In the 21st century, North Dakota had an increasing population of Native Americans, accounting for 5.44% of the population in 2010.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the beginning of the 19th century, the territory was dominated by Siwan-speaking peoples whose territory extended west of the Great Lakes region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The word "Dakota" is a Sioux (Lakota/Dakota) meaning "allies" or "friends".

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major historical tribal nations of or around North Dakota are the Lakota and Dakota ("La Grande Nation Sioux" or "Oceti Sakowin", i.e. the seven lights of the council), Blackfoot, Cheyenne, Chippewa (known as Ojibwe in Canada) and Mandan.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The tribes recognized by the federal government have Indian reserves in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Social gatherings known as "powwows" (or wacipis in Lakota/Dakota) continue to be an important part of Native American culture and are held regularly throughout the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Throughout the history of the Amerindians, powwows were held, usually in the spring, to rejoice at the beginning of the new life and the end of the winter cold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These events brought together Amerindian tribes to sing and dance, and allowed them to meet and make new friends and acquaintances.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many pow-wows also had religious significance for some tribes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Today, Powwows are still part of the Native culture and are frequented by both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, the United Tribes International Powwow, which was held monthly in September in the capital of Bismarck, is one of the largest powwows in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A pow wow is an opportunity for Amerindian parades and dancers in regalia, with many styles of dance presented.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is traditional for male dancers to wear regalia decorated with pearls, feathers and eagle feathers; male grass dancers wear coloured fringes, and fancy male dancers wear bright coloured feathers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The dancers dance much more subtly than the male dancers.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fantasy dancers wear fabrics, beaded moccasins and jewellery, while the jingle dancer wears a dress made of metal cones.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Intertribal dances during the pow-wow allow everyone (even the spectators) to participate in the dance.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Around 1870, many European immigrants from Norway settled in the northeast corner of North Dakota, especially near the Red River.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Islanders have also arrived from Canada.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Pembina was a town of many Norwegians when it was founded

name: north_dakota
sentence: They started Lutheran churches and schools, far exceeding the number of other denominations in the region.

name: north_dakota
sentence: This group has unique foods like lefse and lutefisk.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The continent's largest Scandinavian event, Norsk Høstfest, is celebrated every September in Minot's North Dakota State Fair Center, a local attraction featuring art, architecture and cultural artifacts from the five Nordic countries.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Icelandic National Park in Pembina County and an annual Icelandic festival reflect the immigrants from that country, who also descended from Scandinavia.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The folk customs of the Old World have persisted for decades in North Dakota, with the renaissance of weaving techniques, silver craftsmanship and wooden sculpture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Traditional turf roof houses are exposed in parks

name: north_dakota
sentence: A staves is a landmark in Minot.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Norwegian Americans account for almost one-third or 32.3% of the total Minot population and 30.8% of the total North Dakota population.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The ethnic Germans who had settled in Russia for several generations since the reign of Catherine the Great became dissatisfied in the nineteenth century because of economic problems and the revocation of religious freedoms for Mennonites and Hutterites, in particular the revocation of the exemption from military service in 1871.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Most mennonites and hutterites migrated to America in the late 1870s.

name: north_dakota
sentence: By 1900, about 100,000 people had immigrated to the United States, mainly in North Dakota, South Dakota, Kansas and Nebraska.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The south-central North Dakota is known as the German-Russian triangle.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1910, approximately 60,000 Russian-born Germans lived in Central North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These people were Lutherans, Mennonites, Hutterites and Roman Catholics who had kept most of their German customs from the time when their ancestors immigrated to Russia.

name: north_dakota
sentence: They were involved in agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Traditional markers of iron cemetery graves are a famous form of art practiced by ethnic Germans.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The major museums and fine arts venues in North Dakota include the Chester Fritz Auditorium, the Empire Arts Center, Fargo Theatre, the North Dakota Museum of Art, and the Plains Art Museum.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Bismarck-Mandan Symphony Orchestra, the Fargo-Moorhead Symphony Orchestra, the Greater Grand Forks Symphony Orchestra, the Minot Symphony Orchestra and the Great Plains Harmony Chorus are full-time professional and semi-professional music ensembles that offer concerts and educational programs to the community.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota musicians of many genres include blues guitarist Jonny Lang, country singer Lynn Anderson, jazz and traditional pop singer Peggy Lee, Big Band leader Lawrence Welk, and pop singer Bobby Vee.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state also houses Indie rock June Panic (from Fargo, signed by Secretly Canadian).

name: north_dakota
sentence: Ed Schultz was known throughout the country until his death in July 2018 as a progressive radio talk show host, The Ed Schultz Show, and The Ed Show on MSNBC.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Shadoe Stevens welcomed the American Top 40 from 1988 to 1995.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Josh Duhamel is an Emmy Award-winning actor known for his roles in All My Children and Las Vegas.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Nicole Linkletter and CariDee English won the American Next Top Model Cycles 5 and 7 respectively.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Kellan Lutz has appeared in films such as Stick It, Accepted, Prom Night and Twilight.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Bismarck was the headquarters of the NBA Development League's Wizards Dakota and currently hosts the Bucks Bismarcks of the Indoor Football League.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has two NCAA Division I teams, the North Dakota Combat Hawks and North Dakota State Bison, and two Division II teams, the Mary Marauders and the Beavers of Minot State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Fargo hosts the USHL Ice Hockey Team, the Fargo Force.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Secondary Activities Association has more than 25,000 participants.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Outdoor activities like hunting and fishing are hobbies for many North Dakotas.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Ice fishing, skiing and snowmobiling are also popular during the winter months.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Residents of North Dakota can own or visit a cabin along a lake.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Popular sport fish include gilded yellow, perch and northern pike.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The western terminus of the North Country National Stage Trail is located on Sakakawea Lake, where it stops on the Lewis and Clark Trail.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Agriculture is the largest industry in North Dakota, although oil, food processing, and technology are also important industries.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Its growth rate is around 4.1%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to the Office of Economic Analysis, the North Dakota economy had a gross domestic product of $55.180 billion in the second quarter of 2018.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Per capita income was $34,256, measured between 2013 and 2017 by the United States Department of Commerce.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The median household income over three years in 2013–2017 was $61,285.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to Gallup data, North Dakota led the U.S. in 2013 in job creation and has done so since 2009.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State has a job creation index of 40, almost 10 points ahead of its closest competitors.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has added 56,600 private sector jobs since 2011, representing an annual growth rate of 7.32%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: According to statistics released by the Office of Economic Analysis on March 25, 2014, personal income in North Dakota increased by 7.6 per cent in 2013 to $41.3 billion.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The State recorded the highest growth in personal income of all States for the sixth time since 2007.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The growth of personal income in North Dakota is linked to a variety of private sectors such as agriculture, energy development and construction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Just over 21% of North Dakota's 2013 gross domestic product (GDP) of $49.77 billion comes from natural resources and mining.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the only state to have a state bank, the North Dakota Bank in Bismarck, and a state flour mill, the North Dakota plant and the elevator in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: These were established by the NPL prior to World War II.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since 2012, Fargo has been home to Microsoft's second-largest campus with 1,700 employees, and Amazon.com employs several hundred people in Grand Forks.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In December 2019, the state unemployment rate was among the lowest in the nation at 2.4%.

name: north_dakota
sentence: It has not reached 5 % since 1987.

name: north_dakota
sentence: At the end of 2010, per capita government income ranked 17th in the nation, the largest increase in any state in a decade compared to 38th.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The reduction in the unemployment rate and the growth in per capita income are due to the rise in oil in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Due to the combination of oil-related development and investment in the technology and service industries, North Dakota has had a budgetary surplus every year since the market collapse in 2008.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Since 1976, the highest unemployment rate in North Dakota has been only 6.2% in 1983.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Each US state, with the exception of neighbouring South Dakota, experienced a higher unemployment rate during this period.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The earliest industries in North Dakota are the fur trade and agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Although less than 10 per cent of the population is employed in the agricultural sector, it remains an important part of the state economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: With industrial agriculture, it ranks 9th for the value of crops and 18th for the total value of agricultural products sold.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Larger farms produce the most crops.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The proportion of the state population employed in agriculture is relatively high: in 2008, only 2 to 3 per cent of the U.S. population was directly employed in agriculture.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has about 90% of its land area on farms with 27.5 million acres (111,000 km2) of cultivated land, the third largest amount of land in the country.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Between 2002 and 2007, total cropland increased by about one million acres (4,000 km2); North Dakota was the only state to have experienced an increase.

name: north_dakota
sentence: During the same period, 1,800,000 acres (7,300 km2) were converted to monoculture of soybeans and corn, the largest change in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Farmers are concerned about too many monocultures, as they make the economy threatened by insect or crop diseases that affect an important crop.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, this development has adversely affected wildlife and bird habitats, as well as the ecosystem's balance.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is the largest producer in the United States of many grain grains, including barley (36% of U.S. crops), durum (58%), hard red spring wheat (48%), oats (17%) and combined wheat of all types (15%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: It is the second producer of buckwheat (20%).

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2007, maize became the largest crop produced by the government, although it accounted for only 2% of total US production.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The corn belt extends to North Dakota, but is more on the edge of the area than in its centre.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Corn yields are high in the southeastern part of the State and lower in other parts of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is the largest producer of many oilseeds, including 92% of canola cultivation in the United States, 94% of flax seeds, 53% of sunflower seeds, 18% of safflower seeds and 62% of mustard seeds.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Canola is suitable for cold winters and matures rapidly.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The processing of canola for oil production produces canola flour as a by-product.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The by-product is a high protein animal feed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybean is also an increasing crop, with an additional 400,000 acres (1,600 km2) planted between 2002 and 2007.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans are an important crop in the eastern part of the State, and cultivation is common in the south-eastern part of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybeans were not cultivated at all in North Dakota in the 1940s, but cultivation has become particularly common since 1998.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In North Dakota, soybeans must mature rapidly due to the relatively short growing season.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Soybean are grown for livestock feed.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is the second largest producer of sugar beet grown primarily in the Red River valley.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is also the largest producer of honey, peas and dried edible beans, lentils and the third largest producer of potatoes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota's main agricultural products (according to USDA from 2011)

name: north_dakota
sentence: The energy industry is an important contributor to the economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has coal and petroleum reserves.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The shale gas is also produced.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Lignite coal reserves in western North Dakota are used to generate approximately 90% of the electricity consumed, and electricity is also exported to neighbouring states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has the second largest lignite coal production in the United States.

name: north_dakota
sentence: However, lignite coal is the coal of lower quality.

name: north_dakota
sentence: There are increasingly high-quality coal reserves (anthracite, bituminous coal and sub-bituminous coal) in other U.S. states.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The oil was discovered near Tioga in 1951, generating 53 million barrels (8,400,000 m3) of oil per year in 1984.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Recoverable oil reserves have grown dramatically in recent times.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Bakken Formation's oil reserves may contain up to 400 billion barrels (6.4×1010 m3) of oil, 25 times larger than the reserves of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A report published in April 2008 by the US Geological Survey estimates that oil recoverable by the current technology in Bakken's formation is two orders of magnitude less, from the order of 3 billion barrels (480×10^6 m3) to 4.3 billion barrels (680×10^6 m3), with an average of 3.65 billion barrels (580×10^6 m3).

name: north_dakota
sentence: The northwestern portion of the state is the centre of the North Dakota oil boom.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The communities of Williston, Tioga, Stanley, and Minot-Burlington are experiencing rapid growth that is straining housing and local services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2012, the state is the second largest oil producer in the United States, with an average of 575,490 barrels per day.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The Great Plains region, which includes the State of North Dakota, has been called "Saudi Arabia's Wind Energy".

name: north_dakota
sentence: Wind energy development in North Dakota has been cost-effective because the state has large rural areas and the wind speed is rarely less than 10 mph.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota is considered the least visited state, in part because it does not have a large tourist attraction.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Nevertheless, tourism is the third largest business line in North Dakota, contributing more than $3 billion annually to the government economy.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Outdoor attractions such as the 144-mile Maah Daah Hey Trail and activities like fishing and hunting attract visitors.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The state is known for the Lewis & Clark Trail and is the Winter Camp of the Discovery Corps.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Popular visitor areas include Theodore Roosevelt National Park in the western part of the State.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The park often exceeds 475,000 visitors annually.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Regular events in the state that attract tourists include Norsk Høstfest in Minot, designated as the largest Scandinavian festival in North America, the Medora Musical and the North Dakota State Fair.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The government also receives a large number of visitors from the neighbouring Canadian provinces of Manitoba and Saskatchewan, particularly when the exchange rate is favourable.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many international tourists also come to visit the Oscar-Zero missile alert centre.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota has six Level II Trauma Treatment Centres, 44 hospitals, 52 rural clinics and 80 nursing homes.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main supplier networks include Sanford, St. Alexius, Trinity and Altru.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Blue Cross Blue Shield of North Dakota is the government's largest medical insurer.

name: north_dakota
sentence: North Dakota expanded Medicaid in 2014, and its health insurance exchange is the federal website, HealthCare.gov.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Act requires pharmacies, other than hospital clinics and pre-existing stores, to be owned primarily by pharmacists.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Electors rejected a proposal to amend the Act in 2014.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The North Dakota Department of Emergency Services provides 24 hours a day, 7 days a week communication and coordination to more than 50 organizations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In addition, "it administers the federal disaster recovery programs and the Homeland Security Grants Program."

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 2011, the Department selected Geo-Comm, Inc. "for the National Seamless Core Card Project", which will facilitate "identification of 9–1–1 calling locations" and the routing of emergency calls to locations.

name: north_dakota
sentence: In 1993, the State adopted the Burkle on the numbering system of rural roads and buildings to assist in the provision of emergency services.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Transportation to North Dakota is overseen by the Department of Transportation in North Dakota.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main interstate highways are Interstate 29 and Interstate 94, with I-29 and I-94 meeting in Fargo, with I-29 facing north to south along the eastern boundary of the State, and I-94 bisecting the state from east to west between Minnesota and Montana.

name: north_dakota
sentence: A unique feature of the North Dakota interstate highway network is almost entirely paved with concrete, not black roof, due to the extreme climatic conditions it faces.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The BNSF and the Canadian Pacific Railway operate the largest railway networks in the state.

name: north_dakota
sentence: Many branches previously used by the BNSF and the Canadian Pacific Railway are now operated by the Dakota, Missouri and Western Railways, as well as the Red River Valley and the Western Railway.

name: north_dakota
sentence: The main airports in North Dakota are Hector International Airport (FAR) in Fargo, Grand Forks International Airport (GFK), Bismarck Municipal Airport (BIS), Minot International Airport (MOT) and Williston Basin International Airport (XWA) in Williston.

name: north_dakota

name: north_dakota
sentence: As with the U.S. federal government, political power in the state government of North Dakota is divided into three branches: executive, legislative and judicial.

name: north_dakota

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is a state in the east-central Midwest of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Of the fifty states, it is the 34th largest by region, and with a population of nearly 11.7 million, is the seventh most populous and the tenth most densely populated.

name: ohio
sentence: The capital and largest city of the state is Columbus, with the metropolitan area of Columbus, Grand Cincinnati and Grand Cleveland being the largest metropolitan areas.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bordered by Lake Erie in the north, Pennsylvania in the east, West Virginia in the southeast, Kentucky in the southwest, Indiana in the west, and Michigan in the northwest.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is historically known as "Buckeye State" after its Ohio buckeyes, and Ohions are also known as "Buckeyes".

name: ohio
sentence: The state derives its name from the Ohio River, whose name comes in turn from the word Senatorca ohi=yo', meaning "good river," "great river," or "great river."

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was born from the lands west of Appalachia that were disputed from the colonial era through the Indian wars of the late 18th century.

name: ohio
sentence: It was separated from the resulting Northwest Territory, which was the first border of the new United States, and became the 17th State admitted to the Union on March 1, 1803, and the first under the North-West Ordinance.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was the first free post-colonial state admitted to union, and became one of the first and most influential industrial power stations in the 20th century; although it has evolved to a more information- and service-oriented economy in the 21st century, Ohio remains an industrial state, ranking seventh in GDP in 2019, with the third largest manufacturing sector and second largest automotive production.

name: ohio
sentence: The government of Ohio is composed of the executive, led by the Governor, the legislature, composed of the Bicameral General Assembly of Ohio, and the judiciary, led by the Supreme Court of the State.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio holds 16 seats in the House of Representatives of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: The state is known for its status as both a pivotal state and a gazebo in national elections.

name: ohio
sentence: Eight presidents from the United States came from Ohio, the most from any state, which led him to receive the moniker "Mother of Presidents".

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's geographic location has proven to be an asset for economic growth and expansion.

name: ohio
sentence: Because Ohio connects the Northeast to the Midwest, many goods and business traffic cross its borders along its well-developed roads.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has the country's 10th largest road network and is less than a day's drive from 50 per cent of the North American population and 70 per cent of North America's manufacturing capacity.

name: ohio
sentence: To the north, Lake Erie gives Ohio 312 miles (502 km) of coastline, allowing for many cargo ports.

name: ohio
sentence: The southern Ohio border is defined by the Ohio River (the boundary being at the lower limit of 1792 on the north side of the river), and much of the northern boundary is defined by Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's neighbours are Pennsylvania to the east, Michigan to the northwest, Lake Erie to the north, Indiana to the west, Kentucky to the south, and Western Virginia to the southeast.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio's boundaries were defined in the enabling legislation of 1802 as follows:

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio is bounded by the Ohio River, but most of the river itself belongs to Kentucky and West Virginia.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1980, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that, based on the wording of Virginia's cessation of territory (which at the time included what is now Kentucky and West Virginia), the Ohio-Kentucky border (and consequently West Virginia) is the low north mark of the river as it existed in 1792.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio has only this portion of the river between the 1792 low water mark and the current high water mark.

name: ohio
sentence: The boundary with Michigan also changed, following the Toledo War, to a slightly northeasterly angle to the north shore of the mouth of the Maumee River.

name: ohio
sentence: Much of Ohio has glacial till plains, with an exceptionally flat area in the northwest known as Great Black Swamp.

name: ohio
sentence: This glaciated area in the north-west and central part of the state is bordered first to the east and south-east by a belt known as the glaciated Allegheny plateau and then by another belt known as the unglaciated Allegheny plateau.

name: ohio
sentence: Most of Ohio is of low terrain, but the unglazed Allegheny plateau has rugged hills and forests.

name: ohio
sentence: The rugged southeastern quadrant of Ohio, which extends into an arc-shaped arc along the Ohio River, from the Panhandle of Western Virginia to the periphery of Cincinnati, forms a distinct socio-economic unit.

name: ohio
sentence: Geologically similar to parts of West Virginia and southwestern Pennsylvania, mining in that area, dependence on small pockets of former manufacturing establishments, and the distinctive regional dialect put this section out of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1965, the United States Congress passed the Appalachian Regional Development Act, an attempt to "remediate the persistent poverty and growing economic desperation of the Appalachian region".

name: ohio
sentence: This Act defines 29 Ohio counties as part of Appalachia.

name: ohio
sentence: While 1/3 of Ohio's land mass is part of the federal government-defined area of Appalaches, only 12.8% of Ohio's people live there (1.476 million people).

name: ohio
sentence: The main rivers of the state include the Cuyahoga River, the Great Miami River, the Maumee River, the Muskingum River and the Scioto River.

name: ohio
sentence: Rivers in the northern part of the state flow into the northern Atlantic Ocean via Lake Erie and the St. Lawrence River, and rivers in the southern part of the state flow through the Ohio River and the Mississippi River into the Gulf of Mexico.

name: ohio
sentence: The worst weather disaster in Ohio's history occurred along the Great Miami River in 1913.

name: ohio
sentence: Known as the Dayton Great Flood, the entire Miami River watershed has flooded, including Dayton's downtown business district.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result, the Miami Conservancy District was established as the first major floodplain engineering project in Ohio and the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: Great Lake St. Marys, in the western central part of the state, was built as a water supply for canals at the time of canal construction from 1820 to 1850.

name: ohio
sentence: For many years, this body of water, more than 52 km2, was the largest artificial lake in the world.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio canal projects were not the economic fiasco that similar efforts were being made in other states.

name: ohio
sentence: Some cities, such as Dayton, owe their industrial emergence to their location on the canals, and until 1910, the inland canals carried a large portion of the state's bulk cargo.

name: ohio
sentence: The Ohio climate is a humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa/Dfb climate classification) in most of the state, except in the extreme southern counties of the Ohio Bluegrass region, which are located on the northern periphery of the subtropical humid climate (Cfa) and the U.S. Upland South region.

name: ohio
sentence: Summers are generally warm and humid throughout the state, while winters usually vary from cold to cold.

name: ohio
sentence: Precipitation in Ohio is moderate throughout the year.

name: ohio
sentence: Violent weather is not uncommon in the state, although there are generally fewer reports of tornadoes in Ohio than in states in what is known as the Tornado Alley.

name: ohio
sentence: Lake-effect snowstorms are also not uncommon on the southeast shore of Lake Erie, which is located in an area designated as the snow belt.

name: ohio
sentence: Although mostly not in a subtropical climate, warmer-climatic flora and fauna reach Ohio well.

name: ohio
sentence: For example, some trees whose range is further south, such as Blackjack Oak, Quercus marilandica, are located at the northern tip of Ohio, just north of the Ohio River.

name: ohio
sentence: Also referring to this climate transition from subtropical to continental climate, several plants such as southern magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora), Albizia julibrissin (mimosa), Crape Myrtle and even occasionally Needle Palm are robust landscaping materials regularly used as street, yard and garden plantations in the Ohio Bluegrass area; but these same plants will simply not thrive in many of the rest of the state.

name: ohio
sentence: This interesting change can be observed when traveling across Ohio on Interstate 75 from Cincinnati to Toledo; the traveller observing this diverse state can even catch a glimpse of Cincinnati's common lizard, one of the few examples of permanent "subtropical" wildlife in Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the floods that resulted in severely damaged roads, Governor Mike DeWine declared a state of emergency in 37 Ohio counties in 2019.

name: ohio
sentence: The highest recorded temperature was 113°F (45°C) near Gallipolis on July 21, 1934.

name: ohio
sentence: The lowest recorded temperature was −39°F (−39°C) at Milligan on 10 February 1899 during the Great Blizzard of 1899.

name: ohio
sentence: Although few individuals have registered as being visible to the average resident, more than 200 earthquakes with a magnitude of 2.0 or more have occurred in Ohio since 1776.

name: ohio
sentence: The seismic zone of western Ohio and part of the seismic zone of the southern Great Lakes are located in the state, and there are numerous faults below the surface.

name: ohio
sentence: The most important known earthquake in Ohio's history was the earthquake in Anna, Shelby County, on March 9, 1937.

name: ohio
sentence: It was centred in western Ohio, had a magnitude of 5.4, and was VIII-intensity.

name: ohio
sentence: Other major earthquakes in Ohio include: one of magnitude 4.8 near Lima on September 19, 1884; the other of magnitude 4.2 near Portsmouth on May 17, 1901; and one of 5.0 in LeRoy Township in Lake County on January 31, 1986, which continued to trigger 13 replicas of magnitude 0.5 to 2.4 for two months.

name: ohio
sentence: Significant earthquakes in Ohio in the 21st century included an earthquake on December 31, 2011, about 4 kilometres (2.5 mi) northwest of Youngstown, and an earthquake on June 10, 2019, about 5 kilometres (3.1 mi) northwest of Eastlake under Lake Erie.

name: ohio
sentence: Columbus is the capital of Ohio, located near the geographic center of the state and well known for Ohio State University.

name: ohio

sentence: Lima and Toledo are the main cities in Northwestern Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Northwestern Ohio is known for its glass industry and is home to Owens Corning and Owens-Illinois, two Fortune 500 companies.

name: ohio
sentence: Dayton and Springfield are located in the Miami Valley, home to Dayton University, Dayton Ballet and the large base of the Wright-Patterson Air Force.

name: ohio
sentence: Cincinnati anchors Southwestern Ohio and is the largest economy in the state.

name: ohio
sentence: It houses the University of Miami and the University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati Union Terminal, Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, as well as various companies of Fortune 500 including Procter & Gamble, Kroger, Macy's, Inc. and the fifth third bank.

sentence: Steubenville is the only metropolitan town in Appalachian Ohio, home to Hocking Hills State Park.

sentence: Archaeological evidence of spear points of the Folsom and Clovis types indicates that the Ohio Valley was inhabited by nomads as early as 13,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: These first nomads disappeared from Ohio by 1,000 BC.

name: ohio
sentence: Between 1,000 and 800 BC, Adena's sedentary culture was born.

name: ohio
sentence: The Adenas were able to establish "semi-permanent" villages because they domesticated plants, including sunflowers, and "wheat squash and possibly corn"; with hunting and gathering, this culture supported more established and complex villages.

name: ohio
sentence: The most remarkable remnant of Adena culture is the Grand Snake Mound, located in Adams County, Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Around 100 BC, Adena evolved to the Hopewells, who were also mound builders.

name: ohio
sentence: Their complex and technologically sophisticated works of earth can be found in Marietta, Newark and Circleville.

name: ohio
sentence: They were also a prolific commercial company, with their commercial network covering one third of the continent.

name: ohio
sentence: Hopewell disappeared from Ohio Valley about 600 AD.

name: ohio
sentence: Mississippi culture grew as Hopewell culture declined.

name: ohio
sentence: Many peoples speaking the Siwan of the plains and the east coast claim them as ancestors and say that they lived throughout the Ohio region until about the thirteenth century.

name: ohio
sentence: There were three other contemporary cultures with the Mississippis: the Ancient Fort people, the Whittlesey Focus people and Monongahela culture.

name: ohio
sentence: All three cultures disappeared in the 17th century.

name: ohio
sentence: Their origins are not known.

name: ohio
sentence: The Shawnees may have absorbed the people of Old Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also possible that Monongahela did not hold any land in Ohio during the colonial era.

name: ohio
sentence: The Mississippi culture was close and exchanged much with the people of the Ancient Fort.

name: ohio
sentence: The Indians of the Ohio Valley were greatly affected by the aggressive tactics of the Iroquois Confederation, based in central and western New York.

name: ohio
sentence: After the beaver wars in the mid-17th century, the Iroquois claimed much of Ohio as a hunting ground and, most importantly, as a beaver trap.

name: ohio
sentence: After the devastation of epidemics and war in the mid-17th century, which largely emptied the native country of Ohio in the mid-17th century to the end of the 17th century, the land was gradually repopulated by the mainly Algonquian.

name: ohio
sentence: Many of these Ohio countries were multi-ethnic (sometimes multi-lingual) societies born of the devastation caused by disease, war and subsequent social instability.

name: ohio
sentence: They were still on agriculture (maize, sunflowers, beans, etc.)

name: ohio
sentence: Complemented by seasonal hunting.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, they were part of a larger world economy created by European entry into the fur trade.

name: ohio
sentence: Indigenous nations living in Ohio during the historical period included the Iroquoians, the Algonquians, and the Siwans.

name: ohio
sentence: Ohio was also home to Indian massacres, such as the Yellow Creek massacre, the Gnadenhutten massacre and the Pontiac Rebellion School massacre.

name: ohio
sentence: Most Aboriginal people who remained in Ohio were gradually bought and persuaded to leave, or ordered to do so by law, at the beginning of the 19th century with the Indian Abduction Act of 1830.

name: ohio
sentence: In the 18th century, the French introduced a trading post system to control the fur trade in the region.

name: ohio
sentence: From 1754 on, France and Great Britain fought the French and Indian wars.

name: ohio
sentence: Following the Treaty of Paris, the French gave control of Ohio and the rest of the Old North West to Great Britain.

name: ohio
sentence: In the Treaty of Paris of 1783, Britain ceded to the United States all the claims of the Ohio country.

name: ohio
sentence: The United States created the Northwest Territory under the North-West Order of 1787.

name: ohio
sentence: Slavery is not allowed in the new territory.

name: ohio
sentence: The settlement began with the founding of Marietta by the Ohio Company of Associates, which had been formed by a group of U.S. Revolutionary War veterans.

name: ohio
sentence: As a result of the Ohio Company, the Miami Company (also known as the "Purchase of Symmes") claimed the southwest section, and the Connecticut Land Company surveyed and established the West Connecticut Reserve in the present northeast of Ohio.

name: ohio
sentence: Territorial surveyors at Fort Steuben began to survey approximately at the same time an area in eastern Ohio called the Seven Ranges.

name: ohio
sentence: The former Northwest Territory originally included areas formerly known as Ohio Country and Illinois Country.

name: ohio
sentence: As Ohio was preparing to become a state, Indiana was created, which reduced the territory of the Northwest to about the present size of Ohio, plus half of the lower Michigan peninsula and the eastern tip of the upper peninsula, as well as a portion of the southeast Indiana called "The Gore".

name: ohio
sentence: The coalition of Amerindian tribes, known as the Western Confederation, was forced to divest a vast territory, including much of present-day Ohio, in the Treaty of Greenville in 1795.

name: ohio
sentence: Under the North-West Ordinance, areas could be defined and admitted as states as soon as their population reached 60,000.

name: ohio
sentence: Although the population of Ohio was only 45,000 in December 1801, Congress determined that it was growing rapidly and had already begun the way to the state.

name: ohio
sentence: With regard to the natives of Leni Lenape, the Congress decided that 10,000 acres on the Muskingum River in the present state of Ohio would "be set aside and that their property would be vested in the Moravian Brothers... or a Society of the said Brothers for civilizing the Indians and promoting Christianity."

name: ohio
sentence: Rufus Putnam served prominently in the French and Indian War and the American Revolutionary War.

name: ohio
sentence: He was one of the most respected men of the early years of the United States.

name: ohio
sentence: In 1776 Putnam created a method of construction of portable fortifications, which allowed the Continental Army to drive the British out of Boston.

name: ohio
sentence: George Washington was so impressed that he turned Putnam into his chief engineer.

name: ohio
sentence: After the war, Putnam and Manasseh Cutler contributed to the creation of the Northwest Order, which opened the Northwest Territory to settlement.

name: ohio
sentence: This land was used to compensate for what was owed to the veterans of the revolutionary war.

name: ohio
sentence: It is also on the recommendation of Putnam that the land will be surveyed and arranged in six-square-mile townships.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam organized and led the first group of veterans in the Territory.

name: ohio
sentence: They moved to Marietta, Ohio, where they built a large fort called Campus Martius.

name: ohio
sentence: Putnam and Cutler insisted that the Northwest Territory would be free territory – no slavery.

name: ohio
sentence: They were both from Puritan New England, and the Puritans firmly believed that slavery was morally evil.

name: ohio
sentence: The Northwest Territory doubled the size of the United States and it was extremely important to consider it as slavery-free in the decades that followed.

name: ohio
sentence: It includes what has become Ohio, Indiana, Illinois, Michigan, Wisconsin and part of Minnesota.

name: ohio
sentence: Had these States been slave states and their electoral votes been attributed to Abraham Lincoln's main competitor, Lincoln would not have been elected President.

name: ohio
sentence: Civil war would not have been waged.

name: ohio
sentence: And even if there had been a civil war, the north would probably have lost.

name: ohio

sentence: Oklahoma is a state located in the south-central United States bordered by the state of Texas to the south and west, Kansas to the north, Missouri to the northeast, Arkansas to the east, New Mexico to the west, and Colorado to the northwest.

sentence: Most of the state is located in an area known as the Allée de Tornado, characterized by frequent interactions between cold and dry air in Canada, hot hot air, dry air in Mexico and the southwestern United States, and warm and wet air in the Gulf of Mexico.

sentence: Interactions between these three contrasting air currents produce severe weather (violent thunderstorms, damaging storm winds, large hail and tornadoes) with an almost invisible frequency anywhere else on planet Earth.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: On November 11, 1911, the temperature in Oklahoma City reached 83°F (28°C) (the record of that date), then a cold front of unprecedented intensity slammed through the state, resulting in the temperature reaching 17°F (−8°C) (the record of that date) at midnight.

name: oklahoma
sentence: This type of phenomenon is also responsible for many tornadoes in the region, such as the Oklahoma tornado epidemic in 1912 when a warm front ran through a cold front, which resulted in an average of one tornado per hour.

sentence: Oklahoma is a constitutional republic with a government shaped by the U.S. federal government, with executive, legislative and judicial powers.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma
sentence: The State is divided into 77 counties, each governed by a three-member council of elected commissioners, a tax assessor, clerk, clerk, treasurer and sheriff.

name: oklahoma
sentence: While each municipality operates as a separate and independent local government with executive, legislative and judicial powers, county governments retain jurisdiction over incorporated cities and unincorporated areas within their borders, but have an executive but no legislative or judicial power.

name: oklahoma

name: oklahoma

sentence: The U.S. Census Bureau estimates that Rhode Island's population was 1,059,361 on July 1, 2019, an increase of 0.65% over the 2010 U.S. Census.

sentence: According to the U.S. Census Bureau, in 2015, Rhode Island had an estimated population of 1,056,298, an increase of 1,125, or 0.10%, compared to the previous year and 3,731, or 0.35%, since 2010.

sentence: According to the U.S. Community Survey 2010-2015, the largest ancestry groups were Irish (18.3%), Italian (18.0%), English (10.5%), French (10.4%), and Portuguese (9.3%).

sentence: Rhode Island has a higher percentage of Americans of Portuguese descent, including the Portuguese Americans and Cape Verde Americans than any other state of the nation.

sentence: Italian-Americans form a plurality in central and southern Providence County, and French-Canadians form a large part of northern Providence County.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Although Rhode Island has the smallest area of the 50 states, it has the second highest population density in all the states of the Union, after that of New Jersey.

name: rhode_island
sentence: A Pew survey of the religious self-identification of Rhode Island residents showed the following distribution of affiliations: Roman Catholics 42%, Protestants 30%, Jews 1%, Jehovah's Witnesses 2%, Buddhism 1%, Mormonism 1%, Hinduism 1% and non-religious 20%.

sentence: The largest denominations are the Roman Catholic Church with 456,598 adherents, the Episcopal Church with 19,377, the American Baptist Churches with 15,220, and the United Methodist Church with 6,901 adherents.

sentence: Rhode Island has the largest proportion of Catholic residents in any state, mainly due to Irish, Italian and French-Canadian immigration in the past; recently, large Portuguese communities and various Hispanic communities have also been established in the state.

name: rhode_island
sentence: Although it has the highest overall Catholic percentage of all states, none of the counties of Rhode Island ranks among the 10 most Catholic in the United States, as Catholics are very evenly distributed throughout the state.

sentence: The Jewish community of Rhode Island is centered in the Providence region, and emerged during a wave of Jewish immigration mainly from the shtetls of Eastern Europe between 1880 and 1920.

sentence: The presence of the Synagogue Touro in Newport, the oldest synagogue in the United States, points out that these second wave immigrants did not create the first Jewish community on Rhode Island; a relatively smaller wave of Spanish and Portuguese Jews immigrated to Newport during the colonial era.

sentence: The Rhode Island economy had a colonial base in the fishery.

name: south_carolina

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was the last state to choose voters in this way.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On October 19, 1871, President Ulysses S. Grant suspended habeas corpus in nine counties in South Carolina under the Ku Klux Klan Act.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Headed by the Attorney General of Grant Amos T. Akerman, hundreds of Klansmen were arrested and 2,000 Klansmen fled the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The State became a home of racial and economic tensions during the populist and agrarian movements of the 1890s.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A republican-popularist biracial coalition temporarily took power with the white democrats.

name: south_carolina
sentence: To prevent this from happening again, the Democrats obtained the adoption of a new constitution in 1895 that effectively deprived almost all blacks and many poor whites by new requirements in terms of voting taxes, residence and literacy tests that significantly reduced the electoral roll.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1896, only 5,500 black voters remained on the lists of electors, although they constituted the majority of the population of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1900 census showed the extent of exclusion: the 782,509 African-Americans accounted for more than 58% of the population of the state, but they were essentially without political representation in Jim Crow society.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The 1895 Constitution overturned the local representative government, reducing the role of the counties to the agents of the state government, effectively governed by the General Assembly, through the legislative delegations of each county.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Because each county had a state senator, that person had considerable power.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The counties had no representative government until the adoption of the internal system in 1975.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Governor "Pitchfork Ben Tillman", a populist, led the effort to disfranchise blacks and poor whites, although he controlled democratic state policy from the 1890s to 1910s with a base among the poor white farmers.

name: south_carolina
sentence: During the constitutional assembly of 1895, he supported another man's proposal that the State should adopt a rule of one drop, as well as prohibiting marriage between whites and any person of known African descent.

name: south_carolina

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, South Carolina developed a prosperous textile industry.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The state has also converted its cotton agricultural base into more profitable crops; attracted large military bases through its powerful delegation to the Democratic Congress, a part of the South following the abandonment of the right to vote of blacks at the beginning of the century; and created tourism industries.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In the early 20th century, millions of African Americans left South Carolina and other southern states for jobs, opportunities and relative freedom in American cities outside the former Confederate states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In total from 1910 to 1970, 6.5 million blacks left the South in the Great Migration.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 1930 South Carolina had a white majority for the first time since 1708.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of several states that initially rejected the 19th Amendment (1920) giving women the right to vote.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The South Carolina legislature subsequently ratified the amendment on July 1, 1969.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The civil rights movement's struggle took place in South Carolina as in other states of the South.

sentence: However, South Carolina experienced a much less violent movement than other southern states.

name: south_carolina
sentence: In 2011, South Carolina ranked first in the country with regard to the number of women killed by men.

name: south_carolina
sentence: As the 21st century progressed, South Carolina attracted new businesses with a 5% corporate income tax rate, no state property tax, no local income tax, no inventory tax, no sales tax on manufacturing equipment, industrial energy or materials for finished products, no wholesale tax, and no unit global income tax.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina was one of the first states to stop paying for babies' "early" deliveries under Medicaid and private insurance.

sentence: The term "early elective" is defined as an induction of work or a Caesarean section between 37 and 39 weeks which is not medically based.

sentence: This change is aimed at making babies healthier and reducing unnecessary costs for South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: On November 20, 2014, South Carolina became the 35th state to legalize same-sex marriages when a federal court ordered the change.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina has many places for the visual and performing arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The Gibbes Museum of Art in Charleston, the Greenville County Museum of Art, the Columbia Museum of Art, the Spartanburg Art Museum and the South Carolina State Museum in Columbia, among others, provide access to visual arts.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also many historic sites and museums scattered throughout the state that pay tribute to many events and periods in the history of the state, from Amerindian housing to the present day.

name: south_carolina
sentence: South Carolina also has art halls, including the Peace Center in Greenville, the Koger Center for the Arts in Columbia and the Newberry Opera House, among others, to attract local, national and international talent to South Carolina.

name: south_carolina
sentence: Several major venues can host major events, including Colonial Life Arena in Columbia, Bon Secours Wellness Arena in Greenville, and North Charleston Coliseum.

name: south_carolina
sentence: One of the country's main performing arts festivals, Spoleto Festival USA, is held annually in Charleston.

name: south_carolina
sentence: There are also countless local festivals throughout the state that highlight many cultural traditions, historical events and folklore.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the South Carolina Arts Commission, creative industries generate $9.2 billion a year and support over 78,000 jobs in the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: A 2009 government-wide survey conducted by the University of South Carolina's Institute for Public Service and Policy Research found that 67% of residents had participated in the arts in some form in the past year and that, on average, citizens had participated in the arts 14 times in the previous year.

name: south_carolina

sentence: The fourth largest is the African Methodist Episcopal Church with 564 congregations and 121,000 members, and the fifth largest is the Presbyterian Church (USA) with 320 congregations and nearly 100,000 members.

sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was the US state with the highest proportion of citizens per capita following the Bahá'í Faith, with 17,559 adherents, making Bahá'í the second religion of the state.

name: south_carolina
sentence: According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, as of March 2012, South Carolina had 1,852,700 non-agricultural jobs, of which 12 per cent were in manufacturing, 11.5 per cent in recreation and hospitality, 19 per cent in commerce, transportation and public services, and 11.8 per cent in education and health services.

name: south_carolina
sentence: The service sector accounts for 83.7% of South Carolina's economy.

sentence: There are 36 TV channels (including PBS affiliates) serving South Carolina with terrestrial access and some online streaming.

sentence: The State has the fourth largest state system in the country, consisting of 11 interstates, numbered highways, state highways and secondary roads, with a total of approximately 41,500 miles.

sentence: In 2010, South Carolina was one of three states that did not agree to use competitive international mathematics and language standards.

sentence: South Carolina has a variety of institutions, ranging from large state-funded research universities to small colleges that cultivate liberal arts, religious or military traditions.

name: south_carolina
